Volume was below average. The game software maker's earnings growth is lumpy, depending on the success of the most recently released games. Over the past…

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) earned a price-target hike for its stock on Tuesday thanks to its upcoming release slate, including World War I combat game "Battlefield 1."Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey reiterated his buy rating on EA stock and upped his price target to 98.54 from 93.65.On Monday, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson restated his overweight rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 89 from 88.EA stock edged up 0.3% to close at 82.99 on the stock market today. EA hit an all-time high of 84.45 on Sept. 6.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts has solid IBD Composite Rating of 93, but it ranks No. 3 out of 15 stocks in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which companies lead the sector, visit the IBD Stock Checkup."We remain impressed with the company's current game slate, and suspect the potential for meaningful upside relative (to) financial expectations," Hickey said.Like other major console game publishers, EA is benefiting from the shift to higher-margin digital game downloads and the sweet spot of the console upgrade cycle.The buzz for EA's "Battlefield 1" has been strong and it should profit from the large installed base of current-generation consoles, namely Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, Hickey said."Battlefield 1" will be released on Oct. 21. Its biggest competition will be "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI), which comes out Nov. 4.Activision stock ended virtually flat Tuesday at 44.13, trading just below its record high of 44.84, reached on Monday.Piper's Olson raised his sales and earnings estimates for EA based on increasing confidence in the success of "Battlefield 1."The game's developer recently concluded a beta test period that drew in 13 million players, a company record. That compares with 9 million players for the beta test last year of EA's "Star Wars Battlefront."Olson now believes EA will sell 14 million units of "Battlefield 1" this fiscal year, up from his prior forecast for 12 million units.RELATED:Sony Unveils Mid-Cycle Refresh To PlayStation 4 Game ConsoleActivision Stock Stakes New High After 'Call Of Duty' Fan Fest

Posing a threat to eBay (EBAY) and Craigslist, Facebook (FB) launched its own online venue designed to formalize a local buying and selling process that was already taking place on its "Groups" feature.Facebook said the new service, called Marketplace, will be rolling out in the U.S., U.K., Australia and New Zealand over the next few days on the Facebook app for the Apple (APPL) iPhone and Alphabet (GOOGL) Android.Facebook said more than 450 million people already visit sites on Facebook each month where people buy and sell goods."To help people make more of these connections, today we're introducing Marketplace, a convenient destination to discover, buy and sell items with people in your community," wrote Mary Ku, director of product management in a blog post.Facebook stock was up a fraction, near 128.50, in afternoon trading in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Investors should focus on buying leading stocks in an industry group. Among social networks, there's no doubt that Facebook is a leader, with an IBD Composite Rating of 99, the highest possible. It's also an IBD Leaderboard stock. Facebook is holding above its 50-day moving average but hasn't made much progress after a breakout over a 128.43 buy point.EBay stock, which fell 5% in morning trading, was down about 1%, near 32.50, in afternoon trading. EBay hit a new high last week of 33.19 as Deutsche Bank issued a buy rating and said the e-commerce giant might be the best internet growth story heading into 2017.To visit Marketplace, users just tap on the shop icon at the bottom of the Facebook app. It opens with photos of items that people nearby have listed for sale. Users can find something specific by using a search bar. It also provides filters than can present results by location, category and price. Sellers and buyers then work out a sales price and shipment plans. Facebook said it does not facilitate the payment or delivery of items in Marketplace."We will continue expanding to additional countries and make Marketplace available on the desktop version of Facebook in the coming months," Ku wrote.RELATED:Facebook Holding Steady Near Recent Buy PointNew High For eBay On Bullish Report Saying Best Days Are AheadNo Need To Ask Jeeves When You Can Ask Apple, Amazon, Facebook, GoogleFacebook's Zuckerberg, Nvidia, Qualcomm, EA, Top Insider TradesStocks Near Buy Zone: Who Joins Facebook, Biogen And Broadcom?

The video-game industry is at a crossroads this holiday season as consumers must decide in what form they want to purchase new game software.Will they buy packaged game software so their kids will have something to open on Christmas morning? Or will they buy game software as digital downloads?How consumers respond will impact the top and bottom lines for game publishers and retailers.The biggest game publishers such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) lately have been benefiting from the move to digital downloads, which carry fatter profit margins.IBD'S TAKE: IBD Swing Trader uses CAN SLIM technical and fundamental research to find potential hits, not home runs. The goal is 10% profit within five to 10 days, with losses cut at 3%. Take-Two has been a Swing Trader stock of late.Retailers like GameStop (GME) and Best Buy (BBY) have been hurt by the shift to digital game distribution. But they might be able to compensate for that this holiday season thanks to the availability of new midcycle game consoles and the launch of virtual-reality headsets."Nothing is better under the Christmas tree than a box to open that has an actual gift," NPD analyst Mat Piscatella told IBD.Piscatella said he's seen no data yet to indicate that digital game download rates will be higher this holiday season. Video-game publishers have said top titles can sell 30% of units as digital downloads now. But what percentage is gifted is not known, Piscatella said.Many of those downloads probably are purchased by adult gamers who just want to play a new game right away, without having to get a physical game disc, he said.But game downloads have some disadvantages, such as having to wait for a huge digital file to download and install."You get it on Christmas Day and hopefully you're playing by New Year's," joked DFC Intelligence analyst David Cole.Publishers are offering special editions of games with collectibles and other extras to entice gamers to buy physical copies.At the same time, publishers are incentivizing gamers to get digital downloads by bundling in online season passes and pre-release game play.GameStop has been a canary in the coal mine for changes in the industry. On Tuesday, it reported disappointing fiscal third-quarter sales due in part to the increase in game software downloads.GameStop said new game titles sold below expectations for its fiscal Q3 ended Oct. 29. Analysts say Activision's "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" was among the games that came up short in physical game sales at GameStop last quarter.On the plus side, GameStop said the Nov. 18 release of Nintendo's (NTDOY) "Pokemon Sun and Moon" was the retailer's biggest game launch of the year. Nintendo games tend to have a lower digital download rate than those from other publishers. Nintendo customers tend to be younger.Other major game releases this fall include "Battlefield 1" and "Titanfall 2" from Electronic Arts and "Mafia 3" from Take-Two Interactive Software.Annual sports titles are likely to be big sellers this holiday season, including EA's "Madden NFL 17" and "FIFA 17" and Take-Two's "NBA 2K17" and "WWE 2K17."Other games looking to rack up big sales this Christmas include "Watch Dogs 2" from Ubisoft, "Dishonored 2" from Bethesda Softworks, and "Final Fantasy 15" from Square Enix.Publishers are cashing in on the sweet spot of the current game console cycle, where there's a large installed base of consoles in which to sell big game titles.Sony (SNE) is expected to have an installed base of 50 million PlayStation 4 consoles worldwide by year's end, DFC Intelligence said. Rival Microsoft (MSFT) is seen having 28 million Xbox One consoles in use by the end of 2016, DFC said.Game hardware revenue has been in decline this year because of market saturation and lower prices for consoles. Sony and Microsoft are hoping to change that with the recent launch of redesigned and souped-up versions of current consoles. Microsoft has the Xbox One S and Sony has the PlayStation 4 Pro and PS4 Slim. Plus, Nintendo has a retro console in its NES Classic Edition, which comes preinstalled with 30 games.Next year will bring two next-generation consoles: the Nintendo Switch and Microsoft Scorpio.This is the first Christmas season for virtual-reality headsets, including the games-focused Sony PlayStation VR. Other VR headsets include Facebook's (FB) Oculus Rift and HTC's Vive. Plus, there are low-cost VR headsets that use smartphone screens as their display, such as the Samsung Gear VR.Among the big VR games already out are "Batman: Arkham VR" from Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, a unit of Time Warner (TWX), and "NBA 2KVR Experience" from Take-Two. Electronic Arts is releasing its "Star Wars Battlefront Rogue One: X-Wing VR Mission" on Dec. 6."PS VR launch bundles being sold out pretty much everywhere is a positive sign" for adoption of virtual reality, Piscatella said. "There's a lot of excitement around (gaming) hardware and accessories this holiday."But this could be just a get-to-know-you period for VR. Best Buy, GameStop and others are offering demonstrations of VR systems in their stores to acquaint shoppers with the technology."Consumers haven't really been introduced to it yet," Cole told IBD. "2017 is the year that VR really gets started."Best Buy rolled out virtual-reality products to all of its stores during its fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 29, and it has dedicated virtual-reality departments in more than 700 stores, CEO Hubert Joly told analysts on a conference call Nov. 17.Best Buy has given more than 300,000 virtual-reality demonstrations to customers so far, Joly said.And GameStop Chief Operating Officer Tony Bartel said the new gaming hardware products are "bright spots" for GameStop."We're seeing strong demand for new consoles, the PS4 Pro is off to a strong start and VR is generally on the shelves for less than 10 days," he said on a conference call with analysts. "We're also seeing solid consumer interest for the upcoming launch of Switch from Nintendo."The Switch uses physical media and Nintendo products have historically had a low digital download rate, so we expect this to be a console that drives strong sales of physical product along with the console."Activision stock fell a fraction to 37.22 in the stock market today, a half-day session that ended at 1 p.m. ET. Shares touched an all-time high of 45.55 on Oct. 25, but also hit a four-month low of 36.32 on Wednesday.EA stock also fell a fraction Friday, to 79.17. It's forming a flat base with a possible buy point of 86.17. Take-Two stock rose 0.68% to 48.81, in buy range after hitting a 46.88 buy point on Nov. 3 out of a flat base, and touching a record high of 50.19 on Nov. 7.GameStop shares fell nearly 1% Friday, while Best Buy stock fell 0.8% to 46.58. Best Buy touched a six-year-plus high of 47.29, buoyed by its earnings beat on Nov. 17.RELATED:Wireless Headphones, 4K TVs, Drones Top Christmas Wish ListsRoomba Maker iRobot Hopes To Clean Up This ChristmasBest Buy Posts Q3 Earnings Surprise, Sparked By iPhone 7, 4K TVs

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) late Tuesday reported better-than-expected September-quarter results and raised its full-year guidance.EA stock initially fell in after-hours trading as investors worried about light holiday sales guidance. But shares then rallied, rising more than 6% in extended trading. During the regular session Tuesday, EA stock dropped 0.9% to 77.84.EA earned 53 cents a share excluding items, down 18% year over year but better than the consensus estimate of 43 cents.Under generally accepted accounting principles, EA lost 13 cents a share in its fiscal second quarter ended Sept. 30.EA's adjusted revenue rose 10% to $1.098 billion, topping the consensus estimate of $1.085 billion.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 88, meaning it has outperformed 88% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it ranks No. 3 out of 15 companies in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, EA forecast adjusted sales of $2.04 billion, below the $2.08 billion consensus. For the fiscal year, EA guided to net revenue plus deferred net revenue of $4.925 billion. That's up from its previous guidance of $4.9 billion, said Baird analyst Colin Sebastian."Q2 was an excellent quarter for Electronic Arts, led by breakthrough new EA Sports titles engaging players across console and mobile," EA CEO Andrew Wilson said in a statement. "We are in an outstanding position for the quarter ahead, with two of the highest-rated games of this console generation in 'Battlefield 1' and 'Titanfall 2,' global competitive gaming tournaments underway, and our first virtual-reality experiences coming soon."Across all platforms, this holiday season will be a fantastic time to play."Redwood City, Calif.-based EA is "raising our annual guidance today based on the strength of our holiday slate and FIFA 17's strong performance to date," EA CFO Blake Jorgensen said in the earnings release.RELATED:Activision Blasts Higher Ahead Of Year's Biggest Game ReleaseTake-Two Gunning For Big Game Release With 'Red Dead' Sequel

Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) received an upbeat report Monday from Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey, just days after the company issued disappointing holiday-quarter guidance.Activision stock finished trading down 1.4% to 41.10 on the stock market today. On Friday, Activision shares dropped 3.9% to 41.70, a day after it reported third-quarter results and gave Q4 guidance.Hickey reiterated his buy rating on Activision and raised his price target to 50.87 from 49.79.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision late Thursday said it earned 52 cents a share excluding items on sales of $1.63 billion in Q3. Analysts were expecting 42 cents adjusted EPS and $1.57 billion in sales.IBD'S TAKE: Activision stock has a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. It ranks No. 21 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.For the December quarter, Activision forecast non-GAAP earnings per share of 74 cents on sales of $2.38 billion. Wall Street was modeling 80 cents and $2.48 billion.Activision typically gives conservative guidance, Hickey said in a report.Drivers in the current quarter include sci-fi shooter game "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" and youth-focused action-adventure game "Skylanders: Imaginators," he said.Longer-term business drivers include e-sports ventures and advertising in King Digital games, Hickey said.Also Monday, Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald reiterated his buy rating on Activision with a price target of 55 after the company's sold-out BlizzCon conference.The two-day conference was held Friday and Saturday in Anaheim, Calif. A crowd of 25,000 Blizzard game fans experienced the show in person and millions more watched online. The event featured professional video game tournaments, cosplay contests, developer panels and product announcements."The biggest announcement was the creation of a new pro eSports league for 'Overwatch,'" Fitzgerald said in a research report. "Over time, Activision aspires to build the NFL and ESPN of video games, and the new league will serve as a foundation upon which this business is built."BMO Capital Markets analyst Gerrick Johnson struck a cautious tone after Activision's Q3 report.Activision blamed foreign-exchange effects for the reduction in its Q4 sales outlook, but many investors weren't buying it."Given its history of guiding conservatively, one would have thought there would be enough wiggle room in guidance to absorb currency fluctuations," Johnson said in a report. "This leads us to wonder if the company really is concerned about the performance of 'Call of Duty' in the quarter, especially as it goes face to face with two strong EA (EA) shooters that had a bit of a head start this season, 'Battlefield 1' and 'Titanfall 2.'"RELATED:Electronic Arts Stock Gets Price-Target Hikes On Upbeat Q2 ReportTake-Two Jumps To New High On Slam-Dunk Q2 Earnings

United Natural Foods (UNFI), a longtime grocery distributor to Whole Foods Market (WFM), easily topped fiscal fourth-quarter profit forecasts and gave bullish full-year sales guidance after the close Monday.Estimates: Earnings per share of 63 cents, down 12.5%, on revenue of $2.218 billion, up 7.6%.Results: EPS of 69 cents or 70 cents ex items on sales of $2.21 billion.Prior Quarter: Fiscal Q3 EPS fell 8%, the third straight quarterly decline. Sales rose 1%, the sixth straight quarter of decelerating growth.Outlook: Fiscal 2017 GAAP EPS of $2.53-$2.63 on sales of $9.43 billion-$9.6 billion. Analysts see EPS of $2.69 on sales of $9.39 billion.Stock: Shares were up 0.2% in late trading, down from an earlier 9% surge, after closing up 0.5% at 41.82 in the stock market today. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base in June following the organic grocery distributor's last quarterly report, but shares have trended downward since the middle of last month, below their 50-day line.Why It Matters:  United Natural Foods' results will come as the grocery sector deals with an oversupply in some types of food -- particularly meat, poultry and dairy -- that have dragged prices lower and forced grocery stores into more aggressive promotions that some have compared to the industrywide price wars that took place in 2009.SuperValu (SVU), a grocery-store operator and distributor, last week warned about lower food prices and said Wal-Mart (WMT), which is undertaking a big price-cutting campaign, has "always been a tough competitor." Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), a natural-foods rival to Whole Foods, also slashed its full-year guidance.Cowen on Monday upgraded Wal-Mart's stock to outperform from market perform and raised its price target to 83 from 76.Some analysts also believe Wal-Mart's discounting has hurt dollar stores. In reporting their quarterly results last month, Dollar General (DG) last month cited retail "food deflation" as a problem, while Dollar Tree (DLTR) management spoke of a "challenging retail sales environment."And grocery-store operator Kroger (KR) last week attempted to downplay Wal-Mart's effect on sales, but it cut its full-year earnings-per-share forecast due to "continued deflation." Telsey Advisory Group on Monday cut its price target on Kroger to 40 to 46. Kroger shares fell more than 2% to 30.82, a fresh 52-week low.IBD'S TAKE: Cheaper groceries have also hurt the restaurant business, with more people opting to save money and eat in. However, Papa John's in recent days has flirted with a buy point. See why stocks like Papa John's and Domino's Pizza are rising above rival restaurants.Sprouts Farmers Market fell 1.2% and Whole Foods shed 0.7%, while Wal-Mart rose 2.3%. Dollar Tree rose 0.9% and Dollar General gained 2.%. SuperValu edged up 0.4%.RELATED:Grocery Chains Reeling From Low Food Prices, Stiff CompetitionTarget Downgraded; Wal-Mart, Vale, Rio Tinto Upgraded; EA PT Hiked

Stocks struggled to build on gains as trading approached midday Thursday, but all three major indexes were at least tentatively in positive ground.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each were up 0.2% while Dow Jones industrial average gained a smidgen on the stock market today. The small-cap Russell 2000 outperformed with a 0.6% gain. Volume was tracking lower than the same time Wednesday on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.Chinese online gaming site NetEase (NTES) had risen in premarket action after what appeared to be a good earnings report. But NetEase dropped at the open and was trading down nearly 3%. The company reported earnings of $3.67 a share, an 89% increase from a year earlier and well above estimates. That blew away estimates of $2.82. Revenue rose 83% to $1.35 billion vs. estimates of $1.27 billion.The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 179.20 buy point June 29 and made a 20% advance earlier this week, putting it in a profit-taking zone, according to CAN SLIM rules.IBD'S TAKE: See how NetEase measures up with other companies in the gaming software industry group with IBD's Stock Checkup.Overnight, Asian markets were mixed, with the Japanese Nikkei average dropping 1.6% after the government reported no GDP growth in the April-June quarter, missing already-modest forecasts.West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures for September delivery rose 72 cents or 1.5% to $47.51 on continued talk about a production freeze. It is the sixth straight daily increase and the the 10th increase in 12 days in a rally that began with oil below $40.Electronics Arts (EA) rose nearly 2%, breaking out of a flat base with an 80.09 buy point. Volume was above average.

Investors moved the chains for Electronic Arts (EA) on Tuesday as the stock reached an all-time high on prospects for the company's "Madden NFL 17" football video game.EA stock rose 1% to 82.31 on the stock market today. Earlier, EA stock hit a record high of 82.61. EA broke out of a flat base with an 80.09 buy point last Thursday.EA's move happened as the Nasdaq composite also hit an intraday record high Tuesday. Other video game stocks rose as well, including Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).Activision climbed 1.3% to 40.64, and Take-Two rose 2.3% to 42.25 on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer Software-Gaming group is ranked No. 26 out of 197 industry groups. Two companies from the group, NetEase and Activision Blizzard, are on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.On Tuesday, Electronic Arts released "Madden NFL 17," the latest in its long-running pro football game series. It can be played on Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 3 and 4 consoles and on Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox 360 and Xbox One consoles.In a research report Monday, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson reiterated his overweight rating and price target of 88 on EA stock. He said his sales estimates for the new Madden game could be "overly conservative.""Madden NFL 17" has a current average Metacritic rating of 83.5, which is in line with last year's game (84 rating) but ahead of the 10-year average of 81.9, he said."Given solid scores and a larger next-gen console base, it appears our Madden estimate for 5.5 million units through fiscal 2017 (flat year over year), may prove conservative," Olson said. "Overall, EA appears poised to benefit from continued growth of the hardware installed base, as the company has a strong slate of titles through second-half calendar 2016, highlighted by 'Battlefield 1' and 'Titanfall 2' in October."RELATED:Most-Anticipated Video Game Is Out Of This World.

Three Wall Street firms hiked price targets on Intel (INTC), Citigroup increased PTs of Facebook (FB) and Applied Materials (AMAT), and Needham upped PTs of Lumentum (LITE) and Finisar (FNSR) amid an emerging supercycle for optical parts makers.Citigroup hiked its price target on Facebook to 158 from 148. "Investor concerns about the impact of decelerating ad load growth on ad revenue growth for core Facebook appear overblown," said analyst Mark May in a report. Ad load growth refers to the number of ads Facebook can serve up to its users. Another worry is Snapchat's growth. "Investor concerns about the impact from Snapchat's growth on core Facebook's user and user engagement growth appear unfounded," May added.Facebook shares dipped 0.3% to close at 128.65 on the stock market today. The stock is above a buy point of 128.43, but investors should be cautious about making any buys in the current market.RELATED:Fed, Facebook, Disney, Netflix Lead Weekly Investing Action PlanJefferies upped its PT to 49 from 44, Needham hiked its PT to 43 from 38, and Mizuho Securities raised its PT to 42 from 38. Intel on Friday raised its Q3 revenue target. Intel has been winning more business for the Apple (AAPL) iPhone, with modem chips in many new iPhone handsets. "We like the setup on the stock as our checks indicate accelerating demand for high margin server microprocessors from hyperscale players (internet companies)," said Jefferies analyst Mark Lipicas, in a report.Intel shares fell 1.4% to close at 37.16 after climbing 3% on Friday, hitting a 15-year high intraday.RELATED:Intel Stock Earns Price-Target Hikes On Apple, PC DevelopmentsNeedham raised its PT on Lumentum Holdings to 50 from 40 and hiked Finisar's PT to 36 from 32. Needham also reiterated a buy rating on Fabrinet (FN). IBD's Telecom-Fiber Optics group is ranked No. 1 out of 197 groups amid surging demand for 100 gigabit-per-second optical devices for data centers and metro area networks and strong demand in China.Lumentum jumped 3.4% to finish at 40.55 while Finisar climbed 1.9% to close at 28.74.RELATED: U.S. Optical Firms Dominate Supercycle As Chinese Rivals LagCitigroup increased its PT on Applied Materials to 37 from 32, citing demand for smartphone screens and 3D flash memory. The maker of semiconductor manufacturing gear hosts an investor day on Wednesday.Applied Materials rose 0.8% to end the trading day at 30.30.MKM Partners downgraded Arista Networks to neutral from buy and its shares dropped 3.5% to 82.03. Arista is No. 1 in IBD's computer networking group.In other analyst moves, Bank of America upgraded Cerner (CERN) to buy, Robert W. Baird upgraded Wells Fargo (WFC) to outperform, and Stifel downgraded Viacom (VIA) to neutral from buy on reports that the media company's board of directors has decided to table plans to sell a minority interest in film studio Paramount. Cowen increased GrubHub's (GRUB) PT to 38 from 33 and hiked Panera Bread's PT to 250 from 240. Piper Jaffray bumped up Electronic Arts' (EA) PT to 89 from 88. It's No. 3 in IBD's Software-Computer Gaming group while Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is No. 1. Morgan Stanley upgraded General Motors (GM) to outperform.

The stock indexes pared gains in Friday's final minutes, but closed the session higher and erased most of their losses from Thursday's drubbing.The S&P 500 rose 0.8%, fading in the final minutes to close just below the 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq also rose 0.8% while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 advanced 1.1%. The Dow utilities average, however, slid 0.8%.Volume was tracking lower across the board. Friday is the final day of the third quarter, and that can result in some volatility as fund managers make last-minute "window dressing" moves to make their portfolios look as good as possible.Retail stocks were among the strongest in Friday's trading. The sector's rise got started with Costco's (COST) 3.4% burst on better-than-expected earnings. Same-store sales rose 3%, excluding fuel and currency factors. The stock bounced after falling for seven weeks.IBD's Retail-Major Discount Chains industry group also got a boost from Wal-Mart (WMT), which climbed 2% after KeyBanc late Thursday initiated coverage on the stock with an overweight rating and a 90 price target. Costco and Wal-Mart are basing but remain below their 50-day moving averages.In online retail, Amazon.com (AMZN) made a new high and was among the stocks drawing the most volume on a relative basis. The stock is extended after finding support at its 50-day moving average a couple of weeks ago. Amazon was already a big winner from a breakout in April, when it made its second touch of the 50-day line. Yet, it has continued to march higher from that follow-on entry.Financials bounced back on a report that Deutsche Bank (DB) was close to settling a mortgage-securities case with U.S. regulators for $5.4 billion, far less than the $14 billion that the Justice Department sought. Deutsche shares jumped 14%. The SPDR Financial (XLF) exchange traded fund was up 1.4% after sinking 1.4% on Thursday.Mettler-Toledo International (MTD) broke out of a flat base, rising 3% and clearing the 416.85 buy point.  But volume was light. The company, which was added to the S&P 500 index about a month ago, makes precision measuring equipment and is the largest supplier of inspection systems for food, medicine and other industries.RELATED:Facebook's Zuckerberg, Nvidia, Qualcomm, EA, Top Insider TradesDeutsche Bank Jumps On Report $5.4 Billion Settlement NearAre Markets Voting For Clinton — Or For Divided Government?

In analyst action Monday: Target (TGT) got a thumbs down while Wal-Mart (WMT) received a thumbs up from the same firm. Kroger (KR) was subject to a price target haircut. Electronic Arts (EA) got a bump in price goal. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) stock reached a record high on Tuesday, the first trading day since the video game publisher's sold-out three-day fan festival for its "Call of Duty" franchise.Activision stock was up 1.7% to 43.51 at the close on the stock market today. Intraday, the stock hit a record high of 43.69 in above-average trading volume.IBD'S TAKE: Activision Blizzard is one of four notable tech stocks near buy points investors should be watching this week. The others are Apple, Broadcom and Silicon Motion Technology.Over the Labor Day weekend, Activision held its Call of Duty XP event in Inglewood, Calif. The fan show featured a game tournament, various amusements and previews of upcoming releases in the military shooter franchise, including "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare," due out Nov. 4. About 10,000 fans attended the event.Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi on Monday raised his price target on Activision stock to 48 from 46 and reiterated his buy rating."We attended Activision Blizzard's sold-out Call of Duty XP event at the Forum in L.A., and walked away incrementally more positive on this year's CoD title and the franchise in general," Doshi said in a research report. "We played the new CoD game and yes, we like it. After spending more time with 'Infinite Warfare,' we see numerous signs of continued innovation that players will enjoy."Baird analyst Colin Sebastian on Tuesday maintained his outperform rating on Activision stock and price target of 46."While there are some lingering investor concerns regarding the sales outlook for 'Infinite Warfare,' our conversations with game reviewers and other attendees (at Call of Duty XP) suggest the title should be good enough to attract the generally loyal 'Call of Duty' fan base," Sebastian said.E-sports, or professional video-game playing, was a clear focus of the XP event, Sebastian said. Activision believes e-sports could be a billion-dollar market opportunity over the long term, largely through sponsorships and digital sales.Rival video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) also hit a record high on Tuesday, climbing 0.5% past Friday's previous record to finish the regular session of trading at 83.87. Intraday, it hit an all-time high of 84.45.RELATED:Video Game Publisher Stocks Notch Record HighsActivision Blizzard Reinvigorates 'World of Warcraft' Franchise

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) received at least five price-target hikes on its stock after posting better-than-expected fiscal second-quarter results and raising its full-year sales guidance late Tuesday.EA late Tuesday said it earned 53 cents a share excluding items, down 18% year over year but better than the consensus estimate of 43 cents, in its fiscal Q2 ended Sept. 30. Under generally accepted accounting principles, EA lost 13 cents a share in Q2.EA's adjusted revenue rose 10% to $1.098 billion, topping the consensus estimate of $1.085 billion. On a GAAP basis, revenue rose 10% to $898 million.For the current quarter, EA forecast adjusted sales of $2.04 billion, below the $2.08 billion consensus. For the fiscal year, EA guided to net revenue plus deferred net revenue of $4.925 billion, up from previous guidance for $4.9 billion.IBD'S TAKE: EA stock plunged through its 50-day moving average line in a bearish sign on Friday. Investors looking for leading stocks to add to their watch lists should read the article, "Stocks Near A Buy Zone: Activision In Buy Range Ahead Of Q3 Earnings.""We are optimistic on holiday titles 'Titanfall 2' and especially 'Battlefield 1,' by far the more important game, in our view," Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald said in a report. "'Battlefield' is a best-case scenario in terms of profitability. It is 100% owned-IP (no royalties) with a big PC audience (lots of high-margin downloads). We expect robust sales through year-end for both games."EA's Q2 outperformance was driven by the success of sports game "FIFA 17," he said.Fitzgerald rates EA stock as buy, with a price target of 105.EA stock rose 1.6% on the stock market today to 79.12. The stock broke out at 80.09 on Aug. 18, so it remains in a possible buy zone, though shares last week fell below the 50-day key support line and remain there, a bearish signal.After the earnings report, EA stock got price-target hikes from brokerage firms Baird, Benchmark, Mizuho, Piper Jaffray and Wedbush.Some analysts expressed concerns that science-fiction shooter game "Titanfall 2" is not selling well."Management said little about 'Titanfall 2" other than that they were proud of the game's quality (which they should be) and that they think it will have good legs through the holiday," Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said in a report. Creutz thinks "Titanfall 2" sales could be disappointing enough to push EPS below expectations.Creutz rates EA stock as market perform with a price target of 82."Battlefield 1," released Oct. 21, and "Titanfall 2," released last Friday, will face stiff competition from Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare," which comes out Friday, BMO Capital Markets analyst Gerrick Johnson said in a report.RELATED:Activision Blasts Higher Ahead Of Year's Biggest Game ReleaseTake-Two Gunning For Big Game Release With 'Red Dead' Sequel

Buying shares in a company just ahead of its quarterly results — no matter how much you know about the stock or the company itself — can still feel like a flip of the coin. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) stock tumbled to a two-month low Friday after the video game publisher gave a holiday sales forecast that undershot Wall Street's expectations.Activision shares fell as much as 5.8% in early trading on the stock market today, and closed down 3.85% to 41.70. Activision stock hit a record high of 45.55 on Oct. 25.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision late Thursday reported third-quarter results that beat estimates. It earned 52 cents a share excluding items, topping the consensus estimate of 42 cents. Sales rose 57% to $1.63 billion, above analyst estimates for $1.57 billion.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Activision earned 26 cents a share in Q3, up 53% and beating the estimate of 11 cents EPS.For the December quarter, Activision forecast non-GAAP earnings per share of 74 cents on sales of $2.38 billion. Wall Street was modeling 80 cents and $2.48 billion.IBD'S TAKE: Activision stock has a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. It ranks No. 15 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.Video game companies Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) this week both raised their Q4 guidance, though EA's outlook still came in a tad below Wall Street expectations. They both also posted Q3 beats, and their shares popped on the news.Analysts have been expecting a big holiday season for Activision, led by futuristic combat game "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare," which was released Friday.Activision's below-the-Street guidance "is likely due to the company factoring in a healthy layer of conservatism around 'Call of Duty'," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a research report. "Activision management has historically under-promised and over-delivered, exceeding its original EPS guidance on average by 19% in the past 7 years."Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Activision stock with a price target of 51.Activision could see "meaningful upside to estimates as management pursues large new opportunities in e-sports, in-game advertising, and micro-transactions," Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald said in a report. "Advertising is a potential billion-dollar business and is not included in Street estimates."Fitzgerald rates Activision stock a buy with a price target of 55.At least three brokerages raised their price targets on Activision stock after its Q3 beat: Baird, Cowen and Wedbush.Activision's Q3 results were driven by its deep portfolio of game franchises, which include "World of Warcraft," "Overwatch," and "Call of Duty," Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said in a report.Sebastian upped his price target on Activision to 50 from 46 and maintained his outperform rating.Take-Two shares rose 1 cent to 48.30 Friday while EA dipped 0.4% to 80.22.RELATED:Take-Two Jumps To New High On Slam-Dunk Q2 EarningsElectronic Arts Stock Gets Price-Target Hikes On Upbeat Q2 Report

Sony (SNE) on Wednesday launched two new versions of its market-leading PlayStation 4 video game console, following rival Microsoft (MSFT) in coming out with mid-cycle hardware updates.Sony introduced a slimmer, lighter, more energy-efficient PS4 with a 500-gigabyte hard-disk drive costing $299. It will be available starting Sept. 15.Sony also debuted its PlayStation 4 Pro console, which has improved image-processing capability and support for 4K quality images. PS4 Pro will be available on Nov. 10 for $399. It features a 1-terabyte hard-disk drive and faster central and graphics processing units. The device is optimized for Sony's upcoming PlayStation VR virtual reality headset, due out Oct. 13.IBD'S TAKE: Living-room game consoles like those from Sony and Microsoft create a platform for software publishers to sell game titles. One major publisher, Activision Blizzard, is included on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.On Aug. 2, Microsoft began selling its Xbox One S, a smaller and more capable version of the original Xbox One. The Xbox One S features a 2-terabyte hard-disk drive and starts at $299.Sony and Microsoft introduced their current-generation consoles in November 2013. Their newest consoles are considered refreshed versions of those devices, not the next-generation of gaming consoles.Video game publishers such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) are benefiting from the sweet spot in the console upgrade cycle when the installed base of new consoles is big enough to support major game software releases.RELATED:Activision Stock Stakes New High After 'Call Of Duty' Fan Fest

The three biggest U.S. video game publishers saw their stocks hit record highs on Friday as the industry heads into its traditionally strong fall and holiday shopping seasons.Activision Blizzard (ATVI) stock hit an all-time intraday high of 43.10 as the company opened a sold-out "Call of Duty" fan show. The three-day event, called Call of Duty XP, is being held at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif. It features a game tournament and previews of upcoming releases in the military shooter franchise, including "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare," due out Nov. 4.Activision announced that it will offer a free virtual-reality game to owners of "Infinite Warfare" on Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 consoles and PlayStation VR headsets. The game, called "Jackal Assault," will put players into the cockpit of a Jackal fighter jet from "Infinite Warfare."Activision stock ended the Friday up 1.6%, at 42.81.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer Software-Gaming sector ranks No. 16 out of 197 industry groups. Two companies from the group, NetEase and Activision, are on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.Electronic Arts (EA) stock jumped to a record intraday high of 84.18 on Friday. It closed up 2.1% to 83.46.EA released its latest pro football game, "Madden NFL 17," on Aug. 23. Other big upcoming game releases include "Battlefield 1," out Oct. 21, and "Titanfall 2," out Oct. 28.Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) stock rose to a record intraday high of 45.04. It ended the day Friday up 2.2% to 44.70.Take-Two announced Friday that "Creed" actor Michael B. Jordan will star in the role-playing MyCareer storyline in the pro basketball game, "NBA 2K17," due out Sept. 20.Activision, EA and Take-Two are benefiting from the console-upgrade cycle and the shift to digital game downloads, which carry higher profit margins.RELATED:'Pokemon Go' Grosses Nearly Twice As Much As Latest 'Star Trek' MovieActivision Blizzard Reinvigorates 'World of Warcraft' FranchiseElectronic Arts Breaks Tackles, Hits New High On NFL Game Launch

Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) had a big day, rising 1.93, or 4.6%, to close at 44.17, a new high after the company announced a free download to get the ball rolling toward the Sept. 9 released of its "NBA 2K17" video game. Shares of Take-Two were extended from any buy point, but is noteworthy because it is…

A survey of current-generation console video game players picked "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI) as the most-anticipated new video game."Infinite Warfare," the latest in the long-running "Call of Duty" series, is a first-person shooter game set in the distant future that takes place on Earth, in space and across the solar system. It is scheduled for release on Nov. 4 for Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4, Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Windows PCs.Piper Jaffray, in a research report Monday, said it surveyed over 100 PS4 and Xbox One owners to gauge purchase intent for new video games.When asked about upcoming games, 33% were "most excited" to purchase "Infinite Warfare." That compares with a year-ago survey where 27% of respondents chose "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," the previous installment in the series, as their most-anticipated game.Piper analyst Michael Olson said the strong demand for "Infinite Warfare" alleviates concerns about possible "franchise fatigue."IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer Software Gaming group ranks No. 54 out of 197 industry groups. China's NetEase has the group's highest Composite Rating of 99. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.A close second among most-anticipated new games is "Battlefield 1" from Electronic Arts (EA). "Battlefield 1" is a first-person shooter game set during World War I. It is scheduled for release on Oct. 21 for PS4, Xbox One and Windows PCs."Battlefield 1" was the most-anticipated game for 26% of survey respondents, Olson said.Rounding out the top five most-desired new games were "Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands" from Ubisoft at 15%, and "Gears of War 4" from Microsoft and "The Last Guardian" from Sony, each with 10%."Ghost Recon Wildlands" is due for release on March 7. "Gears of Wars" is set to launch on Oct. 11 and "The Last Guardian" will hit shelves on Oct. 25.The survey showed lackluster demand for "Mafia 3" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO). Just 6% of respondents said it was the game they were most-excited about buying, Olson said.Olson has overweight ratings on Activision, EA and Take-Two with price targets of 46, 88 and 45, respectively.Activision stock rose 0.35% to 104.50 on the stock market today. EA fell 0.3% to 81.49. Take-Two climbed 0.8% to 41.29.RELATED:

Investors "rage quit" on GameStop (GME) on Friday after the video game retailer reported weaker-than-expected sales in its fiscal second quarter.GameStop stock fell 10.6% to 28.74 on the stock market today.Late Thursday, the Grapevine, Texas-based company said it earned 27 cents a share, down 13% year over year but in line with estimates, for its fiscal Q2 ended July 30. However, sales fell 7% to $1.63 billion during a weak quarter for the video game industry. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were modeling for sales of $1.72 billion, down 2%.Same-store sales dropped 10.6% in Q2, GameStop said.On the plus side, GameStop executives reiterated their earnings guidance for the full year and guided EPS higher for the current quarter.For fiscal Q3, GameStop expects earnings per share of 53 to 58 cents, when analysts were targeting 53 cents. For fiscal 2016, which ends on Jan. 28, GameStop is forecasting EPS of $3.90 to $4.05. At the midpoint of its guidance, EPS would be up 2% year over year.GameStop's results are in contrast to consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY), which earlier in the week reported a same-store sales increase and better-than-expected results for its July quarter.IBD'S TAKE: GameStop has an IBD Composite Rating of 34, meaning it has been outperformed by 66% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For a list of top stocks, check out the IBD 50.GameStop's new businesses and upcoming hardware and software launches make the stock more of a second-half 2016 and 2017 story, Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter said in a report Friday.Pachter reiterated his outperform rating on GameStop with a 12-month price target of 36.On the negative side, GameStop lowered its full-year sales guidance despite big product launches, such as new game consoles from Microsoft (MSFT) and Sony (SNE) and the Sony PlayStation VR virtual reality headset launch.GameStop sees sales in a range of down 2% to up 1.5%, vs. previous guidance for flat to up 3%, Pachter said.GameStop has been diversifying from video game shops to stores dedicated to selling Apple (AAPL) products, pop-culture collectibles, and devices and services for AT&T (T).Oppenheimer analyst Brian Nagel reiterated his perform rating on GameStop stock."Management continues to successfully  diversify  its  revenue  and  profit  streams  into  new  categories  and  away from the legacy physical gaming business," Nagel said in a report. "But, once again, physical gaming proved much weaker than guidance and the expectations of investors. We applaud GameStop for having the foresight to seek new directions for its model. That said, bears remain in control of the GME story."Baird analyst Colin Sebastian maintained his outperform rating on GameStop, but lowered his price target to 40 from 42.GameStop's video game sales have been pressured by the shift to digital downloads and difficult year-over-year comparisons for hardware and software sales.Bright spots in GameStop's Q2 report were mobile and consumer electronics sales up 43% to $203 million and collectibles sales up 120% to $90 million. Pokemon collectibles were a big seller last quarter thanks to the popularity of the "Pokemon Go" smartphone game, GameStop Chief Operating Officer Tony Bartel told IBD."Our transformation is in full swing," Bartel said. In Q2, GameStop had more than 50% of its profit coming from nonphysical video games. About 29% of the company's sales are now from nongames businesses, including its technology brands.Bartel sees improved game sales this fall and holiday season thanks to new consoles and VR game gear and highly anticipated game software titles like Activision's (ATVI) "Call of Duty: Infinite War," EA's (EA) "Battlefield 1" and Nintendo's (NTDOY) "Pokemon Sun and Moon."RELATED:GameStop Gobbles 507 AT&T Mobility Stores In Diversification Move'Pokemon Go' On $1 Billion-Plus Annual Revenue Run Rate

Celgene (CELG) was upgraded, Alibaba (BABA) got bullish marks ahead of its earnings, and price targets were raised on Square (SQ), Electronic Arts (EA) and Tableau Software (DATA).Celgene was upgraded to a buy at BTIG Research. Celgene last week narrowly beat analysts' Q2 estimates as the drug company raised its full-year guidance. Celgene raised sales guidance for its lead drug Revlimid, even though the blood-cancer treatment narrowly missed analysts' estimate for the quarter.Shares were up 0.1% at 116.27 at the close on the stock market today.MKM Partners set a price target on Alibaba at 95 with a buy rating. The China e-commerce giant reports quarterly results next Thursday.Alibaba stock rose 1.3% to 84.75.Square had its price target raised to 11 from 10 by Morgan Stanley, with an equal-weight rating. The provider of payment processing services reported Q2 results late Wednesday. Adjusted revenue topped views as Square raised full-year revenue guidance. Square said net revenue rose 41% to $439 million, beating the consensus of $406 million. It expects full-year net revenue of $1.65 billion at the midpoint of its guidance range.Shares jumped 8.4% to 11.32.Electronic Arts had its price target raised to 88 form 87 at MKM Partners, which maintained a buy rating. Electronic Arts late Tuesday posted better-than-expected revenue and earnings for the June quarter. The video game publisher earned 7 cents a share excluding items, beating the consensus by 2 cents, on sales of $682 million, for its fiscal first quarter.EA stock fell 0.5% at the close to 78.23.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts moved into buy range on Wednesday, clearing a 77.02 entry point after a breakout from a long consolidation. EA is ranked No. 3 in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming group. How does EA stack up vs. its top peers, and who is the Leaderboard stock that is No. 1 in its group? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupCitigroup raised its price target on Tableau Software to 64 from 54, with a neutral rating. The data analytics provider reported Q2 earnings late Tuesday that beat revenue expectations but fell short on earnings. Revenue rose 32% to $198.5 million, with a 1 cent per-share loss.Shares fell 0.9% to 52.73.

Video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) late Wednesday trounced Wall Street's sales and earnings targets for the September quarter thanks to hit games like "NBA 2K17" and "Grand Theft Auto Online."Take-Two stock jumped 7.8% to 48.29 on the stock market today, earlier hitting a record high of 49.96 and breaking out of a flat base at a 46.88 buy point.The New York-based company earned 44 cents a share excluding items, up 47% year over year, on sales of $479 million, up 31%, in its fiscal second quarter ended Sept. 30. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Take-Two to earn 29 cents a share on sales of $403 million.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Take-Two earned 39 cents a share, down 29% but besting the consensus estimate of 33 cents.IBD'S TAKE: Take-Two stock on Thursday broke out of a flat base with a buy point of 46.88. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 82 and is ranked No. 4 out of 15 stocks in IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Take-Two is the second of the three major publicly traded video game publishers to report quarterly results this earnings season. On Tuesday, Electronic Arts (EA) reported better-than-expected fiscal second quarter results and raised its full-year sales guidance.The third company, Activision Blizzard (ATVI), reports after the market close Thursday.Shares of both EA and Activision rose 1.8% Thursday, and both are in buy zones from recent breakouts, but Activision was down more than 1% after hours, after its earnings release.Take-Two said the biggest contributors to its Q2 revenue growth were "NBA 2K16," "Grand Theft Auto 5," "Grand Theft Auto Online," "BioShock: The Collection" and "Xcom 2.""Our outstanding results were highlighted by the series' record-breaking launch of 'NBA 2K17,' ongoing robust demand for 'Grand Theft Auto 5,' and increased recurrent consumer spending, including year-over-year bookings growth from 'Grand Theft Auto Online,'" Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said in a statement. "Our holiday season is off to a great start with a diverse array of successful new releases, including 'Mafia 3,' 'WWE 2K17' and 'Sid Meier's Civilization 6,' as well as our first virtual reality offering — 'Carnival Games VR.'"Take-Two stock received at least six price-target increases from Wall Street brokerages."We believe investors are already looking past fiscal 2017, with sights set on 'Red Dead Redemption 2,'" set for release next fall, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a research report.Olson raised his price target on Take-Two to 54 from 51 and maintained his overweight rating.Like other major video game publishers, Take-Two is benefiting from the sweet spot of the current console cycle as well as the shift to higher-margin digital game downloads and away from packaged media.The digital download trend has hurt retail sales of video game software. On Wednesday, retailer GameStop (GME) preannounced weaker-than-expected sales and earnings for the third quarter due to disappointing game software sales. GameStop stock caved to its lowest level in nearly four years.GameStop stock fell 0.48% Thursday, to 20.83.RELATED:Watching Activision Blizzard: To Buy Or Not To Buy? Or Sell?

Match Group (MTCH), which run dating sites Match.com and Tinder, turned in mixed results after the close Tuesday, Oclaro (OCLR) and Inphi (IPHI) gave strong results and guidance, while Electronic Arts (EA) and Paycom (PAYC) offered weak or in-line forecasts. Papa John's (PZZA) beat estimates and lifted its earnings guidance to above consensus views.Estimates: EPS of 19 cents on revenue of $318.07 million. No year-earlier comparisons are available for the November 2015 IPO.Results: EPS of 21 cents on revenue of $316.4 million. Average paid member count jumped 33% to 5.5 million, and Tinder's rose to 1.5 million. Average daily revenue per paying user slipped to 54 cents from 59 vents a year ago.Stock: Shares, which have a 98 Composite Rating, fell 3% late. It closed down 1.1% at 17.86 on the stock market today. Match broke out of a consolidation with a 17.10 buy point in late September. After becoming somewhat extended last month, shares have pulled back and are back within the chase zone, which runs up to 17.96.Estimates: The optical-network equipment maker is seen swinging to a profit of 10 cents a share from a year-ago loss of 2 cents a share, with revenue surging 52% to $131.7 million.Results: EPS of 23 cents on revenue of $135.5 million.Outlook: Q2 revenue of $146 million-$154 million, above Wall Street views for $137.86 million.Stock: Shares (98 CR) jumped 7.4% late. It finished up 0.4% at 7.34. The stock broke out in July, entered profit-taking territory in August and climbed even higher, but began to consolidate in late September and is now below its 50-day average.Oclaro's report follows mixed guidance from fellow fiber stock Lumentum (LITE), weak revenue from Infinera (INFN), and disappointing sales from China telecom gear giant ZTE, a major Acacia Communications (ACIA) customer.Estimates: EPS up 52% to 38 cents, as sales climb 9% to $67.89 million.Results: EPS of 46 cents on revenue of $70.7 million.Outlook: Q4 EPS of 44-46 cents, vs. views for 40 cents, on revenue of $74.7 million-$76.7 million, above views.Inphi agreed to buy ClariPhy for $275 million.Stock: Inphi shares (98 CR) rose 5.6% late. It rallied 2% to finish at 37.85 and last week undercut the flat base they had been forming.Inphi, while technically in IBD's fabless semiconductor group, is also part of the fiber-optic-components boom and has seen its stock suffer along with the fiber stocks.Estimates: EPS up 11% to 50 cents. Sales t0 rise 7% to $418.10 million, which would be the third straight quarter of improving year-over-year revenue change.Results: EPS of 57 cents on sales of $422.4 million, as same-store sales rose 5.5% in North America and 7.6% internationally.Outlook: Full-year EPS now seen at $2.46-$2.52, above consensus for $2.45 and up from a prior view of $2.35-$2.45.Stock: Shares (92 CR) rallied 4.5% in extended trade, after ending down 0.9% to 74.76. The stock fell 8.2% last week, tumbling through its 50-day line and the lows of its most recent consolidation.Pizza chains have outperformed amid overall restaurant weakness. But Domino's Pizza (DPZ), which reported last week, continues to see stock gains, while slower-growth Papa John's has faltered.Estimates: EPS should fall 34% to 43 cents, with revenue down 5% to $1.085 billion.Results: Loss of 13 cents as the company stopped reporting non-GAAP earnings that adjust for deferred revenue. Revenue of $898 million and adjusted revenue of $1.1 billion.Outlook: Q3 revenue of $1.125 billion and adjusted revenue of $2.04 billion, vs. consensus for $2.08 billion. Q3 loss of 17 cents.Stock: Shares (88 CR) reversed after-hours losses to jump 6%, after closing down 0.9% to 77.84. The stock dived below a buy point last week amid concerns that new game "Titanfall 2" won't sell as well as hoped.Electronic Arts' earnings and outlook will give investors a heads-up on video game demand for the key holiday season, ahead of quarterly reports this week from rivals Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Entertainment (TTWO).Estimates: EPS up 37.5% to 11 cents; revenue up 38% to $76.59 million.Results: EPS of 15 cents on revenue of $77.3 million.Outlook: Q4 revenue of $85 million-$87 million, vs. consensus for $85.8 million.Stock: Shares (99 CR) dropped 4.2% late. It closed up 0.5% at 52.00, nearing a buy point of 53.03.Paycom, a cloud-based payroll- and human-capital-software firm, is No. 2 on the IBD 50 list of elite stocks and reports ahead of another highly rated peer, Paylocity (PCTY), on Thursday.

Selling picked up in the stock market Wednesday after the Fed left rates unchanged as expected and left the door open for a possible rate hike in December.The Nasdaq slumped 0.9%, the S&P 500 shed nearly 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.4%. Volume was mixed vs. Tuesday, lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.Consumer lenders, hospitals and oil stocks led the decline in the stock market today, as West Texas intermediate crude futures fell nearly 3% to $45.48 a barrel. The Energy Information Administration reported a much higher than expected weekly rise in U.S. oil inventories. Medical stocks outperformed, as did gaming software.After the close, Facebook (FB) climbed slightly after reporting Q3 adjusted earnings of $1.09 a share (up 91%) and a 55% rise in revenue to $7.01 billion, both above views for 97 cents on $6.92 billion. The social network's shares fell nearly 2% in the regular session, closing below its 50-day moving average for the first time since early July. Paycom Software (PAYC) gapped down and plunged 16% in tremendous volume. Shares broke below the bottom of a flat base and breached the 200-day moving average, before paring losses to close above the support line. The software maker's Q3 results topped views late Tuesday, but the stock sold off amid concerns of slowing sales growth.On the upside, video game maker Electronic Arts (EA) jumped 3% at the open but pared gains to 1.7% by session's end. Shares have closed well below their 50-day line the past week. The "Battlefield 1" publisher late Tuesday reported better-than-expected fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue and raised its full-year sales guidance. Several analysts boosted their price targets following the results.Activision-Blizzard (ATVI) finished flat, stemming a six-session slide. The stock has slipped slightly below a 43.15 flat-base entry. The "Call of Duty" video game series maker reports Q3 results after the close Thursday.In economic news, the ADP National Employment Report showed 147,000 private-sector jobs added in October, well below forecasts for 170,000. Data due out Thursday include weekly jobless claims, September factory orders and the ISM non-manufacturing index for October.Activision, CBS (CBS), Monster Beverage (MNST) and Starbucks (SBUX) are among companies reporting earnings Thursday.RELATED:Paycom Software Plunges As ObamaCare Tailwind Dies Down Federal Reserve Leaves Rates Unchanged, Awaits 'Further Evidence'Electronic Arts Stock Gets Price-Target Hikes On Upbeat Q2 Report

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is forming a base with a 43.15 buy point. The stock has declined only 9% as it shapes the pattern. The company is part of the strong gaming-software industry group, ranked No. 33 out of 197 groups, and up from No. 100 six weeks ago. It's the No. 2 company by Composite Rating out of 16 in…

Electronic Arts (EA) late Tuesday posted better-than-expected sales and earnings for the June quarter, a period when it had no major new video game releases.The Redwood City, Calif.-based video game publisher earned 7 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $682 million, in its fiscal first quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EA to lose 2 cents a share on sales of $651 million. On a year-over-year basis, earnings per share fell 53%, and sales slipped 2%.EA raised its full-year EPS guidance to $3.55 from $3.50, and maintained revenue guidance of $4.9 billion.But its Q2 guidance was below consensus views. EA expects to earn 40 cents a share on sales of $1.075 billion, vs. consensus estimates of 59 cents EPS and $1.111 billion in sales. The lighter-than-expected guidance is primarily related to the timing of key game releases during the quarter.EA stock ended trading Wednesday up 2.4% to 78.63 on the stock market today. EA hit an all-time high of 79.99 on July 12. At least three Wall Street analysts raised their price targets on EA stock after the earnings release.IBD'S TAKE: Electronic Arts stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 96, meaning it has outperformed 96% of other stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on EA stock, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter reiterated his outperform rating on EA stock with a 12-month price target of 86."We expect significant growth for the foreseeable future, driven by impressive franchises, digital momentum and cost discipline," he said in a research report Wednesday.However, he expects EA stock to see increased volatility ahead of the launches of this year's three highest-profile first-person shooter games: EA's "Battlefield 1" (Oct. 21) and "Titanfall 2" (Oct. 28) and Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" (Nov. 4).Cowen analyst Doug Creutz raised his price target on EA stock to 83 from 80 and maintained his outperform rating.Baird analyst Colin Sebastian also raised his EA price target to 83 from 80 and kept his outperform rating.EA's fiscal Q1 beat was driven by digital sales of "FIFA Ultimate Team" on consoles and "Star Wars: Galaxy of Heroes" on mobile devices, Sebastian said in a report.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson stuck with his overweight rating on EA stock and upped his price target to 88 from 87.

Electronic Arts (EA), Sturm Ruger (RGR), Fitbit (FIT), Qorvo (QRVO), Cerner (CERN) and Paycom Software (PAYC) all beat quarterly earnings forecasts after the market close Tuesday, with  still on topAll but one of them -- Fitbit -- boast an IBD Composite Rating better than 90, meaning they've outperformed 90% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.The maker of classic video games like "Madden NFL 17" -- and newer ones such as "Star Wars Battlefront: Death Star" -- faces difficult comps because it didn't roll out any major new titles in the spring, while last year it debuted "Battlefield Hardline" and others.Estimates: Consensus is for EA to report a 2-cent per-share loss, reversing from a 15-cent per-share profit a year earlier. Revenue is expected to fall 6.1% to $650.66 million. Electronic Arts has topped earnings estimates for the last eight quarters in a row.Results: EPS of 7 cents on non-GAAP revenue of $682 million.EA shares fell 1.5% after hours on the stock market today.No. 2 U.S. firearms maker by revenue Sturm Ruger will report Q2 earnings amid heightened fears for personal safety after a series of situations in which police were ambushed and shot dead, and a number of shootings of unarmed suspects by police. Rising terror attacks in Europe and the U.S. also stoked fears.Estimates: Wall Street expects $1.15 EPS, up 26% from 91 cents a share a year ago. No consensus revenue estimate was available, but the gunmaker reported $140.9 million revenue in Q2 2015, and its revenue has been growing in the mid-20% range. A 24% increase would imply revenue of about $174.7 million. Results: EPS of $1.22 on revenue of $167.9 million.Dividend: 49 cents, up from 48 cents in Q1.Sturm Ruger shares were up 0.2% late Tuesday as it worked on a handle in a base going back to mid-March. Ruger has a potential buy point at 70.40.The FBI reported that firearm background checks, seen as an indicator of gun demand, rose 3% in July from June and was up 37% from a year ago. But the tally was still down about a third from a high reached in December.Wearable fitness tracking device maker Fitbit has been impacted by intense and rising competition from Apple (AAPL), Garmin (GRMN), Samsung and others. Fitbit has a weak 24 IBD Composite Rating, as its sales growth rate has declined over the last three quarters from a respective 253% to 168%, 92% and 50% last quarter.Estimates: Analysts project a 52% decline in Q2 EPS to 11 cents a share on a 44.5% increase in revenue to $578.48 million.Results: EPS of 12 cents on revenue of $587 million.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 17-19 cents, vs. consensus for 17 cents, on revenue of $490 million-$510 million.Fitbit jumped 5.2% late.The maker of chips used in smartphones, wireless network gear and other devices has hitched its wagon to Apple (AAPL), which early this year tanked amid worries that iPhone sales growth was decelerating. But Apple a week ago reported earnings that beat estimates, driving its shares up 6.5% last Wednesday, a good omen for Qorvo.Estimates: Wall Street estimates Qorvo's earnings will drop 3.7% to $1.05 per share and sales will dip 3.4% to $650.62. Qorvo has topped earnings estimates for six straight quarters.Results: EPS of $1.08 on revenue of $698.5 million.Outlook: Q2 revenue of $820 million-$850 million.For a full IBD story on Qorvo's results, click here.Qorvo stock tumbled 4.4%.The maker of software for the health care industry in early April persuaded Universal Health Services (UHS), the second-largest publicly traded hospital chain in the U.S., to upgrade from its Siemens (SIEGY) revenue-tracking software to Cerner's new Millennium Revenue Cycle suite, which could boost Q2 results.Estimates: Cerner's Q2 EPS is projected to rise about 10% to 57 cents on a 7.5% increase in revenue to $1.21 billion.Results: EPS of 58 cents on revenue of $1.22 billion.Cerner shares dropped 0.5%.Paycom, a cloud-based records management software provider continues to grow. The IBD 50 stock has posted double- or triple-digit profit and sales growth virtually every quarter since going public in April 2014.IBD'S TAKE: Paycom Software is the top-rated stock in a group reporting earnings Tuesday, with a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. It's also one of a trio of recent IPOs that continue to outperform. To learn more check out this IBD IPO Analysis.Estimates: Analysts are looking for a 30% jump in EPS to 13 cents for the young company, and a 44% pop in revenue to $70.60 million.Results: Adjusted EPS of 21 cents on revenue of $73.9 million.Outlook: Q3 revenue of $75 million-$77 million and full-year revenue of $325 million-$327 million.Paycom climbed 3.5%% late Tuesday.

The major market indexes remained in the red heading into the last half hour of Thursday's regular trading session, as earnings continued to dominate stock-price action.The Nasdaq tumbled 0.8% and the S&P 500 fell 0.4%, on track for their eighth straight losses. That's the S&P 500's longest losing streak since October 2008. Blue chips fared better, as the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. the same time Wednesday.In economic news, Challenger, Gray & Christmas announced layoffs of 30,740, a five-month low. But first-time jobless claims came in at 265,000, above forecasts for 255,000 and up from 258,000 in the prior week.Solar, casino and medical stocks led the downside in today's stock market action, while gaming software, gold miners and telecom infrastructure stocks were among the biggest gainers.First Solar (FSLR) plunged 17%, diving below its 50-day moving average in hefty trade. Several analysts downgraded the stock after the solar installer reported weak Q3 results late Wednesday. Shares are 54% off their 52-week high.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) sank nearly 10% in busy turnover, breaching its 200-day line for the first time since February. After the close Wednesday, the casino operator announced weaker-than-expected Q3 results. Facebook (FB) gapped down and sank 6% in heavy trade as shares neared a test of their 200-day moving average line. The stock triggered the 8% sell rule from a 132.08 flat-base entry. After the close Wednesday, the social network delivered solid quarterly results that topped views. But shares sold off amid concerns over slowing ad revenue growth.On the upside, Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) gapped up and soared  9% to a new high in triple its usual trade.Shares are near the top of a buy range from a 46.88 flat-base entry. But all purchases are risky with the market uptrend under pressure. The publisher of popular video games such as "NBA 2K17" and "Grand Theft Auto Online" reported fiscal Q2 results that beat views. A flurry of analysts boosted their price targets after the report.Electronic Arts (EA) jumped 2% in fast turnover, extending Wednesday's nearly 2% gain. The stock regained an 80.09 buy point and is trying to retake its 50-day moving average. On Tuesday, the "Battlefield" and "Madden NFL 17" publisher announced better-than-expected quarterly results and lifted its full-year sales outlook.Activision Blizzard (ATVI) added more than 2% in above-average volume ahead of its earnings, which are due after the close. Shares climbed back above a 43.15 buy point of a flat base. Analysts expect the "Call of Duty" maker to double its Q3 per-share profit to 42 cents on a 51% jump in sales to $1.57 billion.RELATED:Generic Drugmakers Crash On Report DOJ Plans Collusion ChargesTake-Two Jumps To New High On Slam-Dunk Q2 EarningsElectronic Arts Stock Gets Price-Target Hikes On Upbeat Q2 Report

Major stock indexes were in the red again near midday Wednesday, but losses were tame, as investors awaited the conclusion of the Fed meeting and policy statement at 2 p.m. ET.The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite gave up 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.2%. Small caps underperformed again, with the Russell 2000 down around 0.7%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels — more so on the Nasdaq.Health care and mining stocks outperformed. Oil and gas names lagged again amid another sharp drop in oil prices.December West Texas intermediate crude oil futures were down around 3% to 45.12 a barrel after an industry group reported a huge stockpile build ahead of official data. The 10-year Treasury yield slipped 2 basis points to 1.80%.In the stock market today, investors liked the look of Alibaba's (BABA) earnings report early in the session, but shares reversed sharply, falling 2%.Meanwhile, shares of Broadcom (AVGO) rallied 1% on news it's acquiring Brocade Communications (BRCD) for $5.9 billion, including debt. Shares of Brocade jumped 10% to 12.36.The Stocks On The Move screen on the home page of Investors.com highlighted several earnings winners rising in heavy volume, including Wingstop (WING), Papa John's (PZZA), Electronic Arts (EA) and Inphi (IPHI). Activision (ATVI), a group peer of Electronic Arts, reports Thursday after the close.On the downside, Paycom Software (PAYC) crashed 16%. An earnings and sales beat late Tuesday wasn't good enough as Wall Street focused on quarterly sales guidance of $85 to $87 million, pretty much at the midpoint of the consensus estimate of $85.94 million.In economic news, the private sector added 147,000 jobs in October, according to the latest data from ADP. Economists expected growth of 170,000. The data come ahead of Friday's nonfarm payroll report for October, which is expected to show job growth of 178,000.The two-day Fed meeting concludes today, with the policy statement due at 2 p.m. ET. Wall Street isn't expecting much from the meeting so close to the election, but Chairwoman Janet Yellen could take the opportunity to prepare the market for a rate hike before the end of the year. The market is already expecting one. According to the CME Group FedWatch took, the chances of a rate hike are near 70%.RELATED:Alibaba Earnings, Revenue Growth Beat On E-Commerce, Cloud BusinessBroadcom To Buy Brocade For $5.9 Billion, Reaffirms Q4 GuidanceOil Extends Slide As Industry Group Sees Massive Stockpile Gain

The country's best-performing funds for the past three months have been building their portfolios with market-leading stocks in a variety of sectors, including building, metals, medical and retail.Building stocks include A.O. Smith  (AOS), Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS), Lennox International (LII), Drew Industries (DW), Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) and Masco (MAS) in their latest reporting periods.Other industrial stocks performing well include metal fabricators Insteel Industries (IIIN) and Gibraltar Industries (ROCK).A handful of medical issues also saw heavy buying by the best-performing funds, including Vascular Solutions (VASC), Edward Lifesciences (EW), Align Technology (ALGN) and Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND).The market outlook has been in a confirmed uptrend since June 30.Click Here To See A List Of New Buys Of Top Mutual FundsRetailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) contoured its way into top funds' portfolios. Fifty-five top funds have added the cosmetic and fragrances store, investing an estimated $1.38 billion. The $114.7 billion American Funds Growth Fund of America recently added shares in its latest reporting period. Managers of leading funds also shopped for shares at discount retailers Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) and Five Below (FIVE). Other retailers worth shopping for include Burlington Stores (BURL) and Pool (POOL).IBD found 17 top-performing funds adding Ollie's Bargain Outlet, investing an estimated $77.7 million. The $1.3 billion Pioneer Select Midcap Growth added shares.The newly issued company runs a chain of bargain warehouse-style stores, where you buy "good stuff cheap." The Harrisburg, P.A.-based firm has 216 stores selling closeouts, excess inventory and salvage merchandise. Everything you buy at Ollie's has a 30-day "No Hard Time" guarantee. If customers aren't happy with their purchase, they can return it within 30-days of purchase for a full refund with sales receipt.Ollie's stock cleared the 26.65 buy point of a double-bottom base on Aug. 1, but has straddled that level since then. The bargain store has been growing steadily, racking up solid double-digit earnings growth over the past five quarters. For the same period, revenue growth was more subdued, slightly under the 20% range.Other notable stocks on the new buys list acting well include gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC), Hawaiian Holdings (HA) and Edward Lifesciences (EW). Each of these stock are currently etching the handle part of the cup-with-handle base pattern. Make sure to put these stocks on your watch list.The nation's leading funds have been taking profit from online retailer giant Amazon.com (AMZN). Computer software firms Symantec (SYMC), Electronic Arts (EA) and Aspen Technology (AZPN) were also sold by top-performing funds in their latest reporting periods.Top funds also unloading beverage companies, Monster (MNST) and Constellations Brands (STZ). Monster reported second-quarter earnings results of 0.99 cents, missing views by 4 cents, but revenue of $827.5 million beats expectations.Click Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual Funds

Consumer-related stocks helped the major indexes sprint ahead Friday, following a much better-than-expected July payrolls report. Plus, earnings results continued to beat Wall Street views overall.Burger King chain owner Restaurant Brands International (QSR), Wingstop (WING), Leaderboard member Monster Beverage (MNST) and Electronic Arts (EA) were just some of the companies padding strong weekly gains following robust profits in their latest quarter.The Nasdaq composite led, up 1.1%, as big-cap techs continued to flourish. Apple (AAPL) jumped 1.5% to 107.46 in brisk trade, getting closer to a potential double-bottom buy point at 112.49. Keep in mind that the stock has been stuck in an even longer consolidation since topping at 134.54 in the spring of 2015.IBD'S TAKE: It's critical to view both a daily and weekly chart for a stock to understand its true price strength and potential. Go to the Research section at Investors.com to view charts; up days or up weeks are highlighted in blue, down days and down weeks in red. The Relative Strength line, drawn in blue, helps you compare a stock's action vs. the S&P 500. Prefer those stocks with a rising RS line.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rallied 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively. Volume was running sharply higher on the Nasdaq just after 12 noon ET vs. the same time on Thursday; on the NYSE, turnover was edging slightly faster.Restaurant stocks got a badly needed shot in the arm with big gains by both Restaurant Brands and Wingstop. The former, which also operates the Tim Hortons coffee and doughnuts chain, added nearly 0.6% to 46.59, following Thursday's 3.3% jump on the back of a 37% surge in second-quarter earnings per share despite flat revenue growth.  In constant-currency terms, the company's Burger King franchise saw 5.9% growth in the top line, and revenue for the Tim Hortons unit increased 4.8%. Same-store sales also edged higher for both chains. Total Q3 profit is seen growing 105% to 39 cents a share.Restaurant Brands is nearly 6% past a 44.06 flat-base buy point, so it's narrowly extended from proper buy range.Dallas-based Wingstop blasted more than 14% higher to 30.63 in volume that jumped more than six times its usual level. The chicken wing chain reported a 36% rise in Q2 profit, beating views by 7%, as sales rose 18%. Sales have now increased 14% to 22% vs. year-ago levels for the seventh quarter in a row. The small-cap stock cleared a 27.96 handle entry on a yearlong cup.Wingstop went public on June 12, 2015, at 19 a share. The stock's float of 15 million shares is very small, meeting the S factor (or supply) in IBD's CAN SLIM investment criteria for finding outstanding growth stocks. Wingstop also has 29 million shares outstanding, meaning that as much as 14 million are held by management or insiders. It is rather thinly traded, with an average daily volume of 353,000 shares, but that has been rising rapidly.Travel booking and airline stocks also paced the market's upside following better-than-expected Q2 results from the industry's online giant Priceline (PCLN).On the downside, Installed Building Products (IBP) sank further, falling more than 7% to 31.75 in quadruple normal volume. On Thursday, the insulation supplier triggered a key signal by posting its biggest single-session point drop since its May 5 breakout past a 28.28 handle pivot point.Installed Building also broke sharply below the 50-day moving average for the second time in four sessions, another important sell signal that has been discussed in past Investor's Corner columns. You can also read more about important sell signals by clicking here.
