Three top video game publishers with stocks that recently hit record highs are set to report quarterly earnings this week. Investors want to see whether the shares will advance to the next level, or if it's game over.Electronic Arts (EA) is up first, reporting fiscal-first-quarter results after the market close Tuesday. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) follow on Thursday with their own June-quarter results.Electronic Arts notched an all-time high of 79.99 on July 12. EA stock rose 0.4% to 76.63 on the stock market today.Activision Blizzard scored its record high of 43.05 on July 13. Activision fell 0.2% to 40.07 Monday.Take-Two Interactive hit its all-time high of 41.71 on July 12. The stock rose 0.3% to 40.29 on Monday.IBD'S TAKE: Of the three big video game publishers, Electronic Arts has the best IBD Composite Rating. Its 92 rating means it has outperformed 92% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more details, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Electronic Artsto lose 2 cents a share excluding items on sales of $651 million, down 6% year over year, in fiscal Q1. On a fully reported basis, EA expects to earn $1.32 a share.Complicating the earnings reports this quarter is that EA, Activision and some other companies have switched to GAAP financial reporting to comply with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission rules.Last month, Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said the changes could cause some "headline confusion" for video game stocks.For Q2, Activision is expected to earn 42 cents a share excluding items on sales of $1.46 billion. Earnings per share are seen jumping 223% year over year with sales up 92%, thanks to its hit video game "Overwatch." On a fully reported basis, Activision's EPS is seen dipping 17% to 24 cents.For its fiscal Q1, Take-Two is seen posting revenue of $259 million, down 29%, during a quiet game release period. It is expected to post earnings per share of 16 cents on a fully reported basis, but a loss of 30 cents a share on a non-GAAP basis.RELATED:Activision's 'Overwatch' Leads Soft Month For Video Game Sales

Major equity averages edged higher early Wednesday amid another busy day of headline flow. Goldman Sachs (GS), Walt Disney (DIS) and Apple (AAPL) outperformed in the Dow with gains of 1% or more.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 barely rose while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1%.The S&P 500 suffered its third distribution day in seven trading sessions Tuesday, raising its count to four. The Nasdaq composite currently shows three.IBD'S TAKE: Increasing signs of distribution, or higher-volume declines in the indexes, can cause cause problems for a market uptrend. To learn more about institutional selling and its impact on the market, check out this lesson in IBD University.In economic news, 178,600 private-sector jobs were added in July, according to the ADP National Employment Report. The data come ahead of Friday's official jobs report, for which economists expect July nonfarm payrolls to rise 185,000, with the unemployment ticking lower to 4.8%.In the stock market today, Time Warner (TWX) bucked the trend, rising nearly 4%, after the company reported earnings and announced it was taking a 10% stake in streaming service Hulu.Electronic Arts (EA), which had been showing supporting action at its 10-week moving average ahead of earnings, rose 0.1%. Investors have gotten carried away with the "Pokemon Go" phenomenon and driven Nintendo (NTDOY) stock to dizzying heights, Deutsche Bank Securities said Monday.Deutsche Bank analyst Han Joon Kim downgraded Nintendo stock to hold from buy. Nintendo's American depositary receipts ended the U.S. trading day up 12% to 37.37 on the stock market today. Shares earlier reached a five-year high of 38.25."'Pokemon Go' is a genuine phenomenon -- just after a little over a week, it has added $19 billion to the value of Nintendo," Kim said. "The market is now valuing Nintendo … on a par with global leaders such as Electronic Arts (EA) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI) that respectively have 5% global video game market share vs. Nintendo's current 2%."The market has priced-in a recovery for Nintendo in the console game market with its upcoming Nintendo NX and an expanded presence in mobile gaming, he said.IBD's TAKE: While Nintendo's stock ranks highly for technical performance, its underlying fundamentals don't support it. Nintendo has an EPS rating of 7, meaning it's near the bottom of publicly traded companies based on earnings per share. The top-rated company in the Computer Software-Gaming sector is NetEase (NTES), with an EPS rating of 99. Learn more about NetEase in the Investors.com Research section."Pokemon Go" is a joint venture of the Pokemon Company, which is 40%-owned by Nintendo, and Niantic, a spinout from Alphabet (GOOGL). Nintendo also is an investor in Niantic."Pokemon Go" is still awaiting rollout in many markets, including its home market of Japan.Up next, Nintendo is preparing smartphone versions of its games "Animal Crossing" and "Fire Emblem."Meanwhile, companies big and small are trying to capitalize on the "Pokemon Go" hype.Retailers are promoting their businesses as "Poke Stops," where players of the augmented-reality game can collect virtual items. Companies that make smartphone battery cases like Otter Box are touting their products as a solution for the battery-draining game.Makers of augmented-reality headsets, such as Microsoft's (MSFT) HoloLens and Vuzix (VUZI), are demonstrating "Pokemon Go" on their smart glasses. And other video game and entertainment companies are working on copycat augmented-reality games.Related:Late-Night Comedians Capture 'Pokemon Go' For Laughs'Pokemon Go' Craze Has Retailers Hunting For Revenue

It's more than 25% past a 22.29 buy point of an ascending base, a level at which investors should consider taking profits.Pan American Silver (PAAS) also rose more than 2% to a new high, hitting the 20%-25% profit-taking zone.In the IBD 50, Chinese consumer loan stock Yirendai (YRD) bolted 10% to a fresh record high. Selling is an emotionally charged decision, even when you have profits. It's natural to think of selling when a stock shows weakness, but there are many "what ifs" that can taunt you.If you sell, you fear the stock may turn right around to make gains without you. If you don't sell, you risk the possibility of losing even more profits or having the trade go negative. Using a short-term moving average line as a sell rule allows for an objective and consistent strategy to handle the decision unemotionally.Since the 5-day average hugs the price tightly, it is usually in your best interest to wait for a decisive close below the line before taking action. If the stock punctures the line intraday but shows signs of support by the end of the day, the stock can be kept. That show of support suggests the stock was able to overcome selling pressure. Even if the close is just slightly below it, the stock may still be kept, especially if it made progress from its lows.Electronic Arts (EA) was a winning trade from IBD's SwingTrader product. The stock reversed on May 23 and closed in the middle of its range for the day (1). The following day Electronic Arts surpassed the high of the reversal, and it was put on as a current trade at 74.20. Shares finished strongly and closed above the 5-day moving average line, allowing it to be used as a future sell signal.On May 26, EA fell below the 5-day line intraday but rallied back above it by the close, avoiding the sell signal (2). The stock actually closed below the line (3) on June 3 and June 6. In both cases, shares rallied from their lows, closed near the upper quartile of the day's trading range, within 0.1% of the 5-day line. Lacking the decisive close below the line justified giving the stock a little more room.That decision was rewarded with a 2% jump the following day, and half profits were taken at 77.63 (4). That sell ended up being within 1% of a near-term top, and Electronic Arts traded lower for most of the day after that.The following day, the weakness continued to worsen throughout the session. The stock did close below the 5-day line by almost half a percent (5). The remaining shares were sold at 76.10 a couple of hours before the market close. That put the average price of the sells at 76.87 for a 3.6% profit.Subscribers and trialists to SwingTrader can view the full details of this real-time trade, as well as the complete history of all trades, in the Past Trades section of SwingTrader. Free trials are available.

The insane viral success of "Pokemon Go" has more than doubled Nintendo's (NTDOY) shares since the game's July 6 debut.How much bigger is Nintendo now?With a market cap of $40.6 billion at Tuesday's close, it's now bigger than gaming peers Activision (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and Sony (SNE). Perhaps more surprisingly, the "Legend of Zelda" and "Super Mario" maker is now bigger than Tesla (TSLA), Netflix (NFLX) and Yahoo (YHOO).For a breakdown of just how much bigger, take a look at the video.RELATED:Nevermind 'Pokemon Go'; Apple, Nike File Augmented Reality Patents.

The smash hit smartphone video game "Pokemon Go" is on an annual revenue run rate of more than $1 billion, Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said Wednesday."We think the game is currently operating at meaningfully north of a $1 billion annual revenue run rate," Creutz said in a research report."Pokemon Go" is a joint venture of the Pokemon Company and video game publisher Niantic. Nintendo (NTDOY) is a shareholder in both of the two companies and also owns the trademarks to Pokemon and the Pokemon character names."Pokemon Go," a free-to-play, location-based augmented reality game, has been the No. 1 most-downloaded game on the Apple (AAPL) App Store and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Play store since its July 6 launch.While the game is free to play, it sells in-game items that enhance the experience and help players advance. Apple and Google get a 30% share of in-game sales sold through their respective app stores.Nintendo stock rose 1.25% to 28.27 in the stock market today, though well off its five-year high above 38, touched July 18. Alphabet stock climbed 0.1%, while Apple stock was down 0.7%.IBD'S TAKE: Two video game companies are among the top-performing companies on the IBD 50: NetEase and Activision Blizzard. IBD's Computer Software-Gaming industry group currently ranks No. 56 out of 197 groups.The popularity of "Pokemon Go" has benefited a host of other companies. Some retailers like GameStop (GME) and McDonald's (MCD) have become stops for "Pokemon Go" players looking for digital creatures and in-game items and have seen a corresponding sales boost."Pokemon Go" has also spurred sales of smartphone battery packs because the game is a notorious power hog. The NPD Group reported that portable power pack sales were up 101% year over year in the two-week period in July following the introduction of "Pokemon Go." Makers of mobile power packs include Best Buy (BBY), Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB)-owned Duracell, Energizer (ENR) and Zagg (ZAGG)."Pokemon Go" does not appear to be affecting sales for other top mobile game companies, Creutz said."Multiple gaming companies that we cover have … said that they haven't seen much impact on their revenue from the launch of the game, suggesting that 'Pokemon Go' has largely been additive to the market," he said.The success of "Pokemon Go" demonstrates the importance of major franchises to game publishers, he said."Companies with significant franchises and quality (intellectual property) are likely to increasingly dominate the space," he said. Another prime example is King Digital Entertainment, now owned by Activision Blizzard (ATVI), which has the "Candy Crush" game series.Electronic Arts (EA) has been successful in the mobile games space with versions of its popular consoles sports franchises. They include "Madden NFL Mobile," "NBA Live Mobile" and "FIFA Mobile."RELATED:Nintendo Tanks On News It Won't Benefit Much From 'Pokemon Go''Pokemon Go' Fires Starting Gun For Augmented RealityApple Could Reap Billions From 'Pokemon Go'

Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) hit video game "Overwatch" topped the sales charts in June, but overall game software sales dropped 20% year over year, the NPD Group reported late Thursday."Overwatch," a sci-fi shooter game, was the top-selling title in combined U.S. retail and digital download sales last month. It was released worldwide on May 24.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer Software-Gaming sector ranks No. 95 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. The top-ranked stocks within the group are NetEase, Electronic Arts and Activision. For more information on these companies, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Take-Two Interactive Software's (TTWO) "Grand Theft Auto 5," first released in September 2013, came in second place in June, NPD reported.Rounding out the top five, in order, were "Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens" from Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, "Doom 2016" from Bethesda Softworks, and "Mirror's Edge: Catalyst" from Electronic Arts (EA).Total video game software sales declined to $349.8 million in June from $437.5 million in June 2015, NPD said. Video game hardware sales sank 42% to $181.5 million. Game accessories sales dipped 6% to $120.9 million.Total domestic sales of video game hardware, software and accessories fell 26% to $652.2 million in June, NPD said."Poor comparisons to last June, where software and hardware sales were bolstered by strong launches like 'Batman: Arkham Knight,' led to a sharp 26% year-over-year decline in overall spending across software, hardware and accessories," NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.Activision stock closed up 0.4% at 41.44 in the stock market today, while Take-Two stock rose 1.2% t0 40.56.RELATED:NetEase Hits High Score On 'Overwatch' Game SuccessActivision Game 'Overwatch' Profitability May Be Underappreciated.

Stocks showed mild action Friday, but the Dow snapped a four-week winning run. In general, the market maintained a positive bent amid a week jam-packed with earnings reports and a data showing weaker-than-expected growth in the U.S. economy.But the Q2 advance GDP report didn't seem that horrible beyond the headline number. While the overall 1.2% gain far missed the Econoday consensus forecast for an increase of 2.6%, the government also revised the figure for Q1 of 2015 sharply higher from 0.6% growth to 2.0%.Plus, in the latest reading, consumer spending jumped 4.2%, strongly reflecting the positive impact of relatively high employment and lower gas prices in the world No. 1 economy.The Dow Jones industrial average slipped less than 0.1%, lagging gains of nearly 0.3% for both the Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500. The latter hit a new all-time high, rising as high as 2,177.09 during the stock market today.The Dow's 0.1% loss for the week pales in comparison with gains of 3.2%, 1.1%, 2% and 0.3% in the prior four weeks, respectively. The Nasdaq rallied 1.2% for the week -- a fifth straight weekly advance. The S&P 500 edged lower by fewer than 2 points, or less than 0.1%.Which stocks are performing best in the Dow?One way to view this is by comparing the Relative Strength Rating, which measures a stock's performance over the past 12 months vs. the rest of the stock market. Action over the past three months carries a higher weighting. On that score, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) lead the Dow's 30 components with RS ratings of 83 and 81, respectively.J&J rose 0.6% to 125.23, padding its impressive gains since clearing a long saucer with handle near 105. Even with that large advance, J&J's annualized dividend yield of 2.6% still exceeds the S&P 500's 2% payout.J&J continues to rise after recently posting a third quarter in a row of modest earnings growth. Q3 earnings are seen rising 11% to $1.66 a share, which would be an acceleration from the 2% increase which the medical and personal care products titan saw in the second quarter.For the year, J&J's earnings per share are seen rising 8% on a 3% pick-up in revenue to $72.07 billion.UnitedHealth has had a masterful performance since it broke out of a shallow double-bottom base at 121.19 in late February. The managed care behemoth rose 0.3% to 143.20, up 18% from that proper pivot point.Ranking third in RS Rating among the Dow components is DuPont (DD). The chemicals giant is cozying up to the 70 price level, where it's had trouble piercing higher. Earlier this week, DuPont marked a 14% jump in Q2 earnings, the best result in 10 quarters. Sales slid 8%, however.Investors who seek companies with faster growth need to look at IBD's various high-growth screens, including today's IPO Leaders column. This screen looks for outstanding performers in each aspect of IBD's CAN SLIM investment paradigm. The latest story highlights China's Yirendai (YRD) (EPS seen rising 65% in 2016), Veeva Systems (VEEV) (EPS seen up 12% in 2016 after a 38% gain in 2015) and IBD 50 stock LGI Homes (LGIH) (EPS seen rising 36% in 2016).IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50, Big Cap 20, Stock Spotlight and Sector Leaders columns, located inside IBD Stock Lists at Investors.com, all hunt for companies with above-average fundamentals. Keep an eye out for those companies that offer something new in the form of fantastic new products, a new industry, new market conditions, new management and a stock hitting new highs in price. This is the N in CAN SLIM.Next week, keep an eye out for quarterly results from Big Data software expert Tableau (DATA), CVS Health (CVS) and Procter & Gamble (PG) on Tuesday; Tesla Motors (TSLA), Electronic Arts (EA) and First Solar (FSLR) on Wednesday; and IBD Leaderboard member Monster Beverage (MNST) and Priceline Group (PCLN) on Thursday.

A possible crackdown by the Securities and Exchange Commission on companies reporting adjusted revenue and earnings could have a big impact on video game companies, Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said in a research report Thursday.The SEC says it may place restrictions in the near term on the use and reporting of non-GAAP revenue and eventually non-GAAP earnings. Unlike Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, non-GAAP reporting lets companies factor out items, such as stock-based compensation, from earnings. The great majority of tech companies report non-GAAP earnings and some report non-GAAP revenue, though as required they also report GAAP earnings and provide a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP numbers."While these changes should not impact company operations, cash flow, or intrinsic values, investors should be aware of the potential for headline confusion and/or some additional modeling complexity," Sebastian said, in one of the first analyst reports to deal with this issue. At an address at a conference this month, Mary Jo White, chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, criticized the prevalent use of non-GAAP financial reporting.SEC changes that could restrict non-GAAP accounting would impact video game publishers, including Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA), Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and Zynga (ZNGA), Sebastian said.IBD Take: Activision ranks third in its group, find out why at IBD Stock Checkup.Today, video game publishers defer a portion of revenue for online-enabled games over a period of time when users are likely to access online content and services, he said."As such, non-GAAP revenues excluding the impact of deferrals would be higher than GAAP revenues in video game launch quarters, but lower than GAAP in subsequent quarters," Sebastian said. "On an annualized basis, the difference between GAAP and non-GAAP revenues is limited; however, on a quarterly basis, there can be significant differences that we believe could cause some headline confusion."For instance, for the June quarter, EA guided to GAAP revenue of $1.25 billion and non-GAAP revenue of $640 million.Video game publishers use non-GAAP revenue because it is arguably more representative of quarterly operating performance and business trends, Sebastian said.Among the top publicly traded video game publishers, it appears that Take-Two would face the largest impact an SEC restriction on non-GAAP revenue reporting, according to the analyst.He said such changes, though, would allow better apples-to-apples comparisons of video game publishers.Sebastian rates Activision and EA stocks as outperform and Take-Two and Zynga stocks as neutral.As stocks continued to rebound from their post-Brexit fall, shares of Activision closed up 4.2% in the stock market today, and and Zynga rose 2.9%, while shares of EA added 2.7% and Take-Two rose 3.55%.

Stocks climbed at the open Thursday, as currency moves, M&A action and quarterly reports factored into early trade.The Dow industrials and Nasdaq jumped 0.7% and the S&P 500 rose 0.6%.Chipmakers were in early motion on the stock market today, following a positive Q2 report from Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) and after Cree (CREE) announced it would sell its Wolfspeed Power & RF (radio frequency) division to Germany's Infineon Technologies for $850 million. Cree shot up 9% at the open, but Taiwan Semiconductor opened with a loss of 0.5%.Cypress Semiconductor (CY) surged 6% at the open. U.K.-based deal blog Betaville reported unconfirmed news that Cypress was working with Goldman Sachs on strategic options, and that several parties were interested.Other major movers were:JPMorgan (JPM) rose 2%. The bank reported above-consensus second-quarter earnings and revenue, with consumer deposits, merchant processing volume and core loan growth up in double digits, and continued strength in both wholesale (outside energy) and consumer credit.Yum Brands (YUM) climbed 4.5. The Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC owner delivered mixed second-quarter results, but management said it now expects full-year operating profit to rise 14%, up from previous projections of a 12% increase, helped by a strong performance by KFC China.Delta Air Lines (DAL) rose 3%. Second-quarter earnings topped analyst expectations, but revenue growth missed; management announced plans to cut capacity.Paycom Software (PAYC) added 1. The provider of human resources software ended Wednesay's session extended above a 42.70 buy point, and just breaking into new highs above its prior, November peak.Electronic Arts (EA) edged up 0.3%. The video game maker has been fighting to gain lift above a 77.25 handle buy point in an eight-month cup-with-handle base.Oil futures were rebounding from Wednesday's sharp losses. Gold, bonds and currencies reacted, in part, to the Bank of England's surprise decision to hold its target interest rates unchanged. The yen slipped against the dollar after a key advisor to Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Abe and former Federal Reserve chief Ben Bernanke had discussed perpetual bonds as a tool to fight deflation.In today's commodities and currency exchanges:West Texas Intermediate: +1.9% to $45.60 a barrelBrent crude: +2.2% to $47.26 a barrelGold: -1.4% to $1,324.90 an ounceEuro-dollar: +0.4%Dollar-yen: +1.2%Pound-dollar: +1.6%10-year Treasury yield: +6 basis points to 1.53%China's mainland markets dipped while other markets, from Hong Kong to London, continued their rallies. Moves by the major indexes included:Shanghai composite: -0.2%Hong Kong Hang Seng index: +1.1%Tokyo Nikkei 225: +1%Paris CAC 40: +1.3%Frankfurt DAX: +1.4%London FTSE 100: +0.3%The number of jobless claims was unchanged, at 254,000, in the week ended July 9 according to the Labor Department. That was better than the uptick to 260,000 expected by economists. The four week moving average dipped to 259,000 -- its third drop in four weeks.The June producer price report showed prices up 0.5%, vs. a 0.4% rise in May and more than the economist-projected 0.3% advance. Core prices, minus energy and food, rose 0.4% -- double the 0.2% estimate and above May's 0.3% increase.St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank President James Bullard speaks at 10 a.m. ET.

Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) on Tuesday announced a deal to buy an 84% stake in mobile video game company Supercell for $8.6 billion. The transaction values the Finnish game developer at $10.2 billion.Helsinki-based Supercell makes free-to-play mobile games such as "Clash of Clans" and "Clash Royale." It makes money by selling virtual goods that help players advance. Supercell's games are played by more than 100 million people each day.Tencent is a leader in PC games, thanks to its purchase of U.S.-based Riot Games, maker of "League of Legends." It is also a major online game distributor in China, handling such titles as Activision's (ATVI) "Call of Duty Online" and Electronic Arts' (EA) "FIFA Online."Last year, Tencent bought minority stakes in mobile game publishers Glu Mobile (GLUU) and Pocket Gems.Tencent is purchasing the stake in Supercell from Japanese telecom firm SoftBank (SFTBY). Tencent expects the deal to close in the third quarter, subject to regulatory approvals and closing conditions."Supercell is known for its creativity, focus on player experience and unique culture, which have enabled it to create innovative mobile games that are wildly popular globally," Tencent President Martin Lau said in a statement. "Tencent is dedicated to building long-term strategic partnerships with leading game companies."We are excited that Supercell is joining our global network of game partners and will preserve their independence and enhance their advantages, thus bringing even more exciting gaming experiences to players around the world."Tencent's purchase of SoftBank's stake in Supercell had been rumored since last month.Tencent, which trades over the counter in the U.S., closed up 0.9% at 22.22 on the stock market today. The stock hit a record high of 22.87 on June 7.Separately Tuesday, SoftBank announced that President Nikesh Arora is stepping down, effective July 1. Several months ago, a group of unidentified SoftBank investors, in a letter to SoftBank's directors, criticized some of Arora's business decisions and claimed he had some conflicts of interest, but the board cleared him of any wrongdoing. Tuesday, SoftBank said Arora would remain in an advisory role with the company. Arora was seen by some as a possible successor to SoftBank's high-profile CEO Masayoshi Son.

With the Electronic Entertainment Expo, better known as E3, drawing to a close in Los Angeles, Wall Street analysts are chiming in with their thoughts on which publicly traded companies performed the best at the annual trade show and which came up short.Several analysts proclaimed "Battlefield 1," a World War I combat game from Electronic Arts (EA), as the title with the most positive buzz at E3.Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said “Battlefield 1” stole the show. He also was impressed with EA's sci-fi action game "Titanfall 2.""Given the initial positive feedback on 'Battlefield 1,' coupled with improved 'Titanfall 2' functionality (now includes single-player campaign), we believe management's current guidance could prove overly conservative," Sebastian said in a research report. He rates EA stock as outperform, with a price target of 80. EA rose 0.8% to 75 on the stock market today.Meanwhile, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) overcame negative pre-show buzz for its game "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" and won over some skeptics.“Before E3, many investors were concerned about the negative reception for (Activision's) ‘Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare’ trailer,” Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson said in a report. “However, we think CoD showed better this week.”Wilson rates Activision stock as overweight with a price target of 43. Activision climbed 1.8% to 39.03 on Thursday.Still "Infinite Warfare" faces "stiff competition" from "Battlefield 1," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report. “Infinite Warfare” is set for release on Nov. 4, following two big EA titles. “Battlefield 1” comes out on Oct. 21 and “Titanfall 2” drops on Oct. 28.The highlight for Activision at E3 came not from the show floor, but from an upbeat report about its recently launched sci-fi shooter game "Overwatch." Activision announced during the show that it has over 10 million users for "Overwatch" worldwide since the game's release on May 24.Baird's Sebastian raised his price target on Activision stock to 43 from 42 on Thursday based on the "Overwatch" news. He maintained his outperform rating on the stock.“While users will likely exceed unit sell-through due to time-based usage in Asia and disc-sharing, we now expect material upside to our original 6 million unit expectation,” he said. “As such, we are increasing our Q2 fiscal 2016 estimates to reflect 8.5 million unit sales.”What’s more, his firm’s checks in China suggest that “Overwatch” is taking significant share from Tencent’s (TCEHY) “League of Legends,” at least temporarily, Sebastian said.On the downside, Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) disappointed analysts and fans at E3 by not announcing any big new titles.“The Street’s biggest takeaway from Take-Two’s E3 2016 will be the lack of an announcement for the next ‘Red Dead’ (or any other new IP), despite a strong showing for ‘Mafia 3’ and ‘Civilization 6’ at the event,” Piper's Olson said. “‘Mafia 3’ in particular could be the critical cog for the company to reach its internal goals. However, little was discussed related to ‘Borderlands,’ ‘Red Dead’ or any other new IP, which is the primary focus of most investors.”Here's our interview with Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick from E3.Olson rates Take-Two stock as overweight with a price target of 40. Take-Two rose 0.7% to 37.77 on Thursday.Pacific Crest's Wilson called Take-Two's game slate this year "uninspired."Another letdown at E3 was the lack of major AAA game titles for new virtual-reality headsets from Sony (SNE), HTC and Facebook's (FB) Oculus.The major game publishers are unwilling to devote resources to VR games until the installed base of headsets makes the market opportunity worthwhile, Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a report.“From a publisher perspective, VR looks more like a 2018 story (at the) earliest,” Pitz said. “Every management team we spoke with had the same two concerns about VR. First, what kind of games will succeed on VR? Second, how long will gamers be willing to wear the headsets?”The three-day E3 conference officially opened Tuesday at the Los Angeles Convention Center, but several large companies held pre-show events.RELATED:‘Clash Of Clans’ Game Maker Possible $9 Billion Takeover TargetElectronic Arts Impresses At E3; Why Take-Two’s Stock Sold OffWedbush’s Pachter On The ‘Conspiracy Theory’ Behind EA’s E3 Snub

This year's E3 has been "much more of a hardware show than we expected," said Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter on Wednesday, calling Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One S announcement "a big deal" and touching on the Sony (SNE) PlayStation Neo and Nintendo (NTDOY) NX console.But what was behind Electronic Arts' (EA) decision to snub E3 in favor of its own event, EA Play?"I think the industry is super healthy right now," Pachter told IBD. "The big downside is EA pulled off the show floor, which I think was a mistake. I think they need to support the industry, because if others follow suit, the industry collapses and there is no more E3, and that would be horrible."Pachter also shares his "conspiracy theory" on why EA decided not to have a booth at the media- and trade-only E3 2016 but instead host its separate consumer-facing gaming event down the street.Click on the video to find out more, and check out Investor's Business Daily's Facebook Live feeds from the show floor, including including this tour of the Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus booth and demo of the Oculus Rift and Touch.RELATED:Are Drone, Cybersecurity And Gaming ETFs On Your Radar?Why Microsoft’s Project Scorpio Is A ‘Game Changer’Electronic Arts Impresses At E3; Why Take-Two’s Stock Sold Off.

Investor's Business Daily spoke to Piper Jaffray Senior Research Analyst Michael Olson, who offered his take on Electronic Arts (EA), Activision (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO):Why Should Investors Be Keeping Tabs On E3? Because Of These Major Publicly Traded NamesFor the full interview, click on the video above, and keep checking Investor's Business Daily's Facebook Live stream for more updates and interviews.Shares of EA closed down 0.2%, Take-Two fell 2.2%, and Activision eased 0.2%.RELATED:As Disney Exits Toys To Life, Drones And Bots Move InVirtual Reality Meets Fitness With VirZOOM Bike.

Electronic Arts (EA) on Sunday kicked off a week of video game announcements around the E3 conference in Los Angeles with details of upcoming titles like “Battlefield 1” and expanded e-sports initiatives.At the company’s EA Play event, held two days before the start of E3, executives announced EA’s lineup for the rest of year and beyond. Key titles included science-fiction action games “Titanfall 2” and “Mass Effect: Andromeda,” as well as the latest sports titles such as “Madden NFL 17” and “FIFA 17.” EA also outlined its coming slate of “Star Wars” games.But the biggest game at EA Play was the World War I combat game “Battlefield 1.” EA had posted a trailer for the game, but this week was the first time it let journalists play “Battlefield 1,” which is set for release on Oct. 21. It will be playable on Sony’s (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft’s (MSFT) Xbox One, as well as on Windows PCs.“Battlefield 1” promises a different experience every time a player plays it, EA said. The game features dynamic weather and “intuitive destruction,” so no battle is ever the same, it said.Redwood City, Calif.-based Electronic Arts also upped its game in the fast-growing e-sports field.EA announced plans to expand competitions for its own titles, starting with “Madden NFL.” It will offer $1 million in prize money for the upcoming Madden NFL 17 Championship Series.Peter Moore, EA’s chief competition officer, said the company wants to open up its tournaments to all levels of players.“We want to make stars of all of our players,” Moore said. “With new competitive modes and weekly online contests in our biggest franchises, we’re making competition fun and meaningful for everyone, regardless of their ability.”Moore announced three types of competition: Challenger, Premier and EA Major events.Despite the new announcements, however, EA shares fell 1.4% to 74.24 in the stock market today.The E3 conference officially runs from Tuesday through Thursday at the Los Angeles Convention Center.Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said “Battlefield 1” is shaping up to be “the most important title of the year for EA.”“Early indicators suggest unprecedented excitement around the game, which is set in WWI,” Pitz said in a report Monday. “The trailer may be the most-liked trailer of all-time on YouTube. The game will feature 64-player multiplayer, and gamers can control behemoth vehicles like airships and battleships.”The most recent game in the series, “Battlefield 4,” sold about 15 million units in its launch quarter, he said.One concern is that EA is launching two big games only a week apart this fall.It is set to release “Titanfall 2” on Oct. 28, one week after “Battlefield 1.” However, EA management expects very little overlap between the audiences for the two franchises, Pitz said.“With two high-quality titles ahead of the holiday, we suspect EA intends to create a challenging environment for competitive shooters like Activision’s (ATVI) Call of Duty, Pitz said.“Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare,” the latest in Activision’s long-running series, is due for release on Nov. 4.Pitz reiterated his buy rating on EA stock with a price target of 105.

Chinese internet company Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) reportedly is close to a deal to buy Finnish mobile game publisher Supercell, best known for its hit "Clash of Clans."Tencent is in late-stage talks with SoftBank (SFTBY) to buy the Japanese telecom giant’s majority stake in Supercell, the Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. SoftBank owns 73% of Supercell. The deal would value Supercell at more than $9 billion, the WSJ said. Just last year, Supercell was valued at $5.25 billion.Helsinki-based Supercell was founded in 2010 and has launched just four titles to date: “Boom Beach,” “Clash of Clans,” “Clash Royale” and “Hay Day.” Its games are free to play, but Supercell sells virtual goods that help players advance.Last year, Supercell had a net profit of about $780 million on revenue of $2.38 billion. It competes with a host of mobile game publishers including Activision's (ATVI) King Digital, Electronic Arts' (EA) EA Mobile, and privately held Machine Zone, Rovio Entertainment and Kabam.Tencent is a leader in PC games thanks to its purchase of U.S.-based Riot Games, maker of “League of Legends.” And last year, it bought minority stakes in mobile game publishers Glu Mobile (GLUU) and Pocket Gems. Tencent is a major online game distributor in China, handling such titles as Activision's "Call of Duty Online" and EA's "FIFA Online."U.S. shares of Tencent rose 2.9% to 22.13 on the stock market today.This week, Tencent is among the many companies participating at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, in Los Angeles.RELATED:Britney Spears Game Lifts Glu, But Big Publishers WinningSony Turns To Batman, ‘Star Wars’ To Lead Virtual Reality Games

GoPro (GPRO). Tencent (TCEHY). Palo Alto Networks (PANW). Activision (ATVI). AeroVironment (AVAV).PureFunds CEO Andrew Chanin spoke with Investor's Business Daily about half a dozen (perhaps millennial-minded) ETFs comprised of publicly traded names like these, including the appropriately named GAMR ETF that covers video game-related stocks such as Activision, Electronic Arts (EA) and others.

Sony (SNE) and Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus are wrestling for the top spot in the nascent market for virtual reality video games. Both companies announced slates of upcoming VR games for their respective headsets on Monday at the annual E3 video game conference in Los Angeles.Sony is hoping to get the upper hand with a lineup of games featuring well-known entertainment franchises, including comic book hero Batman and sci-fi series "Star Wars."At its annual E3 press event, Sony announced that its PlayStation VR virtual-reality system for the PlayStation 4 console will go on sale on Oct. 13 in North America for $399.Sony Interactive Entertainment America revealed a lineup of exclusive games including “Batman: Arkham VR” from RockSteady and Warner Bros Interactive Entertainment, “Star Wars Battlefront: X-Wing VR Mission” from Electronic Arts (EA), and “Farpoint” from Impulse Gear.Sony expects to have over 50 VR games available by year's end, including Capcom's "Resident Evil 7," Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said in a research report Tuesday.PlayStation VR titles will range from $9.99 to $59.99. But “Star Wars Battlefront: X-Wing VR Mission” will be available for free this holiday season to owners of “Star Wars Battlefront” on PS4.PlayStation VR users also will need a $60 PlayStation 4 camera accessory and many games will require PlayStation Move controllers, which cost $50.Sony says it intends to bring VR to the mainstream by leveraging its installed base of over 40 million PS4 consoles worldwide.By contrast, owners of Oculus Rift must have a high-end graphics PC to play games and videos on the $599 VR headset.Oculus announced Monday that its Oculus Touch controller will launch later this year with more than 30 full, made-for-VR games, including 20 brand-new titles. The Oculus Rift headset has been available since March 28.RELATED:EA Kicks Off E3 Week With ‘Battlefield 1’ Debut, E-Sports NewsMicrosoft Confirms ‘Project Scorpio’ After LinkedIn Buy

The E3 gaming expo is in Los Angeles next week and IBD will be covering the show.On the surface, E3 may seem like an event that only concerns gamers, but investors have reasons to be interested.The consumer adoption of virtual reality gear is ramping up, and some notable publicly traded tech companies are involved in this space: Sony (SNE) with its PlayStation VR and Facebook (FB) with its Oculus Rift.There could be announcements related to the gear surrounding next week’s event.Speculation has already risen about such an announcement from Sony. Reports in late March said that Sony has plans to release a new console to accommodate its PlayStation VR headset, which will launch this fall.Rumors have also surfaced that rival Microsoft (MSFT) will unveil new Xbox hardware at the show. Microsoft’s HoloLens is an Augmented Reality device in the developer stage. But Xbox is currently partners with Facebook's Oculus, with its controller included with Rift purchases.Meanwhile, Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google is also developing products for the VR space, but its Cardboard uses a smartphone, not a video game console.Sony fell 1.4% in the stock market today while Microsoft dipped 0.8%. Alphabet dipped 0.1% while Facebook edged up 0.1%.And big-name video game publishers Electronic Arts (EA), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) and Activision (ATVI) will be thrust into the spotlight, though not all of them will be present on E3’s show floor. Still, any information or announcements about new games could impact their stocks.EA is trading near its all-time high set in Tuesday’s session, but fell 3 cents to 76.25 Thursday, as it continues to struggle to break out of a consolidation.Take-Two is also hovering near a recent high, falling 0.2% Thursday. The stock recently broke out of a flat base and is still trading in buy range.And Activision is extended from a breakout past a cup-with-handle base. Shares are trading slightly below their high set earlier this month, climbing 1.1% Thursday as Activision unveiled a new game in its "Destiny" franchise.

Barclays analyst Chris Merwin shared his take on some of E3's biggest news and names, including Microsoft (MSFT), Sony (SNE) and others.Why Should Investors Be Keeping Tabs On E3? Because Of These Major Publicly Traded NamesRELATED:Why EA Is An E3 Standout, And Why Take-Two's Stock Is Falling.

The E3 video game convention offers a steady flow of publicly traded names to track, including Xbox maker Microsoft (MSFT), Oculus maker Facebook (FB) and PlayStation maker Sony (SNE), among others.Microsoft unveiled two new consoles on Monday -- the Xbox One S and Project Scorpio -- and Sony confirmed that the PlayStation VR headset will get an Oct. 13 release date and $399 price tag.Now that the major announcements are mostly out of the way, expect these early media and gamer reactions to shape the public reception of all of the titles and consoles that will soon be available.Microsoft shares fell 0.6%. Facebook shares edged up 0.9%. Sony added 0.6%. Video game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) climbed 2.1%, Electronic Arts (EA) rose 0.4%, and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) gained 0.3%.RELATED:Microsoft Confirms ‘Project Scorpio’ After LinkedIn Buy Dogs In Race Cars: The Future Of Virtual RealityE3: Will Microsoft’s Xbox And Facebook’s Oculus Rift Trump Sony’s VR Console?

Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for Tuesday. The Federal Reserve will begin its two-day policy meeting in Washington, D.C., the Electronic Entertainment Expo gaming conference kicks off in Los Angeles, and Citigroup starts its 2016 Industrials Conference in Boston. Meanwhile, Apple's (AAPL) Worldwide Developers Conference continues in San Francisco. Fed Meeting Market watchers…

The Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles is expected to be somewhat smaller this year as major video game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) will be absent from the show floor, but that doesn’t mean there won’t be any game-changing announcements.This year’s E3 is focused on the prospect of hardware updates from Sony (SNE) and Microsoft (MSFT) as analysts and industry experts call for a shorter console upgrade cycle.It’s been four years since Sony's PlayStation and Microsoft's Xbox have released new consoles, and the gaming community has sighed at the sluggish pace.But with virtual reality headsets and games now hitting the consumer market, it could be time for a refresh since powerful consoles are needed to handle the complex virtual reality graphics."We view this event as a directional positive change to transform the traditional (roughly) 5-year console upgrade cycle to a more small-steps/iterative series akin to what PC and mobile hardware see currently," said Credit Suisse analyst Stephen Ju in a June 9 report.Ju says the result "may be a decreased incentive for the consumer to wait for new hardware as well as alleviated development gyrations for the publishers," and calls that a "win-win."Sony launches its PlayStation VR gear this fall for $399, and a report from the Wall Street Journal in late March said the company has plans to unveil a new console ahead of the headset’s release.E3, with a show floor open Tuesday through Thursday and press conferences several days prior, is an ideal venue for such an announcement and has been the selected location for big-name product debuts in years past.Speculation also has surfaced that Sony rival Microsoft will unveil new Xbox hardware at the show. The HoloLens, Microsoft’s augmented reality headset, is still in the developer stage. But Xbox currently partners with Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus VR, with its Xbox One controller included with a $599 Rift purchase.Some analysts have even asserted an expansion on an Xbox-Oculus partnership, since Oculus currently does not have its own console and requires expensive PCs to run its games.Adding to the tone of the event is the absence of major video game publishers Electronic Arts and Activision Blizzard from the show floor. EA will be holding its own separate event that's open to the public, dubbed "EA Play," at a nearby venue.According to Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter, the decision has a ripple effect."EA's move to its own space a block away from E3 will benefit EA but will hurt the industry, and we fear that if EA's choice creates a template that others follow, E3 will suffer mightily in future years," Pachter said in a June 6 report.He's "less critical" of Activision's decision. It has opted to relocate its floor presence to the PlayStation booth, with its "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare" among the games to be displayed. Activision on Thursday announced the September launch of "Destiny: Rise of Iron."The third major publicly traded video game publisher, Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), will have a booth at the show.E3 is typically a trade and media-only event, but in late May the Entertainment Software Association announced the debut of "E3 Live," which will be a public event held at the same time as E3. It's also at the same location as EA Play.With significant announcements, the event could be a catalyst for a number of stocks. EA, Activision, Take-Two are all currently trading 5% or less below their recent highs.Sony broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 28.21 buy point on Monday, but fell below that level Friday. It lost 2.6% to 28.03 in the stock market today.Microsoft is finding support at its 200-day line, but its recent attempts to retake the 50-day line were met with resistance. Shares are trading 8% below their late December high and ticked down 0.3% to 51.48.Facebook has been trading sideways for more than a month, but it's still holding within buy range from a cup-with-handle base cleared in April after the social media giant's earnings report. Shares were down 1.6% to 116.62 by the close Friday.

The Computer Software-Gaming group ranks in the bottom half of IBD’s 197 industry group rankings, but it’s been the top performer in the past four weeks, up about 10%. This year's teeter-totter market has posed special challenges for all investors. The managers of $1.3 billion USAA Aggressive Growth (USAUX) are no exceptions.Over the past year going into Wednesday, the fund has outperformed 72% of its rival large-cap growth mutual funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. by losing less than most of them. The fund has gained 4.99% in the volatile past three months, but that only tops 28% of its peers.The fund could be primed for strong performance when the stock market strengthens if the quality of its top holdings are an indication. Aggressive Growth's top 10 holdings as of March 31 included six stocks with IBD Composite Ratings of 80 or higher. The highest Comp Rating is 99. The Composite Rating combines IBD’s five performance ratings, including EPS and Relative Strength ratings. Stocks poised to move higher often have a high Comp Rating.In addition, holdings include Adobe Systems (ADBE), which sports a 92 Comp Rating.Trading around 95, Adobe is working on a cup-with-handle base with a 98.10 buy point. Volume has dried up as the handle forms, which is positive. But as IBD's Leaderboard analysis of the stock points out, Adobe's earlier breakout past an 88.65 handle entry within the base was successful, and from that point of view the stock is extended. Still, you could make a case that the right side of the base needed more work.Adobe has succeeded in morphing into a company that lets customers receive products through the cloud and pay a subscription fee.Is Adobe a buy or a sell? Take a free trial of IBD Leaderboard today to find outRevenue growth has sped over the past three quarters, from 9% to 21%, 22% and 25%. The fiscal second quarter ends this month. Wall Street currently expects earnings to rise 42% to 68 cents a share. That would extend the slowdown in EPS gains of 30%, 93%, 59% and 50% in the prior four quarters. It's still vigorous profit growth.Facebook (FB), another Leaderboard stock, is one of those top holdings. It has a 99 Composite Rating.EPS gains are accelerating, rising 16%, 33% 46% and 83% the past four quarters. The 83% earnings jump to 77 cents a share easily beat Wall Street estimates as did the 52% jump in revenue to $5.4 billion. The stock responded to the upbeat results by gapping up 7% April 28 and clearing a 117.09 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. It got as high as 121 before easing to just below the buy point.Facebook has gifted investors with a big 300%-plus return since it broke out past a 29.17 buy point of a double-bottom base in the week ended July 26, 2013, as IBD pointed out recently.Electronic Arts (EA) is a top new buy, which has a 95 Comp Rating.The video game publisher delivered better-than-expected earnings and sales growth last week.Q4 EPS rose 28%. That profit got a boost from EA's growing digital sales, which made up over 70% of all fourth-quarter revenue, as IBD reported on Tuesday.Also, EA had no debt last year and a solid 32% return on equity. That, plus a 46% average annual EPS growth rate over the past five years, has attracted a rising number of funds as investors. Two typically better-performing funds own shares in Electronic Arts: $12 billion Fidelity OTC (FOCPX) and $12 billion MFS Growth (MFEGX).Among other holdings, Zimmer Biomet Holdings (ZBH) has a 99 Comp Rating and is up 16% so far this year.The maker of orthopedic and dental reconstruction implants, trauma products and related surgical products has seen EPS rise in each of the past four quarters, climbing from -2% to 30% in that span. Revenue grew 59%, 58% and 68% in the past three stanzas. The company beat consensus estimates for both EPS and revenue in Q1.The company was born from last year's $14 billion merger of Zimmer Holdings and Biomet. That created a global leader in musculoskeletal health care, which does business in more than 100 countries, IBD recently reported.Last month, Zimmer said it would take over Cayenne Medical to strengthen its sports medicine offerings.Trading near 117, the stock is within 1% of the 117.87 buy point of a long cup-with-handle base.The portfolio is run by two separate subadvisors. Winslow Capital and Wellington Management each manage about 50% of the fund. When one side's outperformance skews the split by too much, USAA rebalances by funneling inflow into the lagging portion. It also takes any shareholder redemptions from the larger portion.Winslow's Clark Winslow, Patrick Burton and Justin Kelly are somewhat more aggressive in their style, says USAA's Wasif Latif, who oversees the subadvisors. Wellington's manager is Paul Marrkand. "Wellington is more conscious of valuation," Latif said.The subadvisors' sleeves share many names. "But Winslow has more FANG stocks," said USAA analyst Julius Barnes, referring to 2015 high-flyers Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google, now Alphabet (GOOGL).As of Jan. 31, UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and Starbucks (SBUX) were in the Winslow sleeve only.Going into Thursday, UnitedHealth was up about 11% for the year. It had an 86 Comp Rating but a weak D+ Accumulation/Distribution Rating, which is a sign of more recent selling than buying by mutual funds over the past 13 weeks. Starbucks was down about 9% for the year. It has a so-so 70 Comp Rating and worst-possible E Accumulation/Distribution Rating.Oracle (ORCL) and PepsiCo (PEP) were two names in Wellington's sleeve only.Oracle was up 8%, but has a weak 55 Composite Rating and a D Accumulation/Distribution Rating. EPS fell the past four quarters and were flat in the two frames before that.Pepsi was up less than 1%, with a 59 Composite Rating and E Accumulation/Distribution Rating."When we have a high-growth, bullish market, Winslow does better," Latif said. "The opposite happens when the market is not led by growth and is challenged." Wellington's sleeve has outperformed Winslow's so far this year, Latif says.

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) on Tuesday laid out its plan to add $1 billion in incremental revenue within the next three to five years.EA earned mostly positive reviews for its presentation at the company's investor day event, held at its headquarters in Redwood City, Calif.Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz reiterated his outperform rating on EA stock but raised his price target to 88 from 78. EA stock fell 0.9% to 74.49 on the stock market today. Electronic Arts shares hit an all-time high of 77.15 on Monday.“We came away more confident in EA’s growth strategy and ability to engage existing and potential customers with new tools,” Uerkwitz said in a research report Wednesday. “We believe secular tailwinds such as the move to digital and mobile will support multiyear margin expansion and profit growth for the company.”EA sees future sales growth coming from action games, shooter games and international expansion. It projects that digital growth, including sales of full-game downloads and extra content spending, will boost profitability.Another area of growth is e-sports. EA says competitive gaming initiatives will drive game sales, plus deliver advertising and sponsorship revenue.The next potential catalyst for EA is the E3 video game conference in mid-June, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a note Wednesday. He maintained his overweight rating on EA stock with a price target of 87.EA’s game lineup for its current fiscal 2017 is more attractive than last year’s slate, Olson said. Upcoming releases include “Mirror’s Edge Catalyst,” due out June 7, and “Battlefield 1,” due out Oct. 21. Also in the pipeline are “Titanfall 2,” scheduled for fiscal Q3, and “Mass Effect: Andromeda,” set for late Q4. EA's fiscal 2017 started April 1.EA ended fiscal 2016 with non-GAAP revenue of $4.57 billion, up 6% year over year. Earnings per share minus items rose 25% to $3.14 in the just-closed fiscal year.EA isn't the only video game stock trading just below its record high. Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), which reports fiscal Q4 earnings after the market close Wednesday, hit an all-time high of 38.52 on April 4. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) notched a record high of 39.93 on Dec. 29.Take-Two stock sank 0.9% to 35.68 and Activision stock rose 0.9% to 38.47 in trading Wednesday.RELATED:EA Stock Soars Like ‘Star Wars’ Millennium Falcon After Q4 Beat.

Mobile video game publisher Glu Mobile (GLUU) got a rise Thursday from the release of a new game featuring pop singer Britney Spears. However, it’s the big game publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) that are winning in the mobile games market.Glu saw its low-priced, micro-cap stock rise 7% to 2.50 in afternoon trading on the stock market today, on the release of its latest celebrity game: “Britney Spears: American Dream.”The San Francisco-based company needs another hit along the lines of its genre-defining game, “Kim Kardashian: Hollywood,” to regain its footing.Glu’s sales have fallen on a year-over-year basis for three straight quarters. And the declines are accelerating -- from a 2% decrease in Q3 2015 to a 16% drop in Q4 and a 22% fall in Q1.Glu has a miserable IBD Relative Strength Rating of 3, meaning it is in the bottom 3% for performance among all stocks over the last 12 months.Another publicly traded maker of mobile games, San Francisco-based Zynga (ZNGA), faces similar challenges. Its sales have stalled the last two quarters -- falling 4% year over year in Q4 and increasing just 2% in Q1. Zynga is known for games such as “Words With Friends” and “Zynga Poker.”Like Glu, Zynga stock is low valued, trading near 2.50 and up a fraction Thursday afternoon.Meanwhile, PC and console game giants Activision Blizzard and Electronic Arts reported solid gains in their mobile game initiatives in the March quarter.Activision stock jumped to near its all-time high after the company posted better-than-expected first-quarter results on May 5. The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company credited the upside surprise to newly acquired mobile game publisher King Digital Entertainment and its hot titles like “Candy Crush Jelly Saga.”Activision completed its purchase of King on Feb. 23. In Q1, King’s monthly active users rose 3% to 463 million from the prior quarter. King has had three of the top 15 highest-grossing titles in the U.S. mobile app stores for nine quarters in a row.EA stock climbed to a record high of 77.15 after the Redwood City, Calif.-based company posted better-than-expected results for its fiscal Q4 on May 10. Shares were down 1.5% Thursday afternoon, near 73.50.EA was the No. 1 most-downloaded mobile game publisher in 2015, with such popular games as “Madden NFL Mobile” and “Star Wars: Galaxy of Heroes.”

The rally was modest Tuesday and faded at the close as the S&P 500 dropped slightly. Yet early gains were good enough to produce some intriguing new highs. Thor Industries (THO) was one of the more interesting, bursting out of a long consolidation with a conventional buy point of 64.75. Although it had traded around the buy point for a…

The U.K.'s surprising and historic decision to leave the European Union overshadowed all other news this week, roiling global markets and raising doubts about the European economy and post-war order.But it was a busy week for business news. In a well-timed release, the Federal Reserve said JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and other giant banks passed their "stress test" scenarios. Elon Musk's bid to merge Tesla Motors (TSLA) and SolarCity (SCTY) raised doubts, even among long-time devotees. Wal-Mart (WMT) and JD.com (JD) teamed up. Adobe Systems (ADBE), Red Hat (RHT) and FedEx (FDX) gave weak guidance, and the Federal Aviation Administration finalized drone regulations.Gloom overtook world markets after Britons voted to leave the EU amid a wave of nationalist sentiment. The vote will begin a long process of negotiations to determine what parts of the existing business landscape will stay or go for a range of industries that operate in the region. JPMorgan Chase, American Airlines (AAL) and their global peers were hit hard. U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron said he would step down, while right-wing populists elsewhere on the Continent called for similar referendums in their nations, potentially expanding financial and cultural fissures within the bloc. The Federal Reserve said it is "prepared to provide dollar liquidity through its existing swap lines with central banks, as necessary," but questions remained about how much left was in its arsenal to ward off any coming market turmoil.U.S. stocks had rallied through Thursday, in large part because polls got it wrong and predicted that the U.K. would stay in the EU. Stocks suffered huge losses Friday after the Brexit results pushing the major averages into the red. The Nasdaq lost 1.9% for the week while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials closed off 1.6%. European markets suffered deeper losses. Big losers included carriers such American Air, while Tesla Motors tumbled on its ill-received SolarCity bid. Treasury yields hit four-year lows. The dollar skyrocketed vs. the pound but tumbled vs. the yen.Tesla made a surprise offer to buy solar energy company SolarCity in a stock swap valued at roughly $2.7 billion. Tesla CEO Elon Musk is chairman of SolarCity, which is run by Musk's cousins.Analyst reviews of the deal hit a negative tone, calling it a fundamental change to Tesla's business model that could thwart its aggressive efforts to expand production of its all-electric vehicles and add to cash flow and financing concerns. Tesla shares tumbled 10.45% on Wednesday, its worst one-day loss since May 2014. Tesla  fell 10.4% for the week. SolarCity initially spiked on the deal, but closed up just 4.1% as investors doubt a deal will happen. Musk, the top shareholder of both companies, said he won't vote on any merger agreement.The Federal Reserve passed all 33 banks -- including majors JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) -- in the first round of its annual stress tests, as expected. Investors will now focus on the second round of results, set for release Wednesday, that will determine whether banks can carry out their submitted plans to return capital to shareholders. But just because banks can weather a storm doesn't mean it will be fun: Bank stocks were among the biggest losers Friday on the Brexit fallout, erasing gains from earlier in the week.Adobe reported better-than-expected adjusted earnings per share on in-line sales for its fiscal second quarter ended June 3, but investors focused on its disappointing sales guidance for Q3.The maker of digital media and marketing software earned 71 cents a share excluding items, 3 cents above views, on sales of $1.4 billion. It was Adobe's fourth straight quarter of 20% or greater sales growth and its seventh straight quarter of double-digit gains in adjusted EPS.For the current quarter, Adobe is targeting non-GAAP earnings per share of 72 cents on sales of $1.445 billion, based on the midpoint of guidance. Analysts had been modeling 71 cents, up 31%, on sales of $1.47 billion, up 21%.Adobe shares were down 3.55% for the week, undercutting a buy area.Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) announced a deal to buy an 84% stake in mobile video game company Supercell for $8.6 billion. The transaction values the Finnish game developer at $10.2 billion.Helsinki-based Supercell makes free-to-play mobile games such as "Clash of Clans" and "Clash Royale." It makes money by selling virtual goods that help players advance in its games. Supercell's games are played by more than 100 million people each day.Tencent is a leader in online games. It owns "League of Legends" maker Riot Games and distributes games in China for Activision (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and others.Wal-Mart (WMT) announced an alliance with China's JD.com (JD), with JD taking ownership of Wal-Mart's Yihaodian marketplace, its China e-commerce business, in return for an approximate 5% stake in JD.com in the form of newly issued shares. The move may help both Wal-Mart and JD compete against Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA).JD.com is the second-largest online retailer in China after Alibaba. Wal-Mart has struggled to build its China business.Wal-Mart rose 1.4%, hitting a 10-month high. JD closed up 2.5% for the week.Twitter (TWTR) expanded its push into machine learning with the acquisition of Magic Pony Technology, a London-based startup that specializes in visual processing.Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed, but the price tag was reported to be $150 million.Magic Pony's technology ranges across computer vision, machine learning, high-performance computing and computational neuroscience.Also, Twitter gave its users more room to unleash their creativity, expanding the length of its video play to 140 seconds from 30, as it battles for viewers with the likes of Facebook (FB) photo and video sharing site Instagram, which has now grown to 500 million subscribers.The Twitter change is designed to help video creators boost their audiences and make money in the process.Existing-home sales rose 1.8% in May to an annual rate of 5.53 million, the highest in nine years, the National Association of Realtors said. But new-home sales fell 6% to 551,000, the Commerce Department said. April new-home sales were revised down sharply to 586,000 from the initial reading of 619,000. Tight supply has limited purchases of new dwellings. But homebuilders Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH) reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings.Meanwhile, new jobless claims fell 18,000 in the week ended June 18 to 259,000, the Labor Department said. That was a bigger drop than expected, and put the total back near a 43-year low set in March. It's a good sign for the June employment report after May's surprisingly weak payrolls gain.The Transportation Department and FAA finalized regulations for the commercial use of drones, which officials say could generate more than $82 billion for the U.S. economy over the next 10 years. The rules are seen as less restrictive than expected. Under the new regulations, the unmanned aircraft must be kept within the pilot's line of sight and cannot be operated at night, but those restrictions could be lifted under a waiver. Among the publicly traded companies impacted by the new rules are Amazon (AMZN), Wal-Mart, GoPro (GPRO) and AeroVironment (AVAV).Red Hat reported fiscal Q1 revenue and billings slightly above views, as well as in-line earnings. But it forecast full-year profit that was a bit light, citing a new planned acquisition. Some analysts said larger enterprise deals were a bright spot. The open-source Linux software company increased a stock buyback program to $1 billion from its earlier $500 million authorization. Red Hat is expected to update its public cloud strategy at an investor day slated for June 30.Red Hat stock tumbled 4.8% for the week, falling below a recent buy point.FedEx reported strong fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings per share and revenue growth, both topping analyst estimates. But the company forecast adjusted EPS of $11.75-$12.25 for the current fiscal year. The midpoint of $12 was below consensus of $12.05. FedEx also didn't say how its recently acquired European shipper TNT Express would affect results. Shares fell 4.5% on Wednesday, a day after it issued Q4 results. Shares are off 7.2% this week, undercutting the 200-day line.The No. 2 U.S. package shipper plans to spend about $5.1 billion this year for ongoing expansion of the FedEx Ground network, as well as for planned aircraft purchases to support the FedEx Express fleet modernization program. Rival and No. 1 shipper UPS (UPS) crept out to a 17-month high on Thursday before tumbling Friday to fall less 1% for the week amid the Brexit turmoil on the market.
