Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) late Thursday missed Wall Street's targets for the fourth quarter and gave conservative guidance for the current quarter and full-year 2016.Investors punished Activision stock on Friday. In morning trading, Activision shares were down about 10% to about 27 on the stock market today. On Dec. 29, Activision stock hit an all-time high of 39.93. At least eight Wall Street analysts cut their price targets on Activision stock after the earnings report.The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company earned 83 cents a share excluding items on sales of $2.12 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Activision to earn 86 cents a share on sales of $2.20 billion. On a year-over-year basis, Activision's EPS fell 12%, and its sales slipped 4%.Activision was hurt by smaller-than-expected sales of “Guitar Hero Live” and “Skylanders” during the holiday quarter, as well as negative foreign-exchange trends, Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey said in a research report Friday.For the current quarter, Activision expects to earn 11 cents a share ex items on sales of $800 million. For 2016, Activision is looking to earn $1.75 in adjusted EPS on sales of $6.25 billion.Activision’s figures include its planned acquisition of King Digital Entertainment (KING), while current Wall Street estimates do not.Excluding King, Activision’s core adjust EPS guidance for the year would be $1.35, 21 cents below Wall Street consensus, Hickey said.“The company’s weaker-than-anticipated guidance was primarily attributable to the delay of (the sequal to action game) ‘Destiny’ and the general conservative nature of management,” Hickey said. He rates Activision stock buy, but he lowered his price target to 37.63 from 43.07.The underperformance of "Guitar Hero" and "Skylanders" was partially offset by the continued success of "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Friday. He reiterated his overweight rating on Activision stock but cut his price target to 39 from 42."We still believe a history of conservatism suggests the outlook may prove low,” Olson said. “Activision has exceeded its original full-year revenue and EPS outlook, on average, by 19% and 7% from ’09 to ’15.”Excluding a tax benefit, Activision would have missed its earnings guidance for the first time in 10 years in the fourth quarter, Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said in a report Friday. He maintained his outperform rating on Activision stock but lowered his 12-month price target to 40 from 47.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson said the holiday season proved "strangely difficult" for the video game industry.Activision, Electronic Arts (EA), GameStop (GME) and Ubisoft all disappointed with their recent earnings reports, he said.“This is supposed to be the sweet spot right?” Wilson said in a report Thursday. “What has become clear is that the breadth of successful games continues to narrow, and increases in competition can have a huge impact, especially on lower-quality or casual titles. This holiday likely fully transitions the sector from ‘buy the basket’ to ‘buy the slate,’ as releases don’t guarantee success.”Wilson maintained his overweight rating on Activision stock but trimmed his price target to 36 from 41.RELATED:Take-Two Interactive Software’s Games Show Staying Power; Q3 BeatsElectronic Arts Falls On Mixed Q3, Weak Guidance.

Oculus founder Palmer Luckey announced a deal at this week's virtual reality Vision Summit with Unity, a 3D game engine used to create a vast amount of VR content.Unity has partnerships with Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google, Facebook (FB), Sony (SNE) and Microsoft (MSFT) among others. That means the Unity platform is compatible with Google Cardboard, Facebook's Oculus Rift, Sony's PlayStation VR and Microsoft's HoloLens.IBD sat down with Unity CEO John Riccitiello, former chief executive at Electronic Arts (EA), to learn more about the new pact with Oculus.

The new Star Wars movie could be a force that lifts a lot of companies this holiday season: cinemas, toy makers, video game publishers ... and big-screen theater firm Imax (IMAX).Rosenblatt Securities analyst Martin Pyykkonen on Monday reiterated his buy rating on Imax stock, based in part on the impact of Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," which opens Dec. 18."The advanced domestic ticket sales for Disney's 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' are already setting new records (about $50 million) nearly a month before its opening weekend, and Imax is over-indexing so far, with about one-third of those advance tickets sales domestically," he said in a research note.The Imax percentage of advance ticket sales for the movie likely will decline as the release date approaches, due to Imax screen capacity, Pyykkonen said."The highly anticipated new 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' film could be a new catalyst for another foreign screen growth cycle beyond the current global (total addressable market that) Imax is projecting," he said.Pyykkonen noted that another blockbuster film, 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) "Avatar," released five years ago, was a key catalyst to kick-starting Imax screen growth in China. The new Star Wars flick could have a similar effect, he said."Our key focus continues to be on Imax's long-term foreign screen growth outlook," Pyykkonen said. "We estimate that even by the end of 2016, the Imax foreign screen base will still only be about 35% of the total addressable market (TAM) across foreign regions. Imax's global TAM estimate is 2,450 total global screens (1,000 in Greater China)."Pyykkonen has a price target of 47 on Imax stock. Imax was down a fraction, near 38, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Other companies benefiting from Star Wars mania include Electronic Arts (EA), which released its video game "Star Wars Battlefront" on Nov. 17; and toy licensees like Hasbro (HAS) and Lego Group.RELATED:EA's New 'Star Wars' Game Gets 'Disappointing' ReviewsCan Stores Keep Pace With 'Star Wars' Toy Demand?'Star Wars' To Help 3D Cinema Leap Into Hyperspace.

"Star Wars Battlefront," the much-anticipated video game from Electronic Arts (EA), appears to have found its dark side: mediocre reviews. The game, released Tuesday, has earned an early score of 73 out of 100 on Metacritic, based on 13 critics using a version of the game for Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One console. That falls in the range of "mixed or average reviews," Metacritic said. The version of the game for Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 earned a score of 78, which equates to "generally favorable reviews," based on reports from 11 critics.Critics praised "Star Wars Battlefront" for its visuals and cinematic quality, but knocked it for limited gameplay and lack of options. The game rides a wave of enthusiasm ahead of Walt Disney 's (DIS) holiday movie "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," a sequel to the classic science-fiction trilogy.Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi said the initial reviews for "Battlefront" are "disappointing," but the game likely still will sell 13 million units in the company's fiscal 2016, which ends March 31."In our view, the game should be a holiday hit, boosted by the upcoming theatrical release of 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' on Dec. 14," Doshi said in a research note Tuesday."Reading user reviews, many of the lowest scores were from people who expected a single player campaign," he said. "There were also some complaints regarding a lack of content, which we believe the company will address with upcoming DLC (downloadable content)."Also, major gaming sites like IGN and Game Informer have yet to post their reviews, Doshi said.Doshi reiterated his buy rating on EA stock, with a price target of 84.EA stock was up 1%, near 69, in midday trading on the stock market today.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said "Star Wars Battlefront" is a game that can "rise above" reviews because of enthusiasm for the "Star Wars" franchise."Early reviews agree the game looks good, but suggest the dearth of overall content limits replay," Olson said.Olson rates EA stock as overweight, with a price target of 87.The major game publishers are benefiting from the sweet spot in the console upgrade cycle. The installed base of new game consoles, such as the Xbox One and PS4, is big enough to support the release of many AAA titles.Shares of game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) were both up nearly 3% in midday trading Tuesday.RELATED:GameStop weakness exposed by retail sales reportActivision's 'Black Ops 3' comes out with guns blazing.

The consumer shift from packaged video game sales to digital downloads is putting the hurt on specialty retailer GameStop (GME). GameStop shares were down 15% to below 38 in afternoon trading on the stock market today.
The tumble followed a report late Thursday by the NPD Group on October retail sales of video games in the U.S.

The NPD report showed that game software sales at retail fell 3% year over year last month to $338 million, despite the launch of several hot game titles, including Microsoft's (MSFT) "Halo 5: Guardians" and Ubisoft's "Assassin's Creed: Syndicate."
Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson downgraded GameStop stock to sector weight from overweight on the report Thursday.

"The video game business is seeing a dollar mix-shift to digital games, which is a cocktail of DLC (downloadable content), direct downloads, mobile and free-to-play," Wilson said in a report. "GameStop has much lower share and very little profitability in digital."

GameStop's sales of new physical software grew 2.3% through Q1 and Q2, but expectations for growth this year look risky now, Wilson said. He also thinks GameStop will show no growth in new software sales in fiscal 2016.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said that the digital shift in game sales appears to have "dramatically accelerated."
He expected retail game software sales to rise 34% year over year in October, but they fell 3%.

"This is the biggest miss we have seen in eight years," he said in a report. "We suspect most of this is due to digital sale share take and hence more of a problem for physical retailers than the publishers."
Most of the shortfall in physical game software sales last month, he said, is attributable to the top-selling title, "Halo 5."

"'Halo 5' sold less than half of the units we were modeling, accounting for almost half the miss in our overall number," Creutz said. "Since Microsoft has already announced that 'Halo 5' is the fastest-selling 'Halo' title of all time, and even allowing for some variance in release date timing and such, this suggests to us that at least half of 'Halo 5''s non-bundled unit sales were digital."
The No. 2 best-selling game at retail in October was "NBA 2K16" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), followed by "Assassin's Creed: Syndicate."
Electronic Arts (EA) had the fourth best-selling game in "Madden NFL 16," followed by "WWE 2K16" from Take-Two.

Overall sales of video game hardware, software and accessories at U.S. retail rose 2% in October to $806 million, NPD reported. Game hardware sales were flat at $270 million, but accessories were up 18% to $198 million, the retail tracker said.
RELATED:
Activision's 'Black Ops 3' comes out with guns blazing.

'Grand Theft Auto' maker steals record high on Q2 earnings.The consumer shift from packaged video game sales to digital downloads is putting the hurt on specialty retailer GameStop (GME). GameStop shares were down 15% to below 38 in afternoon trading on the stock market today. The tumble followed a report late Thursday by the NPD Group on October retail sales of video games in the U.S.The NPD report showed that game software sales at retail fell 3% year over year last month to $338 million, despite the launch of several hot game titles, including Microsoft's (MSFT) "Halo 5: Guardians" and Ubisoft's "Assassin's Creed: Syndicate."Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson downgraded GameStop stock to sector weight from overweight on the report Thursday."The video game business is seeing a dollar mix-shift to digital games, which is a cocktail of DLC (downloadable content), direct downloads, mobile and free-to-play," Wilson said in a report. "GameStop has much lower share and very little profitability in digital."GameStop's sales of new physical software grew 2.3% through Q1 and Q2, but expectations for growth this year look risky now, Wilson said. He also thinks GameStop will show no growth in new software sales in fiscal 2016.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said that the digital shift in game sales appears to have "dramatically accelerated."He expected retail game software sales to rise 34% year over year in October, but they fell 3%."This is the biggest miss we have seen in eight years," he said in a report. Insiders at Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR), Amazon (AMZN), Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) and Bank of America (BAC) were among those who made notable trades disclosed this week.The transactions come as many of those companies contend with disappointing quarterly results, struggles with user engagement and broader fears of economic turmoil.A handful of Facebook's senior managers recently sold shares of the social media giant, according to SEC filings this week. Jan Koum, a director and founder of WhatsApp, disclosed the sale of 286,906 company shares.Last week, Koum disclosed the sale of almost 1.15 million shares for about $114.2 million. He agreed to sell WhatsApp to Facebook in 2014 for $19 billion and still holds more than 65 million Facebook shares.Koum recently expressed support for Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook's resistance to a government order to assist the FBI in cracking the security software in an iPhone used by Syed Rizwan Farook, one of the shooters in the San Bernardino, Calif., mass killing in December.Facebook Chief Technology Officer Mike Schroepfer also disclosed the sale of 20,000 shares, while Chief Product Officer Chris Cox had sold 15,600 shares.Facebook shares ended the week up 2.5%.Bank of America Director Frank Bramble has bought 75,000 company shares, while the banking giant's stock has tumbled 28% since the start of the year amid growing fears of a recession.On Tuesday, Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari also called for policymakers to consider breaking up big banks to avoid another government bailout.Shares of Bank of America added 1.5% for the week.Barry Rosenstein, a board member of Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) and a founder of hedge fund JANA Capital Partners, disclosed the sale of 1.72 million shares of the drugstore operator.After visiting with management recently, Wolfe Research analyst Scott Mushkin wrote in a note this week that "we have even more doubt that the merger with (Rite Aid (RAD)) will be approved.”Walgreens shares rose 0.6% vs. a week ago. Rite Aid gained 1.4%.Thomas Ryder, a member of e-commerce giant Amazon's board and a former CEO of the Reader's Digest Association, has sold 4,000 shares. Director William Gordon, a co-founder of Electronic Arts (EA), has sold 1,000 shares.Amazon's fourth-quarter results last month disappointed investors. But its cloud services stand to benefit as more tech firms adopt cloud-based infrastructures and, if nothing else, recent company moves suggested to some that it could be considering selling its own diapers.Amazon shares rallied 5.5% for the week.Twitter Chief Financial Officer Anthony Noto disclosed the purchase of 15,500 company shares. Noto also disclosed purchases in November, August and May.The latest purchase comes as the company's share price has suffered amid struggles to draw more users. Twitter also recently announced plans to incorporate tweets based on relevance into users' timelines.Twitter shares surged 15.3%.LinkedIn (LNKD) Chief Financial Officer Steve Sordello has sold 1,405 company shares. The professional networking site's stock crashed this month on a weak 2016 forecast, which came after the company killed its marketing-centered Lead Accelerator segment.LinkedIn shares jumped 12.9%.Insider transactions don’t typically have a major impact on a stock or indicate major pending news. Rapid liquidation of all or most of an insider’s holdings, however, can affect a stock.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) military shooter game "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3" has blasted its way into the history books. Activision announced Wednesday that the latest game in its hugely popular "Call of Duty" franchise racked up more than $550 million sold through to consumers worldwide in its first three days of release.
That makes it the biggest entertainment launch of the year in any medium, topping even the blockbuster movie "Jurassic World."
Player engagement metrics also are up, the Santa Monica, Calif.-based game publisher said. Fans played more than 75 million hours online for "Black Ops 3" in its opening three days.

Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said the three-day revenue figure probably equates to more than 9 million units of "Black Ops 3" being sold. Olson is modeling for Activision to sell 20.5 million units of the game in 2015.

"Given the solid reviews and a larger next-gen (console) installed base, our estimate could prove conservative," Olson said in a research report Wednesday. "Additionally, we anticipate strong digital attach rates for subscription and a la carte downloadable content."

Olson rates Activision stock as overweight with a price target of 42. Activision stock was up more than 2%, near 34.50, in afternoon trading on the stock market today, after touching a record high just shy of 38 on Thursday.

Cowen analyst Doug Creutz called the opening-weekend "Black Ops 3" sales a "solid start." It implies a first-year sell-through pace of 22 million to 23 million units, providing upside to his estimates and company guidance.
Creutz rates Activision stock as outperform with a price target of 44.

The fall and holiday seasons are crowded with major software releases as the current video game console cycle hits the sweet spot. The next big title is science-fiction action game "Star Wars: Battlefront" from Electronic Arts (EA), due out Tuesday.

Other major titles recently released or coming within a few weeks are Microsoft's (MSFT) "Halo 5: Guardians," Ubisoft's "Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege" and "Assassin's Creed Syndicate," EA's "Need for Speed," Bethesda Softworks' "Fallout 4," and Nintendo's (NTDOY) "Yoshi's Woolly World."

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) late Thursday surprised Wall Street with better-than-expected September-quarter sales and earnings, thanks to its popular sports games. It also raised guidance for the year based on anticipation for its blockbuster "Star Wars: Battlefront" game.

For its fiscal Q2 ended Sept. 30, EA earned 65 cents a share excluding items, down 11% year over year but better than the 45 cents expected by Wall Street. Sales dipped 6% to $1.15 billion, which topped the Street's forecast for $1.10 billion. Sales would have been up 3% year over year if not for foreign-exchange-rate effects.
For the December quarter, EA expects to earn $1.75 a share ex items, up 43%, on sales of $1.78 billion, up 24%.

"Our markets are very healthy, the digital transition continues to drive margins, and engagement in our live services and excitement for our upcoming launches is exceptional," EA Chief Financial Officer Blake Jorgensen said in a statement.

Despite the beat, Electronic Arts shares were down 4%, near 73, in morning trading in the stock market today, the day after shares touched an all-time high of 76.92. EA stock maintains a strong IBD Relative Strength Rating of 96, where 99 is the highest.
Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz reiterated his buy rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 95 from 80.

"If EA can post such solid results in its 'tough quarter,' we are even more optimistic around the holiday, when key title 'Star Wars: Battlefront' drops on Nov. 17," Pitz said in a research report. "EA continues to benefit from two powerful tailwinds: 1) fast console sales and 2) the digital transition, which is resulting in EA being structurally more profitable than ever."
EA's fiscal Q2 was driven by strong sales of "Madden NFL 16" and "FIFA 16."
Based on a successful beta test, EA upped its sales estimate for "Star Wars: Battlefront" to 13 million units from a range of 9 million to 10 million.

Digital game sales, including full game downloads and add-on content, accounted for 42% of revenue in fiscal Q2. Digital sales are more profitable than packaged game sales. EA is projecting 56% of sales to be digital this fiscal year.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz maintained his outperform rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 79 from 74.
"EA put up yet another strong quarter, with top and bottom line upside driven by continued impressive monetization of the company's sports franchises," Creutz said in a note.
EA and other game publishers, such as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), have benefited from the console upgrade cycle hitting the sweet spot.
The installed base of Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 consoles has reached a sufficient level to drive big software sales.

Retail video game sales toss air ball in September

Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) announced Monday that it is joining the esports phenomenon with a tournament around its popular basketball video game "NBA 2K16."Take-Two's move follows even bolder moves by rivals Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA).The Take-Two tournament, called NBA 2K16 Road to the Finals, will begin Feb. 15 in North America with a series of in-game events scheduled through May 8. Winners of those online qualifying events will advance to a single elimination tournament on May 21. The top teams from the tournament will face off for the $250,000 championship in June, while the NBA Finals are taking place.The tournament is accepting “NBA 2K16” players who play the game on either the Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 or Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One.“As the world of competitive gaming continues to evolve, NBA 2K is a natural fit to join the growing landscape,” Alfie Brody, vice president of marketing for NBA 2K, said in a statement. “Our series has long inspired rivalry among gamers, and we’re looking forward to encouraging our fans to enjoy the thrill of competition on a larger scale.”Last week, market research firm Newzoo predicted that global esports revenue will rise 43% this year to $463 million. In 2015, worldwide esports revenue jumped 67% to $325 million.Newzoo projects that esports could generate $1.1 billion in 2019. Esports revenue includes money generated through event tickets, sponsorships, online advertising, media rights and merchandise sales.Competitive gaming this year is expected to entertain an audience of 131 million esports enthusiasts and an additional 125 million occasional viewers who tune in mainly for the big international events, Newzoo said in a blog post. Much of the audience watches online through Amazon.com (AMZN)-owned Twitch or Google's YouTube Gaming, owned by Alphabet (GOOGL).On Dec. 10, Electronic Arts announced the creation of the EA Competitive Gaming Division and reassigned COO Peter Moore to head the unit. The group was set up to hold global esports competitions for its game franchises, including FIFA, Madden NFL and Battlefield.On Oct. 22, Activision announced the creation of a new division devoted to competitive gaming. To lead the esports unit, it tapped Steve Bornstein, former CEO of ESPN and the NFL Network, to serve as chairman, and Mike Sepso, co-founder and former president of Major League Gaming, to be senior vice president.On Jan. 4, Activision acquired the assets of Major League Gaming. It will use MLG as the foundation of its esports broadcast streaming network.On Sept. 24, Time Warner (TWX)-owned Turner Broadcasting System and entertainment firm WME/IMG announced a partnership to create an e-sports competitive gaming league.Last week, Turner and WME/IMG said their esports league, called Eleague, will debut on May 24 with live event coverage featuring Valve’s “Counter-Strike: Global Offensive” from Turner Studios in Atlanta.

Zynga went public in December 2011 at 10 and reached as high as 15.91 in March 2012. It initially rode on the coattails of Facebook (FB), providing games like…

With the holiday shopping season right around the corner, research firm NPD Group is expecting higher sales of video games. "Typically, the fourth quarter of the calendar year represents just over 40% of the year's sales, due to a combination of gifting and great software releases. My expectations are positive for the holiday," NPD video game analyst Liam Callahan wrote in a blog last month.
Higher expectations come despite a lack of new consoles from Microsoft (MSFT), Nintendo (NTDOY) and Sony (SNE). All three last released their latest gaming machines nearly two years ago.
Callahan is predicting that some of the fourth quarter's top-selling game titles will include "Madden NFL 16" and "FIFA 16" from EA Sports, which is a brand from Electronic Arts (EA).

Last week, the Redwood City, Calif.-based game publisher posted better-than-expected fiscal Q2 results. The company earned 65 cents a share, down from 73 cents in the year-earlier period but above views by 20 cents. Sales fell 6% to nearly $1.15 billion vs. views of $1.1 billion.

EA shares cleared a 75.86 buy point from a consolidation Oct. 28 in mildly above-average trade. Volume was only 6% above average that day. Ideally, trade should be at least 40% above average on a breakout from a base.

Callahan's top pick is "Call Of Duty: Black Ops III" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI). Late Monday, the company agreed to buy King Digital Entertainment (KING) for $5.9 billion, making a push into mobile gaming. Ireland-based King is the maker of the widely popular "Candy Crush Saga." King is profitable, but earnings and sales have fallen in recent quarters.
Also late Monday, Activision Blizzard posted third-quarter earnings of 21 cents a share on sales of $1.04 billion. Both were above views.

While Activision Blizzard's stock has had its share of volatility, shares are up more than 40% past a 26.19 buy point in a flat base. The stock touched an all-time high in Thursday's session, even tough the market fell.
Activision Blizzard and Electronic Arts are two of the highest-rated stocks by Composite Rating in the Computer Software-Gaming group. The group ranked No. 11 out of 197 in Thursday's paper.

China's NetEase.com (NTES) is the top-rated stock in the group. It has a Composite Rating of 99, the highest possible. The company holds the license to Activision's "World Of Warcraft" role-playing game in China.
NetEase will report Q3 earnings Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 24% to $1.78 a share. This would mark a third straight double-digit increase for the company.

Thin opening gains firmed in early action Wednesday following a flood of primarily positive economic news. The Nasdaq rolled ahead 0.3%, while the Dow and the S&P 500 held to 0.1% gains.Volume faded about 20% each on the NYSE and the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time on Tuesday.The stock market today launched to a heavy slate of economic news, led by better than expected — or at least as good as expected — October durable goods orders, weekly unemployment claim and personal income numbers.The preliminary services sector estimate from researcher Markit was also positive, with its Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 56.5 for November, up from 54.4 and above economist projections of 55. Employment gains aided the bounce off October's nine-month low, but business confidence remained subdued, the report said.Also above expectation: the Federal Housing Finance Agency's September House Price Index, which leaped 0.8%, up from August's 0.3% rise and vs. consensus projections for an 0.4% rise.New home sales jumped to an annualized rate of 495,000 in October, the Commerce Department reported. The reports also revised September's rate lower, to 447,000. Economist consensus had forecast a November increase to a rate of 499,000 homes sold.The University of Michigan offered the morning's leading down note. The final reading of its November Consumer Sentiment Index dipped to 91.3 — above October's tally of 90 but down from a preliminary November estimate of 93.1 and below views for no change.Oil prices were still down more than 1%, but losses eased a bit on the approach to the Energy Information Administration's 10:30 a.m. weekly report on inventories.Oil-related stocks held eight of the 10 worst losses among S&P 500 companies in early action. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) posted to the worst opening declines on the Dow.In other stocks, nothing runs like a Deere, the ads say, and that was true Wednesday morning as Deere (DE) led the S&P 500 after narrowing a 5% gain to 3%. The agricultural and construction equipment maker reported its fiscal fourth quarter earnings fell less than consensus forecasts. The stock is trying to climb off the floor of a three-month consolidation.Freshly halved PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) dived 13% at the start of trade. IT services and equipment sibling Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) surged 6%. The company late Tuesday reported its last full quarter as a combined outfit, following the Nov. 1 split into separate operations.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) charged ahead almost 4%, continuing its rebound from its week-ago low. The stock is deep in a year-long correction, attempting to retake support at its 10-week moving average.Electronic Arts (EA) jumped 3%, attempting to bounce back from the two-day sell-off that appeared to follow comments from retailer GameStop (GME) that sales of EA's Star Wars Battlefront were weaker than expected.On the IBD 50 list, Euronet Worldwide (EEFT) climbed more than 2% at the start of trade. It put the stock in buying range on a rebound from its 10-week moving average. It is the first test since the ATM and card payment processor broke out above a cup base in September.China-based online game provider NetEase (NTES) added nearly 2%. The stock is working on its seventh straight gain and is extended above a 154.98 buy point.Overseas, Europe's market powered higher following mostly positive U.S. economic news. Benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded higher in afternoon action, led by Frankfurt's DAX, up 1.7%.
Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is satisfying its sweet tooth for acquisitions by buying mobile game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING), best known for "Candy Crush Saga."
Activision announced late Monday that it has agreed to pay $18 in cash per share for London-based King, in a deal worth $5.9 billion. The offer is a 20% premium over King's Friday closing price.
King shares jumped 3.9% to 15.54 on Monday in heavy volume ahead of the acquisition announcement. And King stock was up another 15%, near 18, in early afternoon trading in the stock market today.

Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision plans to fund the deal with $3.6 billion in offshore cash and $2.3 billion in debt financing. Activision ended the third quarter with $4.5 billion in cash and investments, with $870 million held domestically and the rest offshore.

U.S.-based multinational companies are reluctant to repatriate foreign profits because of hefty taxes. U.S. companies bringing home foreign earnings must pay the full U.S. corporate tax rate of 35%, though they get tax credits for payments to foreign governments.
Activision expects the deal to close in spring 2016, subject to approval from government regulators and King shareholders.
Mobile Games Gain

Activision's purchase of King Digital will bolster its position in the fast-growing mobile games market, Activision CEO Bobby Kotick said on a conference call with analysts Tuesday. Activision already is a leader in console and PC video games, with franchises including "Call of Duty," "Skylanders," "Destiny" and "World of Warcraft."

"We think now is the right time to enter mobile gaming in a meaningful way," Kotick said. "Widespread mobile access around the world has opened up significant demand for engaging, fun content that players can enjoy anytime, anywhere."

The mobile games market is worth $36 billion, but it's "extremely fragmented," Kotick said. Other major players include Supercell, Machine Zone, Rovio, Glu Mobile (GLUU), Electronic Arts (EA) and Zynga (ZNGA).

"Acquiring King will solidify Activision Blizzard's position as the world leader in interactive entertainment, positioning the combined company for growth across platforms, audiences, genres and business models," Kotick said.

The acquisition is a "creative, tax-efficient way to use its offshore cash as it enters the fast-growing mobile gaming market in earnest," Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a research report Tuesday. King's sales, however, are declining as its "Candy Crush" franchise matures and as it faces the "daunting task" of trying to replicate that success, Pitz said.
King's revenue has fallen on a year-over-year basis for four straight quarters, and earnings per share have dropped in three of those four quarters.

King is scheduled to report third-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect King to earn 37 cents a share excluding items, down 34% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $455 million, down 13%.
Activision Earnings Rise
Meanwhile, Activision reported Q3 earnings Monday that soundly beat Wall Street's estimates.

Activision earned 21 cents a share excluding items on sales of $1.04 billion in the September quarter. Analysts were looking for EPS of 15 cents on sales of $950 million. On a year-over-year basis, Activision's earnings per share rose 9%, and sales fell 11%.
Analysts are divided on whether Activision got a bargain or overpaid for King.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz called the acquisition "an absolute steal for Activision." The purchase "immediately vaults them to being one of the top mobile gaming companies in the world."

The timing of the sale is puzzling, because King is on the cusp of launching another "Candy Crush" sequel and has three more games in regional testing, including "Farm Heroes," its second-biggest franchise, Creutz said.

"Success by these games could have returned the company to a top-line growth profile, which we think would have reaped benefits for King shares, given the company's inherently high profitability," Creutz said. "We can only surmise that perhaps the management team and key investors were tired of being spurned by the market as a public company and wanted to be able to totally focus on game creation."
Mike Wade, a professor at the IMD business school of Switzerland, said Activision's purchase price overvalues King. "To me, this sounds very expensive," he said in a note.

Activision's purchase of King could pave the way for more mergers and acquisitions in the gaming sector, Mizuho Securities analyst Neil Doshi said in a report. He noted that Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), with $1 billion in cash on hand, could be a buyer.
Evercore ISI analyst Mike Swierczek agreed. Large media conglomerates such as Walt Disney (DIS) and Time Warner (TWX) could be potential acquirers of mobile games companies, he said in a report.

Activision stock was up 7% in afternoon trading, near 37. Glu Mobile stock was up 4.6%, and Zynga added 3%, on speculation that they could be acquisition targets.Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is satisfying its sweet tooth for acquisitions by buying mobile game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING), best known for "Candy Crush Saga."Activision announced late Monday that it has agreed to pay $18 in cash per share for London-based King, in a deal worth $5.9 billion. The offer is a 20% premium over King's Friday closing price.King shares jumped 3.9% to 15.54 on Monday in heavy volume ahead of the acquisition announcement. And King stock was up another 15%, near 18, in early afternoon trading in the stock market today.Santa Monica, Calif.-based Activision plans to fund the deal with $3.6 billion in offshore cash and $2.3 billion in debt financing. Activision ended the third quarter with $4.5 billion in cash and investments, with $870 million held domestically and the rest offshore.U.S.-based multinational companies are reluctant to repatriate foreign profits because of hefty taxes. U.S. companies bringing home foreign earnings must pay the full U.S. corporate tax rate of 35%, though they get tax credits for payments to foreign governments.Activision expects the deal to close in spring 2016, subject to approval from government regulators and King shareholders.Mobile Games GainActivision's purchase of King Digital will bolster its position in the fast-growing mobile games market, Activision CEO Bobby Kotick said on a conference call with analysts Tuesday. Activision already is a leader in console and PC video games, with franchises including "Call of Duty," "Skylanders," "Destiny" and "World of Warcraft.""We think now is the right time to enter mobile gaming in a meaningful way," Kotick said. "Widespread mobile access around the world has opened up significant demand for engaging, fun content that players can enjoy anytime, anywhere."The mobile games market is worth $36 billion, but it's "extremely fragmented," Kotick said. Other major players include Supercell, Machine Zone, Rovio, Glu Mobile (GLUU), Electronic Arts (EA) and Zynga (ZNGA)."Acquiring King will solidify Activision Blizzard's position as the world leader in interactive entertainment, positioning the combined company for growth across platforms, audiences, genres and business models," Kotick said.The acquisition is a "creative, tax-efficient way to use its offshore cash as it enters the fast-growing mobile gaming market in earnest," Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a research report Tuesday. King's sales, however, are declining as its "Candy Crush" franchise matures and as it faces the "daunting task" of trying to replicate that success, Pitz said.King's revenue has fallen on a year-over-year basis for four straight quarters, and earnings per share have dropped in three of those four quarters.King is scheduled to report third-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday. Time Warner (TWX)-owned Turner Broadcasting System plans to bring electronic sports, or e-sports, to primetime cable television next year. Turner and entertainment firm WME/IMG announced Thursday that they have formed a strategic partnership to create an e-sports competitive gaming league. The companies will hold competitive video game events with live fan experiences and televised coverage on TBS and online.
Turner Studios in Atlanta will become the East Coast epicenter for the e-sports league. It will be the headquarters for the new league and primary operations facility for the live gaming experience.
First-person shooter game "Counter-Strike: Global Offensive" from Valve will be the featured game during the league's first season.

TBS will televise the e-sports tournaments on Friday nights for 10 consecutive weeks twice a year, which it described as "the most extensive commitment to televised e-sports programming to date." The tournaments will feature a regular season, playoffs and championship.

"E-sports is one of the fastest growing entertainment genres among young adults around the world," Turner Sports President Lenny Daniels said in a statement. "We're looking forward to creating a tremendous live event atmosphere, leveraging the infrastructure and expertise within Turner Studios, and presenting the competitions in an innovative way throughout our portfolio of leading brands."

Market research firm Newzoo estimates that global e-sports revenue will hit $252 million this year, with a fan base of 113 million enthusiasts. Revenue is forecast to grow 30% year over year in 2015. This revenue includes sponsorships, online advertising, media rights and consumer spending on merchandise and tickets.
Newzoo predicts that e-sports will generate more than $500 million in 2017 and over $1 billion by 2020.

At e-sports tournaments, teams compete in multiplayer video games — usually strategy, shooting or combat games. Top games played include "League of Legends" from Riot Games, majority owned by Tencent Holdings (TCEHY); "Dota 2" from Valve; and "Call of Duty" and "StarCraft 2" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI).
'Call Of Duty' League Debuts
Also Thursday, Activision announced a new e-sports league for its "Call of Duty" game franchise, Call of Duty World League.

Two divisions will comprise the league: the Pro Division for professional players and the Challenge Division for amateurs and aspiring pros. Each will feed into the annual Call of Duty Championship. The Pro Division kicks off competition in January in North America, Europe, and Australia and New Zealand.
The Call of Duty World League will have a prize pool of more than $3 million.

Of all the publicly traded game publishers, Activision is best positioned to capitalize on the e-sports trend, Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a Sept. 17 research report. In addition to its "StarCraft" and "Call of Duty" franchises, Activision's upcoming game "Overwatch" could be a key e-sports title, Pitz said.

The popularity of e-sports led Amazon.com (AMZN) to buy Twitch.tv, a live-streaming platform focused on video games, for $970 million last year. In August, Google (GOOGL) launched YouTube Gaming, a new live-streaming platform with a focus on e-sports and gaming to compete with Twitch.

Stock futures forged higher ahead of Monday's open as the market looked to rebound from Friday's loss.Dow futures traded up 141.4 points. S&P 500 futures were 13 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures held a solid 34.8-point gain.The stock market today heads into the week showing mixed results so far in September. The Nasdaq opens with a 1% gain since the start of the month. The S&P 500 is down 0.7%, and the Dow is off 0.9%. Leading stocks are in somewhat better standing, with the IBD 50 Index ahead 1.9%.The market technically remains in an uptrend, but distribution days climbed last week on both the Nasdaq and S&P 500, placing the uptrend under increasing pressure .Monday's big economic data points come out at 10 a.m. ET, when the National Association of Realtors reports existing home sales and the Atlanta Federal Reserve releases its Business Inflation Expectations index, both for August.Dow stocks were all flat to positive in premarket action. Goldman Sachs (GS), Exxon-Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) rose more than 1% each. More than nine of ten Nasdaq 100 stocks advanced. Kraft-Heinz (KHC) and Electronic Arts (EA) led with 2% gains.Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) climbed 2% before the start of regular trade, after reporting its fiscal third-quarter revenue and earnings easily outpaced consensus estimates. The stock is working to regain its 10-week moving average after stalling out of a breakout attempt above a 54.06 buy point.Smaller peer KB Home (KBH) reports on Thursday.Aerie Pharmaceuticals (AERI) was on the move, up 4%, after posting a 52% home run last week. The Irvine, Calif.-based biotech reported it had initiated the phase three trial of Roclatan, a combination treatment using Aerie's glaucoma treatment Rhopressa. Aerie ended Friday 22% below its April high, and 179% above its October 2013 IPO price.Uniqure (QURE), a thinly-traded biotech based in the Netherlands, spiked 12%. The company announced positive results in a one-year follow-up to phase one and two clinical trials for a treatment of the rare disease Sanfilippo B. Uniqure gained 21% last week, ending just below a 32.32 buy point in a double-bottom base.Overseas, China's markets dived in early trade before an uneven recovery that left the Shanghai Composite up 1.9% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index with a 0.8% loss. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slumped 2%. In Europe, leading indexes were mixed near midday, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 1% and Frankfurt's DAX 0.4% in the red.The dollar rose. Bonds edged lower. Oil bumped up nearly 2% while most other commodities traded narrowly up and down.

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) stock hit an all-time high Thursday after the company announced the successful launch of "Destiny: The Taken King," the latest chapter in the Destiny science-fiction action game saga.Activision shares reached 31.47 on the news Thursday afternoon. The stock was flat, near 31, in afternoon trading on the stock market today."Destiny: The Taken King" broke the record for the most downloaded day-one game in Sony (SNE) PlayStation history. It also set a new day-one franchise benchmark for both total players and peak online concurrency, surpassing the original Destiny launch day last September, which was itself the biggest new video game franchise launch in history."It's safe to say the Destiny franchise continues to gain momentum," Eric Hirshberg, chief executive of Activision Publishing, said in a statement."The Taken King" was made available for digital download for $39.99 starting Tuesday. It also is included on disc from retailers, packaged with the original game and two prior expansion packs, for $59.99 as the "Legendary Edition."The game is available for PlayStation 3 and 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox 360 and Xbox One. But PlayStation users get access to exclusive content such as weapons and armor until at least fall 2016.Digital downloads are becoming increasingly important to game publishers. More gamers are requesting instant access to hot new games. Plus, such downloads carry higher profit margins for publishers.In the June quarter, sales through digital channels accounted for a record 55% of Activision's total revenue.RELATED:'Star Wars' to help 3D cinema leap into hyperspaceEA scores with 'Madden,' but overall game sales sacked.

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and United Continental (UAL) are being added to the S&P 500. They're replacing two buyouts: Pall (PLL) is being acquired by Danaher (DHR), and Hospira (HSP) is being bought by Pfizer (PFE).Here's what you need to know about the two new additions:Activision Blizzard earns a 95 IBD Composite Rating. Earlier this month, the video game publisher reported better-than-expected second-quarter sales and earnings, which shot up 117%.Its big-name games include "Call of Duty," "World of Warcraft" and "Guitar Hero." Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) are two of its peers, and EA is a fellow S&P 500 component.Activision shares gapped up 5.8% in giant volume in the stock market today, shaking off the sell-off and hitting an all-time high of 30 intraday. The stock has risen about 47% this year.United Continental has an 85 IBD Composite Rating. The carrier met analyst expectations when it reported earnings a month ago.The airline industry group has come under pressure lately amid a Justice Department investigation into airfare price collusion.Peers Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) are already members of the S&P 500.United shares popped 6.7% in fast turnover, retaking their 50-day moving average. But the stock is still trading below its 200-day line and is more than 20% below its late January peak.Activision is set to join the index after the close Friday, while United Continental will be added after the close Wednesday.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.
Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus VR is a trailblazer in virtual reality headsets, but next year it's likely to trail in the industry it pioneered, according to a new report.
Samsung's Gear VR and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation VR headsets are poised to outsell Oculus Rift and HTC Vive next year, research firm IHS (IHS) says.

IHS predicts that Alphabet's (GOOGL) low-cost solution, Google Cardboard, will be the top virtual reality platform in 2016, with 30% market share. Google Cardboard is a do-it-yourself virtual reality system that uses smartphones as the display.
The VR systems from Samsung and Sony are seen as tying for second next year, each with 21% market share.
Facebook's Oculus Rift goggles are projected to come in fourth with 8% market share, followed by HTC's Vive with 7%, IHS said.
Sales of virtual reality headsets will reach $1.1 billion in 2016, IHS analyst Piers Harding-Rolls said in a blog post this week. VR headset sales are projected to hit $2.7 billion in 2020, he said.
The worldwide installed base of virtual reality headsets could reach 38 million by the end of 2020, Harding-Rolls said.
The biggest initial application for virtual reality headsets will be video games. IHS is forecasting that VR game sales will total $496 million in 2016.
VR headsets and games were a hot topic at the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles in June.
Not Yet Mass-Market
Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) is cautious on VR games in the near term.
On a conference call with analysts Thursday, EA CEO Andrew Wilson said he believes VR gaming will be big, but says there's work to be done to develop the technology.

"I personally am very bullish on VR, and believe it will be an integral part of our industry and our business on a go-forward basis," Wilson said. "With that said, we don't expect it will have a material revenue impact in the near future. We still think there is work to be done to get to a point where this is really a mass-market consumer proposition."
Sony is making its own headsets for its PlayStation 4 console. Microsoft (MSFT) is supporting Oculus headsets for its games.
The VR headsets from Sony, Oculus and HTC are expected to hit the market in early 2016.

The Samsung Gear VR headset, like Google Cardboard, uses a smartphone for the display, specifically a Samsung Galaxy handset. The $99 Gear VR headset is expected to be available in November. The headset uses technology developed in partnership with Oculus.
Smartphone-based VR headsets like those from Samsung and Alphabet are expected to make up 64% of the installed base of VR headsets in 2016, IHS said.
Another market for virtual reality will be filmed entertainment, analysts say.

GoPro (GPRO) is investing in video equipment and content production for VR entertainment. Studios like Walt Disney (DIS) also are investing in the sector, taking a stake in cinematic virtual reality company Jaunt.Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus VR is a trailblazer in virtual reality headsets, but next year it's likely to trail in the industry it pioneered, according to a new report.Samsung's Gear VR and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation VR headsets are poised to outsell Oculus Rift and HTC Vive next year, research firm IHS (IHS) says.IHS predicts that Alphabet's (GOOGL) low-cost solution, Google Cardboard, will be the top virtual reality platform in 2016, with 30% market share. Early gains deteriorated into narrowly mixed trade early Friday, as investors waded through a welter of mixed earnings reports and economic news.
The Nasdaq inched up 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%, and the S&P 500 backed off 0.2%.
Volume was soft, down 4% on the Nasdaq and 14% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today launched into October's final trading session with the Nasdaq up 9.8% for the month, and the S&P 500 up 8.8%. Both are leaning toward their first monthly advance since July. The gains were on track to be the best month for both indexes since October 2011.

The market took added confidence from weaker-than-expected September personal income and spending numbers, speculating that the data would add to the Fed's reasons to further delay the normalizing of interest rates.
The Labor Department's Labor Cost Index ticked up 0.6% in the third quarter, in line with expectations, as costs accelerated from 0.2% growth in Q2.

Midwest manufacturing returned to expansion mode in October, sending Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index to 56.2, up from 48.7 and well above forecasts for 49.2. A reading above 50 indicates sector growth.

Consumer sentiment eased in October, according to the University of Michigan, which placed its Consumer Sentiment Index at 90 for the month. That was down from September's 92.1 level, disappointing expectations for an uptick to 92.5.
Oil prices traded a fraction higher, lifting West Texas Intermediate to $46.19 a barrel, down about 20 cents on the week. Baker-Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m. E.T.
Stock action was brisk and mixed.

LinkedIn (LNKD) vaulted 11% higher, and Baidu (BIDU) leapt 7% on quarterly results delivered after Thursday's close. Genworth Financial (GNW) dropped 8%, and Electronic Arts (EA) shed 6% on disappointing results.

CVS Health (CVS) fell 6%. The pharmacy giant's Q4 earnings met expectations, as revenue rose a better-than-forecast 10%, and full-year 2015 profit guidance met consensus views, but the 2016 EPS outlook was shy of projections. The big-volume dip dragged shares below their 10-week moving average. The stock is climbing the right side of a three-month consolidation.
Cleveland-based bank KeyCorp (KEY) dropped 6% at the open after announcing it would acquire First Niagara Financial Group (FNFG) in a deal valued at $4.1 billion. First Niagara rose less than 1%.

Gains among IBD 50 stocks were modest in early trade. Cavium (CAVM), Starbucks (SBUX) and Avago Technologies (AVGO) rose more than 1% each. On the downside, egg man Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) saw the deepest decline, down 1%.

On IBD's Big Cap 20 list, Priceline (PCLN) was the early leader. The online travel deals site pulsed up more than 2%, possibly feeling some updraft from peer Expedia (EXPE), which spiked 8% after reporting Q3 results late Thursday. Expedia's results were mixed, but gross bookings rose 21%, driven by hotel bookings and air tickets. The gain easily pushed Priceline to a new high, 4% above a 1394.10 buy point in a cup base. Priceline reports its Q3 results Nov. 9.

Comfort Systems USA (FIX) jetted ahead 14% to lead IBD's Your Weekly Review list. The heating, ventilation and air-conditioning contractor reported late Thursday its third-quarter earnings and revenue clobbered consensus forecasts. The stock had been in a buy range, facing some resistance just above a 29.40 buy point in a double-bottom base. It is now extended and 16% above that buy mark.

At the low end of the Weekly Review list, electronic retail chain Aaron's (AAN) fell more than 4% after a mixed third-quarter report. Earnings missed, and revenue topped the consensus forecast, while management lowered its full-year guidance to well below expectations. The move pulled the stock below its 200-day moving average.Early gains deteriorated into narrowly mixed trade early Friday, as investors waded through a welter of mixed earnings reports and economic news.The Nasdaq inched up 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%, and the S&P 500 backed off 0.2%.Volume was soft, down 4% on the Nasdaq and 14% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.The stock market today launched into October's final trading session with the Nasdaq up 9.8% for the month, and the S&P 500 up 8.8%. Both are leaning toward their first monthly advance since July. The gains were on track to be the best month for both indexes since October 2011.The market took added confidence from weaker-than-expected September personal income and spending numbers, speculating that the data would add to the Fed's reasons to further delay the normalizing of interest rates.The Labor Department's Labor Cost Index ticked up 0.6% in the third quarter, in line with expectations, as costs accelerated from 0.2% growth in Q2.Midwest manufacturing returned to expansion mode in October, sending Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index to 56.2, up from 48.7 and well above forecasts for 49.2. A reading above 50 indicates sector growth.Consumer sentiment eased in October, according to the University of Michigan, which placed its Consumer Sentiment Index at 90 for the month. That was down from September's 92.1 level, disappointing expectations for an uptick to 92.5.Oil prices traded a fraction higher, lifting West Texas Intermediate to $46.19 a barrel, down about 20 cents on the week. Baker-Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m. E.T.Stock action was brisk and mixed.LinkedIn (LNKD) vaulted 11% higher, and Baidu (BIDU) leapt 7% on quarterly results delivered after Thursday's close. Genworth Financial (GNW) dropped 8%, and Electronic Arts (EA) shed 6% on disappointing results.CVS Health (CVS) fell 6%. The pharmacy giant's Q4 earnings met expectations, as revenue rose a better-than-forecast 10%, and full-year 2015 profit guidance met consensus views, but the 2016 EPS outlook was shy of projections. The big-volume dip dragged shares below their 10-week moving average. Stocks wrapped up a busy earnings week on a down note Friday after hovering near the flat line most of the session. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each closed with a 0.5% loss, while the Nasdaq shed 0.4%. Volume was slightly higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq in the stock market today, according to preliminary data. All three indexes ended with fractional gains for the week.

Winners outpaced losers by a 6-5 margin on the NYSE, while decliners edged past advancers on the Nasdaq. Consumer electronics retailers, solar power and alcoholic beverage stocks lagged; transportation, security software and online travel bookers led.

Expedia (EXPE) gapped up 7% to a new high in fast trade. Cantor Fitzgerald and RBC Capital Markets boosted their price targets after the Internet travel agent's Q3 results late Thursday beat views. Priceline Group (PCLN) rose 2%, also a new high. Piper Jaffray reiterated an overweight rating ahead of the travel site's Nov. 9 earnings report.

LinkedIn (LNKD) gapped up and soared 11% in massive turnover, retaking its 200-day moving average for the first time since July 30. The professional-networking website reported Q3 results above forecasts Thursday after the close.

Electronic Arts (EA) fell 5% in fast trade, slipping below a 75.86 buy point it cleared Wednesday. The video game publisher late Thursday reported fiscal Q2 earnings and sales that beat views. Jefferies raised its price target to 95 from 80 and reiterated a buy rating.
EA also boosted its sales forecast for the highly anticipated "Star Wars: Battlefront" video game, which lands Nov. 17.
On the IBD 50 , 23 stocks advanced and 27 fell. Universal Insurance (UVE) staged a bearish reversal and gave up 11% despite reporting better-than-expected Q3 results late Thursday.
Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) led the upside with a 5% jump in heavy volume. The chip designer's shares are still in buy range from a 24.63 cup base entry cleared last week.

Companies reporting quarterly results Monday include Clorox (CLX), Fitbit (FIT) and Visa (V). Key economic data on tap for Monday include October existing-home sales and the Purchasing Managers' Index for November.

Disney (DIS) is making sure fans know these are the droids they're looking for with an epic 18-hour, 12-country event that leads up to the release of its new "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" toys.

The live-streamed event, which Disney is calling "Force Friday," is styled after the immensely popular "unboxing" videos on Google (GOOGL) YouTube that feature people unwrapping new toys. Online talent from Maker Studios, which Disney acquired last year, will be doing the unboxing, starting in Sydney and ending at Lucasfilm in San Francisco. The toys go on sale to the public at midnight on Sept. 4.

In tandem with the event, Target (TGT) launched a new ad campaign called "Share The Force," encouraging fans both young and old to get nostalgic about their favorite characters and toys from the storied film franchise that dates back to 1977. And Wal-Mart (WMT) is reportedly pushing up its holiday layaway program by two weeks in anticipation of the rollout.
Besides action figures and light sabers, fans are also looking forward to the November release of Electronic Arts ' (EA) "Star Wars Battlefront" video game, which is expected to perform well.

All the hubbub is in anticipation of "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," which comes to theatres on Dec. 18. Analysts from Stifel recently estimated the movie will gross $2.2 billion worldwide. For comparison, the last "Star Wars" release, 2005's "Episode III - Revenge of the Sith," grossed over $848 million globally.
Disney shares closed up 3% in the stock market today. Target shares rose 1.3%, and Walmart shares gained 1.9%.

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) leaped to a record high on Wednesday, a day after the video game publisher reported better-than-expected second-quarter sales and earnings.
Activision stock was up 12.1% to 28.77 in late morning trading on the stock market today.

Late Tuesday, the Santa Monica, Calif.-based company said that it had earned 13 cents a share excluding items, up 117% year over year, on sales of $759 million, up 15%, in the second quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Activision to earn 8 cents a share ex items on sales of $666 million.
Activision also raised its full-year outlook.

Like Electronic Arts (EA), Activision has been helped by the shift to digital video game sales. Game publishers make more money from digital sales because it costs less to deliver game software online than through packaged media.

In the second quarter, 80.5% of the company's revenue came from digital sources. Digital includes full game downloads, extra content, mobile games and subscriptions. Activision's digital revenue was up 27% year over year in Q2.
Last week, Electronic Arts said that 77% of its June quarter revenue came from digital sources. EA stock rose 4.6% to 75.12 in late morning trade.

UBS analyst Eric Sheridan reiterated his buy rating on Activision stock and raised his price target to 30 from 28. In a report Tuesday, Sheridan said that he was impressed by Activision's digital sales growth, strong player engagement metrics, and growth in China.
Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson maintained his overweight rating on Activision and upped his price target to 30 from 27.

Activision's guidance for the rest of this year looks conservative, and the company's game slate for 2016 appears very strong, Olson said in a report Wednesday. He noted that Activision's management has historically under-promised and over-delivered.
S&P Capital IQ analyst Scott Kessler on Wednesday reiterated his hold rating on Activision stock, but raised his 12-month price target to 33 from 26.
Baird analyst Colin Sebastian kept his outperform rating on Activision and bumped his price target to 30 from 27.

"Given strength in recurring digital revenue and generally healthy franchise trends, we continue to view Activision as a category leader well-positioned to take advantage of positive industry trends," Sebastian said in a note Wednesday. Those industry trends include the shift to digital sales and the console upgrade cycle.
Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz reiterated his buy rating on Activision and upped his price target to 33 from 26.

Activision is moving from five game franchises (Call of Duty," Skylanders, World of Warcraft, Diablo and StarCraft) to 10 with the addition of Destiny, Hearthstone, Heroes of the Storm, Guitar Hero and Overwatch, Pitz said in a report Wednesday.Activision Blizzard (ATVI) leaped to a record high on Wednesday, a day after the video game publisher reported better-than-expected second-quarter sales and earnings.Activision stock was up 12.1% to 28.77 in late morning trading on the stock market today.Late Tuesday, the Santa Monica, Calif.-based company said that it had earned 13 cents a share excluding items, up 117% year over year, on sales of $759 million, up 15%, in the second quarter. Activision Blizzard (ATVI), the publisher of "Call of Duty" and other hit video game series, late Tuesday crushed Wall Street's second-quarter estimates and raised its full-year outlook.Activision stock was up more than 6% in after-hours trading Tuesday following the earnings release. If that holds in Wednesday's regular session that would mark a new high for Activision stock, which rose a fraction to 25.67 in Tuesday's regular session. Activision stock hit an all-time high of 26.45 on July 21.Activision said it earned 13 cents a share excluding items, up 117% year over year, on sales of $759 million, up 15%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Activision to earn 8 cents a share ex items on sales of $666 million.Activision CEO Bobby Kotick credited strong sales of "Skylanders" and "Call of Duty" games as well as digital titles like "Hearthstone: Heroes of Warcraft" and "Heroes of the Storm."For the September quarter, Activision expects earnings per share of 14 cents ex items on sales of $930 million. Its EPS goal matches Wall Street's target, but its sales goal is ahead of views for $873 million.For the year, Activision raised its EPS goal to $1.30 from $1.20 and its revenue goal to $4.6 billion from $4.43 billion. Both are ahead of views. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were modeling EPS of $1.23 on sales of $4.47 billion."Our strategic focus on expanding our franchise portfolio with captivating and original new intellectual property, innovating on new platforms, and expanding into new geographies is reflected in our results," Kotick said in a statement. "These strong results and the excitement for our future games have driven us to raise our full-year outlook."Major upcoming games for Activision include "Destiny: The Taken King" (Sept. 15), "Skylanders SuperChargers" (Sept. 20), "Guitar Hero Live" (Oct. 20) and "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3" (Nov. 6)."Our audience size and the total amount of time people spend with our franchises continue to grow," Kotick said. "In the second quarter, our monthly active users grew by 35% year over year, and the time our communities spent playing our games grew by 25% year over year."Last week, fellow video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) beat Wall Street's June quarter estimates, but disappointed on guidance for the September quarter and full year.RELATED:Batman drives video game sales higher in June.

BlizzCon is an event held by Blizzard Entertainment, a division of Activision Blizzard. Competitive gaming gets its fair share of criticism, but the industry is expected to reach almost $2 billion…
Sports video games topped another down month for traditional video game sales at U.S. retail stores in September, NPD Group reported late Monday.

Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail stores fell 9% year over year to $1.01 billion. Game hardware sales dropped 27% to $313.5 million. Game software sales dipped 3% to $465.6 million. Game accessories were a bright spot, rising 20% to $230.5 million, NPD said.

Three of the top five best-selling packaged video games were sports titles. Basketball game "NBA 2K16" from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) came in first, followed by football game "Madden NFL 16" from Electronic Arts (EA). "Madden NFL 16" was the top-selling game in August.
"Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain" from Konami Digital Entertainment grabbed third place, followed by soccer game "FIFA 16" from EA and "Destiny: The Taken King" from Activision Blizzard (ATVI).

Leading up to the fourth quarter, year-to-date spending across game hardware, software and accessories was down 1%. But with a strong lineup of software titles, a price cut to Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 console and compelling hardware bundles, NPD is expecting a positive 2015 holiday season, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in statement.
The current generation of video game consoles, led by the PS4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, are outselling the prior generation of game machines, he said.
"After 23 months on the market, combined PS4 and Xbox One sales are 40% higher than the combined 23 month totals for PS3 and Xbox 360," Callahan said.

Gauging the health of the video game industry from retail sales of new packaged software is difficult because the NPD statistics do not account for the growing percentage of game sales coming from digital downloads.
Cowen analyst Doug Creutz sees a turnaround for physical game software sales in October and the holiday shopping season.

"We currently expect a major double-digit increase in physical sales in October, driven by the launches of 'Halo 5' and 'Assassin's Creed: Syndicate' vs. a year-ago comp that included no major non-sports AAA launches," Creutz said in a research report Tuesday. "Currently we expect sales in the holiday window to be roughly flat, with the year finishing in slightly positive territory."

Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report that the installed base of current-generation game systems is now big enough, at about 40 million units, "to drive sustainable software growth on a quarterly basis."Sports video games topped another down month for traditional video game sales at U.S. retail stores in September, NPD Group reported late Monday.Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail stores fell 9% year over year to $1.01 billion. Video game maker Electronic Arts (EA) knocked out Street views by 400% last week when it delivered per-share earnings of 15 cents, above views for 3 cents. Can Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) do the same when they report quarterly results?
Today's Screen of the Day, Estimate Beaters, takes a look at companies that beat earnings estimates by a wide margin.
Activision Blizzard
The publisher behind the "Call of Duty" franchise, "World of Warcraft" and "Guitar Hero," among other titles, reports after the close today, Aug. 4.

Activision's earnings leveled up past analyst estimates by 128.6% in Q1. Adjusted Q2 profit more than doubled to 13 cents a share, beating estimates by 5 cents or 62.5%. Adjusted revenue climbed 15% to $759 million, well above views for $665.5 million.
Shares rose slightly in after-hours trading in the stock market today. The stock broke out of a flat base with 26.19 buy point in mid-July but struggled to remain in buy territory.
The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 90, which means it has outperformed 90% of stocks on a mix of technical and fundamental factors, including earnings and revenue growth.
Take-Two Interactive
Take-Two, which has the "Grand Theft Auto" and "NBA" franchises in its portfolio, beat consensus views by 81.5% in its most recently reported quarter.

When the company reports on Aug. 10, fiscal Q1 results are expected to swing to a profit of 36 cents a share from last year's per-share loss of 14 cents. Revenue is seen jumping 132% to $351.1 million.

The stock, which has a 93 Composite Rating, cleared a 28.82 buy point in late June from a cup-with-handle base, but pulled back to 27.01 before reigniting its climb. Shares were up 1% Tuesday, well above its 50-day line. The stock is now extended past buy range.
Electronic Arts

Fans of video games and Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars" alike are anticipating EA's Nov. 17 release date of "Star Wars Battlefront," which comes about a month before the theatrical release of "Star Wars: Episode VII — The Force Awakens." The game will be available on theSony (SNE) PlayStation 4, the Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One and Origin for PC.
Another big title, "Need for Speed," has a Nov. 3 release.
Shares ticked up 0.5%. The stock has an 88 Composite Rating and has been steadily trading above its 50-day line after finding support in late April.
While it beat estimates by 400%, EA's outlook disappointed.
The company guided for 40 cents EPS on $1.075 billion in revenue for the current quarter, below views for EPS of 67 cents and sales of $1.12 billion.

Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, a unit of Time Warner (TWX), has become a powerhouse in the traditional video game business.

In July, Warner Bros. had the top two best-selling video games at U.S. retail, besting such major publishers as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA). Its family-friendly game "Lego Jurassic World" was No. 1, followed by gritty comic book saga "Batman: Arkham Knight."

Warner Bros. had three titles in the top 10 last month, with "Mortal Kombat X" coming in eighth place, retail tracker NPD Group reported late Thursday. Activision and Electronic Arts each had two games in the top 10 in July, NPD said.
Warner Bros. is the top game publisher year to date, with an increase of more than 200% in dollar sales, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.

July marked the fourth straight month that Warner Bros. has had the top-selling game at U.S. retail. In addition to "Lego Jurassic World," other Warner games that have topped the sales chart this year include "Batman: Arkham Knight," "Mortal Kombat X" and "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt."

The best-selling new game release in July was EA's "Rory McIlroy PGA Tour." It outsold last year's iteration of the pro golfing game, "Tiger Woods PGA Tour 14," by close to 70% in terms of first-month sales, Callahan said. "Rory McIlroy PGA Tour" was the No. 5 best-selling game last month.
Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail rose 6% year over year to $542 million, NPD said.

Game hardware sales were up 2% to $202 million. Game software sales were up a fraction to $178.5 million. Game accessories sales rose 17% to $161 million, boosted by interactive toys and video game point and subscription cards.
Video game companies are benefiting from the console upgrade cycle hitting its sweet spot.

After 21 months on the market, combined unit sales of Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony 's (SNE) PlayStation 4 are nearly 50% higher than the combined sales of the previous-generation consoles, Xbox 360 and PS3, after the same number of months, Callahan said.

Activision hits high score on Q2 beat, guidance.Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, a unit of Time Warner (TWX), has become a powerhouse in the traditional video game business. In July, Warner Bros. had the top two best-selling video games at U.S. retail, besting such major publishers as Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA). Its family-friendly game "Lego Jurassic World" was No. 1, followed by gritty comic book saga "Batman: Arkham Knight."Warner Bros. had three titles in the top 10 last month, with "Mortal Kombat X" coming in eighth place, retail tracker NPD Group reported late Thursday. Activision and Electronic Arts each had two games in the top 10 in July, NPD said.Warner Bros. is the top game publisher year to date, with an increase of more than 200% in dollar sales, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.July marked the fourth straight month that Warner Bros. has had the top-selling game at U.S. retail. In addition to "Lego Jurassic World," other Warner games that have topped the sales chart this year include "Batman: Arkham Knight," "Mortal Kombat X" and "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt."The best-selling new game release in July was EA's "Rory McIlroy PGA Tour." Past the midway point of 2015, the S&P 500 is clinging to just a small gain. Trading has been choppy and lacking sustained rallies, but some segments of the market have still managed to thrive.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, 18 are up 20% or more year to date.Strength has been concentrated in the consumer, building and medical segments of the economy.From the consumer space, gaming software is among the groups topping the list. The group is up 33% in 2015, led by big moves in Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and NetEase (NTES).Apparel, movies, retail Internet, beverages and specialty products groups have also been top performers from the consumer space.From the medical sector, drugs, hospitals, and managed care groups are leading.Ethical and generic-drug makers are up more than 30% each year to date. Horizon Pharma (HZNP), Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) and Allergan (AGN) have been major leaders from these groups.Hospitals, ranked No. 2 in Tuesday's IBD, are also up more than 30% in 2015. The group has six stocks with a 90 or better Composite Rating, led by Adeptus Health (ADPT), a June 2014 IPO. A favorable ObamaCare ruling helped spark the industry this summer.A strong housing market and building recovery have pushed the concrete and aggregates and construction products groups, up about 30% and 25%, respectively.Lighting products supplier and Leaderboard member Acuity Brands (AYI) is up about 50% in 2015.Residential and commercial builders and A/C and heating products groups are also up more than 15% each for the year.

U.S. teens continue to show strong interest in owning the latest generation video game consoles, which bodes well for game publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA), Piper Jaffray said late Tuesday.

In its semiannual teen survey, Piper Jaffray interviewed 9,400 teenagers nationwide, of which more than 7,500 are video game players. Of those video game-playing teens, 73% own a Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One or Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 or intend to get one. That's up from 70% in the spring and 67% in fall 2014.
The survey revealed that 39% now own a PS4 or Xbox One, up from 37% in the spring and 26% last fall.

Uptake of the latest consoles "is at the highest level we have seen, reinforcing our expectation for a much more rapid pace than prior-gen" consoles, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Tuesday. The rising interest in the newest consoles is a "clear positive" for game publishers Activision, EA and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), as well as specialty retailer GameStop (GME), he said.

The current-generation console game cycle will be aided by some highly anticipated games such as Activision's "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," EA's "Star Wars: Battlefront" and Microsoft's "Halo 5: Guardians."

"We believe the combination of next-gen console uptake and a robust lineup of AAA titles will lead to sustainable software growth through second-half 2015 and into 2016," Olson said. He rates the stocks of Activision, EA, Take-Two and GameStop as overweight.

The fall survey found that 61% of teen gamers purchase pre-owned video games, creeping down from 62% in the spring and 63% last fall. GameStop remains the top place to buy used games with 53% share, up from 48% in the spring. Amazon.com (AMZN) is a distant second at 17% share.

However, the used-game market is being affected by the trend toward digital downloads. The fall survey found that 37% of teens said they expect half or more of their video game purchases to be digital, full-game downloads this year, a significant increase from 19% in the spring.
About 79% of teen gamers play games on their smartphones or tablets compared with 81% in the spring and 80% last fall.
While the percentage of mobile gamers is relatively stable, the number who are paying for virtual goods when playing a mobile game has been on the upswing, Piper Jaffray said.

In its survey, 24% of teens who play mobile games said they spend money in game vs. 21% in the spring, 22% last fall and 18% in spring 2014. This is good news for the free-to-play business models of mobile game publishers like Glu Mobile (GLUU) and King Digital Entertainment (KING).

Teens cool with Apple, but with GoPro they can't even
