Video game publishers are starting to benefit from the console upgrade cycle hitting the sweet spot and the shift to digital distribution, investment bank Jefferies said Wednesday.Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said he is broadly positive on the video game sector following the annual E3 trade show last week in Los Angeles.Pitz on Wednesday upgraded his ratings on game publishers Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) to buy from hold. He also has a buy rating on Activision Blizzard (ATVI).Pitz sees "two powerful, multiyear tailwinds" for the sector: faster-than-expected sales of next-generation consoles and the transition to digital distribution and other digital revenue streams.He expects the installed base of the latest consoles, specifically Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, to reach 48 million to 49 million by the end of 2015, two years after they launched. By comparison, it took the previous generation consoles, Sony's PS3 and Microsoft's Xbox 360, 3.5 years to hit the same milestone of roughly 50 million consoles sold, he said.The installed base of current consoles could approach 100 million units by year-end 2017, he said.Another positive for game publishers is the move to digital revenue. Publishers get higher profit margins on games sold as downloads than ones sold as packaged media in retail stores."Today, around 15%-20% of new games are digitally downloaded, up from low single digits two years ago, and up to 40% of catalog titles are downloaded," Pitz said. "We expect the percentage of downloads to continue to rise, and the objections (large file sizes, can't resell a download, some people don't have credit cards) will be resolved over time. This is a very positive trend for publishers given gross margin for digital downloads can be 10 to 20 percentage points higher than retail copies of the same game."Looking at specific publishers, Pitz said EA's multiyear game pipeline is "the best we've ever seen (from the company), starting this holiday with 'Star Wars Battlefront.'"He raised his price target on EA stock to 80 from 58. EA stock was up 1.6%, near 68, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Pitz upped his price target on Take-Two to 35 from 29. Take-Two stock was up more than 2%, near 29, in afternoon trading Wednesday.Pitz has a price target of 26 on Activision. Activision stock was up a fraction near 25.50 in afternoon trading Wednesday.RELATED:E3 2015 Video Game News.

The most heavily traded ETFs have rallied from their early-month lows. PowerShares QQQ (QQQ) is up 3% so far in July, 1.6% in the past month and 7.3% year to date. That compares with iShares Russell 2000's (IWM) gain of 1.5%, 0.6% and 6.3% in those periods and SPDR S&P 500's  (SPY) 2.4%, 0.8% and 3.5%.

QQQ holds $38.78 billion in assets and roughly 100 of the largest nonfinancial stocks in the Nasdaq composite index. The technology sector accounts for more than half its assets. Biotechnology companies get a hefty 11.6% portfolio weighting.

Top-performing holdings in the past three months include Netflix (NFLX), up 49%,Electronic Arts (EA) 28% and Tesla Motors (TSLA) 25%. It also has big stakes in highly rated stocks Facebook (FB), Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), Gilead Sciences (GILD), Starbucks (SBUX) and Celgene (CELG). Each has an IBD Composite Rating of more than 95.

A skew toward the technology sector and large growth stocks has helped QQQ edge out its most actively traded rivals for most of the past 10 years. But its average annual gain of 1.2% over the past 15 years trails 4.2% for SPY and 7.2% for IWM.
Successful investors keep an eye on costs. QQQ has a 0.2% expense ratio — on par with IWM but more than SPY's 0.09%.
Assets in QQQ and SPY have shrunk this year, while IWM has grown a smidge. As of June 30, the three exchange traded funds had leaked more than $50 billion in combined investor outflow.
QQQ rose 0.7% on thestock market today, within grasping distance its old high of 111.16.

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) late Thursday easily beat Wall Street estimates for the June quarter, and it raised its guidance for the full year.But EA stock was down 3% in after-hours trading after the earnings release, as the company's guidance disappointed investors. During the regular session, EA rose a fraction to 72.30. EA shares hit an all-time high of 75.10 on July 21.The Redwood City, Calif.-based company earned 15 cents a share excluding items on sales of $693 million in its fiscal Q1 ended June 30. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 3 cents and $652 million.On a year-over-year basis, EPS fell 21% and sales dropped 11%.EA CFO Blake Jorgensen credited strong catalog game sales and better-than-expected business in digital live service for the Q1 beat.Top-selling games in the quarter included cops-and-robbers shootout game "Battlefield Hardline" and soccer game "FIFA 15."For the current fiscal 2016, EA raised its revenue guidance by $50 million to $4.45 billion and non-GAAP EPS guidance by 10 cents a share to $2.85 a share. Those targets, however, are below where analysts have been forecasting.Wall Street had been modeling EA to earn $2.87 cents a share ex items on sales of $4.48 billion.For the current quarter, EA is targeting EPS of 40 cents a share minus items on sales of $1.075 billion. Both are below Wall Street's outlook, which had been modeling 67 cents and $1.12 billion for the September quarter.Electronic Arts is the first of the three big U.S. independent game publishers to report June-quarter results. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is scheduled to report its second-quarter results on Tuesday. Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) will follow with its fiscal first-quarter results on Aug. 10.The video game software sector ranks No. 10 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. The sector is benefiting from the console upgrade cycle hitting its sweet spot. After a period of investment in new game hardware, gamers are spending their cash on new game software.RELATED:Batman drives video game sales higher in June.
Stocks opened higher and strengthened in Wednesday's early going amid mixed economic data.

The Nasdaq led the pack with a 1% gain while the S&P 500 climbed 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.3% gain, hurt by Walt Disney (DIS), which slumped 9% on late Tuesday's revenue miss. Volume was running higher across the board in the stock market today compared with the same time Tuesday.
In economic news, Markit's service PMI for July rose to 55.7 from 54.8 in June. Views were for 55.2.
The ISM's service gauge jumped to 60.3 in July, easily topping expectations for 56.2.
Earlier, ADP's job report. The stock climbed back above a prior 35.96 buy point from a consolidation intraday.

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) gapped up and rallied 11% after beating views late Tuesday, thanks to strong demand for titles such as "Call of Duty" and "Skylanders." The stock is 8% past a 26.19 buy point from a flat base. It had wavered after initially topping that buy point July 14.
Shares of fellow video gamer maker Electronic Arts (EA) rose 1% in sympathy. Last week, the company delivered quarterly results above views, but gave lackluster guidance.

On the downside, Caesarstone (CSTE) gapped below its 50-day line and plunged 14% after posting disappointing sales and lowering guidance. The Israeli maker of quartz surfaces posted Q2 revenue of $127.5 million, missing views of $134.22 million. Citing weaker-than-expected growth in the U.S. and currency headwinds, the company expects full-year sales of $495 million to $505 million. Previously it expected $515 to $525 million. The stock has erased a 14% gain from a breakout past a 63.05 handle buy point, marking a sell signal.Stocks opened higher and strengthened in Wednesday's early going amid mixed economic data.The Nasdaq led the pack with a 1% gain while the S&P 500 climbed 0.7%. Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) has earned high marks for its latest FIFA soccer game and received a stock price target hike from Piper Jaffray.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson on Wednesday maintained his overweight rating on EA stock, but upped his price target to 86 from 85. EA was up a fraction near 69 in afternoon trading in the stock market today.EA stock hit an all-time high of 75.76 on Aug. 5.On Tuesday, EA released "FIFA 16." The sports title has earned an average Metacritic score of 85, indicating generally favorable reviews, for versions on Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4. Last year's edition, "FIFA 15," received a Metacritic score of 82.Given the larger installed base of latest-generation consoles, sales estimates for EA's "FIFA 16" and "Madden NFL 16" could prove conservative, Olson said in a research note."We believe EA is poised to benefit from continued growth of the hardware installed base with strong titles through the second half of 2016, including 'Star Wars: Battlefront' (Nov. 17 launch) leading the charge," Olson said. "The annual EA Sports lineup got off to a strong start with 'Madden NFL 16,' launched on Aug. 25, which scored an average Metacritic rating of 84, ahead of the prior iteration at 80.5."Like rival Activision Blizzard (ATVI), EA is benefiting from the sweet spot of the console upgrade cycle and the shift to digital downloads.RELATED:Activision Blizzard resets after hitting record high.

Stocks rebounded in late trading to end with nice gains Wednesday. Equities had briefly turned negative after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady but left the door open for a rate hike in December.The Nasdaq rallied 1.3%, and the S&P 500 climbed 1.2%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.1%. The small-cap Russell 2000 surged 2.9% Wednesday after lagging in recent sessions. According to preliminary data, volume rose on both major exchanges in the stock market today.After the close, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) tumbled 10% after posting disappointing quarterly results. The company reported EPS of $1 on sales of $455.5 million. Views were for $1.29 on revenue of $464.99 million.In the regular session, top-rated stock Ultimate Software (ULTI) ended off its session high but still rallied more than 7% following better-than-expected Q3 earnings from late Tuesday. The stock ended 7% past a 189.31 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Apple (AAPL) climbed 4% in reaction to late Tuesday's fiscal Q4 results. But the stock is still below its 200-day line as a potential base forms.On the downside, Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) slumped almost 11% in heavy trade, giving back all of Tuesday's gains and then some. The stock also sliced its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Before then open, the drugstore giant reported fiscal Q4 earnings that topped views, but it trimmed the upper end of its 2016 earnings guidance.Also, Moody's Investors Service placed Walgreens on review for a credit downgrade as a result of the deal to buy rival Rite Aid (RAD) for $17.2 billion.Aetna (AET), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Altria Group (MO), Baidu (BIDU), CME Group (CME), Electronic Arts (EA), Expedia (EXPE), MasterCard (MA), SolarCity (SCTY) and Starbucks (SBUX) are some notable companies reporting earnings Thursday.Data on the third-quarter GDP and weekly jobless claims will also be out Thursday.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

Ixia (XXIA) helps businesses and governments run smoothly operating secure networks. The Calabasas, Calif.-based company, which is pronounced x-ea, works behind the scenes as enterprises design, roll out, upgrade and operate their systems, so that customers get the experience they expect, whether they are shopping, banking or conducting other business.Its products validate, test and provide security for global companies.Security has become a prime concern after several enterprises, including Sony (SNE), Home Depot (HD), Target (TGT) and the U.S. government have been embarrassingly hacked in recent months.Earlier this month, Ixia released its latest product, ThreatARMOR, which provides security against hackers. The company says it works by reducing the ever-increasing "attack surface," which is the sum of all the access avenues an individual can use to get into a network.It counts among its customers 74 Fortune 100 companies and all 15 of the top global network equipment manufacturers.Since coming public in October 2000, the stock has had a volatile history. Earnings have been cyclical.EPS fell from 73 cents a share in 2013 to 36 cents a share last year, and 2014 revenue was flat.Analysts at Wunderlich downgraded the stock Oct. 19 from buy to hold on worries that Brocade Communications (BRCD) might take some of Ixia's business with AT&T; (T). But earnings forecasts were unchanged.When the company reports Q3 results after the close on Tuesday, the Street is expecting a profit of 13 cents a share, which would be a 44% increase from a year earlier.The stock appears to be building a flat base with a 16.15 buy point.

EA showed off gameplay footage for the first time at its press conference Monday.
EA shares rose 2.1% to 62.86 in the stock market today. Disney shares climbed 0.8%.

E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends
LOS ANGELES — Electronic Arts (EA) is going full force into "Star Wars" video games, leveraging its licensing deal with Walt Disney (DIS).

At a pre-E3 media event Monday, EA showed game footage from its upcoming game "Star Wars Battlefront" for the first time. The response from the game press was rapturous, with many in attendance jumping up and down and cheering.
"It's the year of 'Star Wars' at EA with games for console, PC and mobile," EA CEO Andrew Wilson said.

In addition to "Star Wars Battlefront" for the latest consoles, EA also showed off an expansion pack for its online PC game "Star Wars: The Old Republic" called "Knights of the Fallen Empire," plus a new mobile game called "Star Wars: Galaxy of Heroes."
But it was "Star Wars Battlefront" that had E3 gamers practically in tears of excitement.
"We're bringing a galaxy far, far away to life as never before," said EA Chief Operating Officer Peter Moore. "This game was made by developers who love 'Star Wars' for fans who love 'Star Wars.'"

The game footage at E3 depicted the battle of Hoth from "The Empire Strikes Back." It featured a light saber duel on the ice planet between Luke Skywalker and Darth Vader, something that didn't happen in the movie.

The games seek to capitalize on "Star Wars" mania, with a new Disney movie out late this year.E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & TrendsLOS ANGELES — Electronic Arts (EA) is going full force into "Star Wars" video games, leveraging its licensing deal with Walt Disney (DIS).At a pre-E3 media event Monday, EA showed game footage from its upcoming game "Star Wars Battlefront" for the first time. E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends

LOS ANGELES — With the video game console upgrade cycle in the sweet spot, Microsoft (MSFT) has decided to bring out the big guns — new games from its best-selling franchises including "Halo" and "Gears of War."
At a media event Monday on the eve of the annual E3 video game show, Microsoft showed game footage from a host of exclusives for its Xbox One console.
They include "Halo 5: Guardians," the latest in its popular science-fiction action series, and "Gears of War 4," a gritty sci-fi combat series.
Others are racing game "Forza Motorsport 6" and fantasy game "Fable Legends."
Exclusives are hugely important for console makers Microsoft, Nintendo (NTDOY) and Sony (SNE) because they can drive console sales and increase their installed base.
"Investing in and shipping new and exclusive franchises is critical to our success," said Phil Spencer, head of Microsoft's Xbox business.

Microsoft's announcements set up a busy holiday season for game publishers. On Sunday, Bethesda Softworks said its highly anticipated "Fallout 4" will be released Nov. 10 for Sony's PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's Xbox One and Windows PCs.

Microsoft's "Forza Motorsport" is set for release on Sept. 15. "Halo 5" is due out Oct. 27. Another Xbox One exclusive, the Lara Croft adventure "Rise of the Tomb Raider," is scheduled for a holiday release.
The biggest applause at Microsoft's event was when the company announced that Xbox One is being made backwards compatible for older Xbox 360 games.

Making the Xbox One console backwards compatible wasn't easy, but it was the most-asked-for feature by gamers, Spencer said. It will greatly expand the number of games available for play on the Xbox One.
Plus, owners of both the Xbox One and Xbox 360 can finally get rid of the older console.
Coincidentally, this situation was the subject of a satirical article last week by the Onion titled "Report: More U.S. Families Living With Multiple Generations Of Xbox Under One Roof."
The Electronic Entertainment Expo runs Tuesday through Thursday.

Electronic Arts (EA), Ubisoft and Sony also had media briefings set for Monday.E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & TrendsLOS ANGELES — With the video game console upgrade cycle in the sweet spot, Microsoft (MSFT) has decided to bring out the big guns — new games from its best-selling franchises including "Halo" and "Gears of War."At a media event Monday on the eve of the annual E3 video game show, Microsoft showed game footage from a host of exclusives for its Xbox One console.They include "Halo 5: Guardians," the latest in its popular science-fiction action series, and "Gears of War 4," a gritty sci-fi combat series.Others are racing game "Forza Motorsport 6" and fantasy game "Fable Legends."Exclusives are hugely important for console makers Microsoft, Nintendo (NTDOY) and Sony (SNE) because they can drive console sales and increase their installed base."Investing in and shipping new and exclusive franchises is critical to our success," said Phil Spencer, head of Microsoft's Xbox business.Microsoft's announcements set up a busy holiday season for game publishers. On Sunday, Bethesda Softworks said its highly anticipated "Fallout 4" will be released Nov. 10 for Sony's PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's Xbox One and Windows PCs.Microsoft's "Forza Motorsport" is set for release on Sept. 15. Walt Disney (DIS) stock hit an all-time high Monday, even as the Mouse's sales and earnings growth is expected to slow down when it reports Tuesday after the close. Revenue is seen rising 6.1% to $13.23 billion, which would mark the second straight quarter of deceleration from 7% and 9% growth in previous quarters. Wall Street predicts third-quarter earnings will…

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA), which just released the pro golf game "Rory McIlroy PGA Tour," might want to take a mulligan on its guidance.Late Thursday, the Redwood City, Calif.-based company reported June-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street estimates, but gave September-quarter and full-year guidance that lagged views.For its fiscal first quarter, which ended June 30, EA earned 15 cents a share, excluding items, on sales of $693 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 3 cents EPS and $652 million in revenue.For the current quarter, EA is targeting earnings of 40 cents a share minus items on sales of $1.075 billion. Wall Street had been modeling 67 cents and $1.12 billion.For the current fiscal 2016, EA is looking for earnings of $2.85 a share ex items on sales of $4.45 billion. Wall Street was targeting $2.87 cents and $4.48 billion.EA stock was down 1.5%, near 71, in midday trading on the stock market today. EA stock hit an all-time high of 75.10 on July 21.Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter remains bullish on EA. He rates the stock outperform, with a 12-month price target of 84."EA has now delivered EPS and revenue beats relative to consensus for nine and six consecutive quarters, respectively," Pachter said in a research report Thursday. "This practice makes it easy for investors to conclude that guidance for fiscal year 2016 is overly conservative."Fiscal Q3 estimates are too conservative, given the high-profile releases of "Need for Speed" (due out Nov. 3) and "Star Wars Battlefront" (Nov. 17), Pachter said.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson also says that EA is being conservative. In a note Friday, Olson said that EA is positioned to benefit from the continued strong uptake of next-generation game consoles, including Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One.EA has a "strong pipeline" of games for the next two years, he said.Olson maintained his overweight rating on EA stock and price target of 79.Though EA management is conservative in its guidance, the June-quarter report was its first Q1 in 15 years that EA raised its full-year outlook, Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a note Friday.Pitz rates EA stock a buy, with a price target of 80.

The most-anticipated multiplatform video game this holiday season is Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) military shooter game "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," according to a survey by Nielsen (NLSN)."Black Ops 3" is tops on the Nielsen Game Rank study, with a rating of 98%. The latest game in the popular "Call of Duty" franchise is due out Nov. 6 for Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Xbox 360 consoles, Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and PS3, and Windows PCs.Nielsen Game Rank measured overall anticipation levels among gamers for games being released in October through December. The research firm polled more than 4,800 gamers in August and September about their awareness, purchase intent and other factors for new games.Games are given a percent value that reflects how strong the overall anticipation level is for the title, relative to the pre-release anticipation levels of all previous titles that released on the platform or platforms."Fallout 4" from Bethesda Softworks and "Assassin's Creed: Syndicate" from Ubisoft tied for second among multiplatform titles with an anticipation rating of 95% each. Racing game "Need for Speed" from Electronic Arts (EA) came in fourth with 92%. EA's "Star Wars: Battlefront" was fifth with 88%.Some games are exclusive to individual consoles.The top exclusive title for the Xbox One is Microsoft's "Halo 5: Guardians" with a rating of 100%, Nielsen said in a report Monday.Sony's "Uncharted: The Nathan Drake Collection" is the top exclusive for the PS4 this holiday season, with a ranking of 79%.Nintendo's "Yoshi's Woolly World" is the top exclusive for the Nintendo Wii U console, with a 91% rating, Nielsen said.RELATED:Activision aims to slay rivals with 'Black Ops 3'Time Warner, Activision betting on e-sports growth.

After hitting a record high on Monday, video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) hit the pause button Tuesday. Activision stock was down a fraction in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Its shares hit an all-time high of 31.65 on Monday.
Year to date, Activision stock is up 56%.

The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company is benefiting from the sweet spot of the console upgrade cycle and the shift to digital downloads. These trends have lifted other major game publishers as well, including Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).
IBD's Computer Software-Gaming sector ranks No. 22 out of 197 industry groups.
Last week, Activision announced the successful launch of "Destiny: The Taken King," the latest chapter in the "Destiny" science-fiction game saga.
Up next for Activision is the release of "Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 5," the first game in the skateboarding franchise in eight years. It is set for release on Sept. 29.

The reviews for "Pro Skater 5" aren't out yet, but Forbes contributing writer Paul Tassi said the game preview videos are worrisome. "I've just never seen a promotional campaign for a game to make something look this bad," he wrote.
Activision's biggest upcoming game title is "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3." The first-person shooter game is set for release on Nov. 6.
Baird analyst Colin Sebastian on Tuesday reiterated his outperform rating on Activision stock and raised his price target to 36 from 30.

"Overall, we remain positive, with a successful launch of the Destiny expansion pack, a stronger 2016 product slate, and opportunities for incremental growth in 2017 and beyond," Sebastian said in a research note.

E-sports and other emerging business areas could provide expanded opportunities for Activision, he said. The other areas include mobile and free-to-play games, digital content sales and virtual reality games.
E-sports could become a meaningful revenue contributor within two to three years, he said.

Virtual reality should start to gain consumer adoption in 2016, Sebastian said. Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus, Sony (SNE) PlayStation and other companies are aggressively pursuing the VR hardware market.

Disney Joins Google, Facebook In Virtual Reality Wars
Virtual Reality Games Face Real Market Challenges

Electronic Arts (EA) scored with "Madden NFL 16" in August, but overall video game sales were tackled for a loss last month.

This year's Madden pro football game, released on Aug. 25, was the top-selling video game at U.S. retail stores in August, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. It was followed by Microsoft 's (MSFT) "Minecraft" and "Gears of War: Ultimate Edition" in second and third places, respectively.
Overall sales of video game hardware, software and accessories dipped 2% year over year to $548 million, NPD said.
Sales of new, packaged game software dropped 10% to $208 million. Game console sales slid 2% to $191 million. Game accessory sales were a bright spot, rising 12% to $150 million, NPD said.

Sales of game software for the current generation of consoles, including Microsoft's Xbox One and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4, were up 34%, but couldn't offset the decline in portable and older generation console game sales, NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.
Current (eighth generation) consoles represented 68% of software sales in August, compared with 61% of sales in July, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Friday.

The installed base of current-generation consoles (about 40 million units) "is now large enough to drive sustainable software growth," he said. "We expect that 2015 and 2016 will be the equivalent to 2007 and 2008 during the prior console cycle; both were years that experienced significant industry software growth, following several years of decline or limited growth in the space."
Olson reiterated his overweight ratings on game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI), EA and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), and specialty retailer GameStop (GME).

The decline in overall game product sales at retail in August followed two months of increased sales on a year-over-year basis. NPD's figures include only new physical-game sales. They don't include digital sales, such as game downloads, smartphone games and subscriptions, or used-game sales and rentals.
For that reason, it's getting tough to gauge the health of the video game industry from the NPD figures, Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said in a report Friday.

Retail sales of the latest Madden game were down roughly 10% from the comparable five-day sales window last year, Creutz said. But the percentage of Madden units sold digitally is increasing, possibly offsetting the retail decline, he said.
Creutz maintained his outperform ratings on Activision, EA and Take-Two.

After boosting the fortunes of toy companies and video game makers, the "Star Wars" effect is next poised to benefit 3-D cinema firms.Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" opens in theaters on Dec. 18. It is one of a cluster of high-profile movies being released on 3-D screens this holiday season.RealD (RLD), which makes 3-D cinema technology, recently showed off a special edition series of Star Wars-themed 3-D glasses that moviegoers can get for the new flick. They come in four designs based on characters in the movie, from Stormtrooper to droid BB-8.Movie theaters will see the widest selection of 3-D movies ever this fall and holiday season, according to the Advanced Imaging Society in Hollywood. In all, 11 major studio drama, action/adventure, and animated feature films are set to be released starting Friday with Universal Studios' adventure thriller "Everest.""We have never seen so many major directors unveiling major 3D movies in so many genres," Advanced Imaging Society President Jim Chabin said in a statement.In addition to "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," from director J.J. Abrams, the 3-D movie lineup includes "The Walk," directed by Robert Zemeckis; "The Martian," directed by Ridley Scott; "Pan," directed by Joe Wright; "In the Heart of the Sea," directed by Ron Howard; and the finale to "The Hunger Games" series, "Mockingjay, Part 2," directed by Francis Lawrence.Two major animated releases coming this season are "The Peanuts Movie" from DreamWorks Animation (DWA) and "The Good Dinosaur" from Disney's Pixar Animation Studios."These are movies that were conceived and designed to be seen in 3D from some of Hollywood's greatest directors," Chabin said. "From now through the holiday season they are going to wow audiences of all ages and make us all feel like kids again."Certainly the first new "Star Wars" movie in over 10 years is making a lot of kids and adults alike excited. Witness the frenzy around the launch earlier this month of the first toys based on "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." Retailers turned the toy launch into an event called Force Friday on Sept. 4.Hasbro (HAS), Mattel (MAT) and Lego Group are among the companies selling Star Wars-branded merchandise.Also benefiting from the renewed excitement around Star Wars is video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA), which is scheduled to release its highly anticipated game "Star Wars: Battlefront" on Nov. 17.In addition to "Star Wars: Battlefront," Electronic Arts is working on an expansion pack for its online PC game "Star Wars: The Old Republic" called "Knights of the Fallen Empire," plus a new mobile game called "Star Wars: Galaxy of Heroes."
E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends
LOS ANGELES — Bethesda Softworks threw red meat to its legions of hard-core gamers with its first ever E3 showcase event on Sunday evening.
The privately held game developer showed off the latest games in its popular "Doom" and "Fallout" franchises to the whoops and hollers of enthusiasts at the Dolby Theater in Hollywood.

Bethesda, based in Bethesda, Md., and owned by ZeniMax Media, kicked off a week of events around the annual Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles. E3, which officially runs Tuesday through Thursday, is expected to attract about 50,000 video game industry professionals and journalists.

The highlight of the Bethesda event was "Fallout 4," set for release on Nov. 10. It's the latest in the post-apocalyptic retro-future action franchise. It will be playable on Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Windows PCs.
It also announced a companion smartphone app for Apple (AAPL) iOS and Google (GOOGL) Android handsets.
Bethesda announced a new version of "Doom," the science-fiction horror game known for, as spokesman Pete Hines put it, "bad-ass demons" and "big f-ing guns."
Demo videos of the violent shooter game showed the protagonist killing demons with guns, a chain saw and his bare hands.
"Doom" is set for release in spring 2016 for Sony PS4, Microsoft Xbox One and PCs.
Bethesda got a jump on rivals with its preshow event. Microsoft, Electronic Arts (EA), Ubisoft and Sony were holding events Monday.

Facebook (FB), Microsoft (MSFT), Sony (SNE), Activision (ATVI), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) and Electronic Arts (EA) are just a few publicly traded companies that have big things planned to…

Video game retailer GameStop (GME) crushed Wall Street's Q1 estimates and ripped out its still-beating heart in triumph late Thursday, thanks to hit titles like ultra-violent fighting game "Mortal Kombat X."
GameStop stock jumped 6% to 43 in morning trading on the stock market today.

The Grapevine, Texas-based retailer earned 68 cents a share, up 15% year over year, on sales of $2.06 billion, up 3%, for the quarter ended May 2. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected GameStop to earn 59 cents a share on sales of $2.01 billion.
Same-store sales rose 8.6% in fiscal Q1, compared with 5.8% in the year-earlier period.
GameStop said its software sales were helped by hot games like "Mortal Kombat X" from Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment and "Battlefield Hardline" from Electronic Arts (EA).
For the current quarter, GameStop expects to earn 23 cents a share, up 5%, based on the midpoint of its guidance, with same-store sales flat to up 3%.

For the full year, GameStop raised its EPS guidance range to $3.63 to $3.83 from its previously announced range of $3.60 to $3.80 to account for the reduction in shares outstanding. It still expects full-year comparable store sales to rise 1% to 6%.

GameStop operates more than 6,700 stores across 14 countries. In addition to GameStop stores, it runs Simply Mac stores, which sell Apple (AAPL) products, and Spring Mobile stores, which sell AT&T (T) wireless products and services.
GameStop's performance was helped by conservative guidance and stock buybacks, which lifted earnings per share, Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey said in a research note Friday.

GameStop is facing "massive pessimism" with short interest at 47%, said Janney Capital Markets analyst Tony Wible. GameStop is the most shorted name in the S&P 500, he said in a note Friday. Critics say GameStop's physical game software sales are being undermined by growing digital downloads of full games.

Wible rates GameStop stock as a buy and raised his price target to 46 from 42. He is bullish on GameStop because of the console upgrade cycle and new business opportunities in selling Apple iDevices and digital game content.

GameStop is benefiting from a "renewed growth phase" in the video game industry, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a report Friday. This phase is being driven by the console upgrade cycle as more gamers switch to the latest living-room consoles such as Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One.
Olson rates GameStop stock as overweight with a price target of 47.

"While those negative on GME will point to digital disintermediation as the source of potential pre-owned weakness, we believe GameStop is strategically positioned to capture industrywide growth in new and pre-owned software & hardware," Olson said. "The footprint of next-gen consoles continues to outpace its predecessor, which we believe bodes well for accompanying software sales (new and pre-owned) in the coming quarters."
The console upgrade cycle also is boosting the fortunes of game publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO).
Baird analyst Colin Sebastian believes GameStop's momentum will continue this year.

"While the company's long-term position remains under scrutiny given the inevitable shift of media consumption online, we believe the company should benefit from a high-quality lineup of core games coinciding with the next-generation console cycle, and positive comp store sales continuing through 2015," Sebastian said in a note Friday.

A late rebound helped the broad averages turn big losses into small gains Thursday. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%, while the Nasdaq edged up 0.1%. They were off by as much as 1% and 1.3%, respectively, at Thursday's lows. The 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. According to preliminary data, volume ended mixed in the stock market today. NYSE trade rose and Nasdaq volume fell.

Among leading stocks, thinly traded Tyler Technologies (TYL) surged 10% to an all-time high in fast trade. The Plano, Texas-based IT software and services provider announced it was buying privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock. Tyler is featured in the latest New Highs column.

Verisk Analytics (VRSK) gapped above its 50-day line and rallied nearly 6% in huge turnover. The provider of actuarial and underwriting data to insurers will be joining the S&P 500 index after the close on Oct. 7. Verisk is shaping a flat base with a 79.98 buy point.
On the downside, Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) gapped down and dived 11% on expectations of weak comp sales and news of store closings.

Spice maker McCormick & Co. (MKC) took heat after reporting disappointing Q3 earnings. The stock tumbled 4% but trimmed losses after finding support at its 200-day moving average. The stock is working on a base.

Electronic Arts (EA) saw its stock hit a record high on Tuesday after receiving a price target bump from investment bank UBS. EA stock closed at 69.89, up 2.8%, and earlier rose as high as 69.95.UBS analyst Eric Sheridan said EA stock still has room to run despite rising 45% this year through Monday. He upgraded his rating on EA stock to buy from neutral and raised his 12-month price target to 80 from 65."Over the past several quarters, EA's management has delivered a series of upside surprises on both top and bottom lines driven by strong title performance, higher gross margins from digital sales (led by growth in extra content, free-to-play and mobile gaming), and cost efficiencies," Sheridan said in a research report Tuesday. "Despite the rise in EA shares during this time, we see continued runway for outperformance."Sheridan pointed to EA's upcoming video game slate, including "Star Wars: Battlefront"; its continued mix shift toward digital sales; mobile gaming traction; continued focus on cost discipline; and the possibility for more share repurchases.He expects that EA will sell 12 million to 14 million units of "Star Wars: Battlefront," compared with management's guidance of 9 million to 10 million units. The game is set for release on Nov. 17.EA and other video game publishers are benefiting from the sweet spot of the current console cycle.Activision Blizzard (ATVI) late Monday received a price target hike from Pacific Crest Securities.Pacific Crest analyst Evan Wilson reiterated his overweight rating on Activision stock and raised his price target to 30 from 25.Activision stock rose 1% to 25.05 on Tuesday. It hit a record high of 26.09 on June 4.Wilson said he is more positive on Activision's game slate after the E3 video game conference in Los Angeles last month."We believe Activision is set up in 2016 for the most profitable first half in company history, which makes the full year more profitable than our prior view," Wilson said. "We expect the next 'StarCraft 2' expansion in March, the next 'World of Warcraft' expansion (tied to the 'Warcraft' movie) in early June and 'Overwatch' commercial release in late June. Three Blizzard releases (with only modest capitalized software), combined with potential high-margin growth from 'Hearthstone,' 'Heroes of the Storm' and 'Call of Duty' in China, could lead to a very big earnings number."Wilson is modeling for the release of "Destiny 2" in September 2016. He expects the sci-fi action-game sequel to be more profitable than the original game.RELATED:Demi Lovato plans to give video games a 'Heart Attack'E3 winners and losers: Wall Street edition.

Stock futures were up and steady en route to Wednesday's opening bell, continuing a positive feedback loop between U.S. and overseas markets.Dow futures punched 149.3 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures traded up 46.2 points and S&P 500 futures showed a straight and even 17.3-point gain.

The stock market today rides the heels of Tuesday's bullish rebound, as well as a wild session overseas that saw Tokyo's Nikkei 225 spike 7.7% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index seize a 4.1% gain. Tokyo's jump, its biggest single-day surge since 2008, followed a 2.4% drop on Tuesday that left the index flat for the year.

But Prime Minister Shinzo Abe told a group of investors he aimed to lower Japan's corporate tax rate by at least 3.3% next year. That, and a rise by the dollar vs. the yen, boosted investor confidence.
Markets in Europe caught the mood, with the major indexes up between 1.5% and 2.5% near midday.
U.S. markets open with more breathing room after Tuesday's rally, and growth investors find stocks on their watch lists passing valid buy points are now in play.

Economic news is on the thin side today, with investors looking toward Friday's Producer Price Index numbers from the Labor Department and, more significantly, next week's rate policy decision from the Federal Reserve.
Mortgage applications declined 6.2% during the week, led by a 10% fall in refinancing applications, as interest rates edged slightly higher, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.
The Labor Department reports its July Job Opening and Labor Turnover Survey at 10 a.m. ET.
In stocks, UnitedHealth (UNH), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Boeing (BA) were pushing premarket gains near 2%. On the Nasdaq 100, Electronic Arts (EA), JD.com (JD) and Intuit (INTU) were up almost 3% each.

Earnings news sent Dave & Buster's (PLAY) up 9% and poised the 11-month-old stock to open at a new high (premarket gains often do not continue into regular trade). Beaumont, Texas-based retailer Conn's (CONN) surged 7% ahead of the open. Pacific Sunwear (PSUN) got burned by an across-the-board weak Q2 report, falling 15% in premarket trade.

Among leaders, Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP) led the IBD 50 list, up nearly 3% before the open. The Bethesda, Md.-based biotech is extended above a 22.10 buy point, but struggling to rebound from a test of 10-week support.

Ellie Mae (ELLI) climbed 2% before the bell. The gain put the provider of professional electronic mortgage services in place to open back above its 50-day moving average, in the fourth week of a 20% deep consolidation.

In other markets, the dollar eased against the euro and jumped vs. the yen. Oil shed 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate above $45 a barrel and Brent crude at $49. Gold inched back to $1,119 an ounce. Among the more curious items seized from the Pakistani compound of Islamic terrorist Osama bin Laden was a strategy guide to the first-person shooter video game "Delta Force Xtreme 2."The guide to the 2009 military combat game for Microsoft (MSFT) Windows PCs was among the trove of documents recovered during the raid in which U.S. Special Forces killed bin Laden on May 2, 2011. The video game guide was disclosed in the latest tranche of declassified documents that the U.S. Office of the Director of National Intelligence released Wednesday.The "Delta Force Xtreme 2" guide, as well as a "GameSpot Video Game Guide," were listed under a category suggesting that compound residents other than bin Laden used them.The discovery of the guide raises some interesting questions. Did bin Laden and his cohorts use the game and the guide for training purposes or to study U.S. combat strategy? Or was it simply entertainment at the isolated compound?The idea of al-Qaida terrorists playing a video game in which the elite U.S. Army squad Delta Force are the heroes is odd. U.S. Navy SEALs in an operation carried out by the CIA killed Bin Laden and his crew.Privately held NovaLogic, which counts Electronic Arts (EA) as an investor, made "Delta Force Xtreme 2." The game scored poorly with game critics, getting a Metacritic rating of 40 out of 100. The plot of the game has Delta Force soldiers sent to Asia to bring a drug cartel and former Soviet mercenaries to justice.The Navy Seal raid also scooped up a library of software and technical manuals, most notably Adobe Systems (ADBE) media creation software. Bin Laden's bookshelf included manuals on Adobe Acrobat, Dreamweaver, Encore, Photoshop and Premiere Pro.

Casual video game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING) lost an alarming number of paying customers in the first quarter, which likely impacted its weak second-quarter guidance.King stock fell as much as 8% on Friday after the company posted first-quarter results that beat views; it had given disappointing Q2 guidance late Thursday. But King stock recovered to close up a fraction, near 15, on the stock market today.King, best known as the maker of "Candy Crush," said that it had 364 million unique monthly active users in Q1, up from 352 million in Q1 2014. Wall Street was modeling for 346 million unique monthly users.But the number of paying customers dipped 29% to 8.5 million from 11.9 million a year earlier. And the number is forecast to decline again in Q2.King competes in the mobile and casual games sector with companies like Electronic Arts (EA), Glu Mobile (GLUU), Kabam, Supercell and Zynga (ZNGA).King's paying users are spending more, helping to offset the decline in paying players. Monthly gross average bookings per paying user rose to $23.64 from $18.02 in the first quarter last year."The trend toward a smaller base of payers, with each payer paying more on average, continues," Deutsche Bank analyst Lloyd Walmsley said in a research note Thursday. "We would prefer to see the company expand its base of payers vs. squeezing more money out of a shrinking base."King uses a free-to-play or "freemium" business model. People can play its mobile and Web-based games for free and buy extras to enhance the experience.Price Targets CutAt least two analysts cut their price targets on King stock after the Q1 report.Walmsley reiterated his hold rating on King stock and slashed his price target to 16 from 21.King badly needs another hit game, he said. All of the company's games are in decline, including its last hit, "Candy Crush Soda Saga," he said."The company has yet to see sustained success for titles that don't begin with 'Candy Crush' at anywhere near the gross bookings levels of that franchise," Walmsley said.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney maintained his sector perform rating on King stock but cut his price target to 17 from 20."For us to become constructive on the stock, we would need to see stable trends showing bookings growth AND diversification away from 'Candy Crush' — which likely isn't attainable until 2016," Mahaney said in a note Friday.A hit game beyond "Candy Crush" is essential for the stock to move higher, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson said in a note Thursday. But making a hit is no easy task."Mobile game developers initially rely on a key franchise or genre, and diversification has been a rare occurrence," Wilson said. "We are not sure King is going to buck the trend. It has plans to launch new games, but the probability that any one will be a big contributor is relatively small. The next two games are 'AlphaBetty Saga' and 'Paradise Bay,' which are both in soft launch and should be released soon."JPMorgan analyst Doug Anmuth stayed positive on King. He rates the stock as overweight with a price target of 20."Our overall thesis does not change — underlying network fundamentals are strong, as King benefits from scale; the overall Candy franchise is healthy; and we are heading into a handful of new mobile game launches in 2Q and into 2H15," he said in a note Friday.
The video game industry returned to growth in April, fueled by violent action games led by "Mortal Kombat X."
The top three best-selling games at U.S. retail last month were rated M for Mature, with content considered suitable for players ages 17 and up.
"Mortal Kombat X" from Time Warner (TWX) unit Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment was the No. 1 game in April. It's the latest in the long-running fight-to-the-death game series.

"Mortal Kombat X" features "blood and gore, intense violence and strong language," according to the Entertainment Software Rating Board. It's available for Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One and Windows PCs.

"After an opponent is defeated at the end of a match, players perform finishing moves called 'Fatalities' that can result in characters' impalement, dismemberment, or decapitation," ESRB said. "Many of these finishing moves depict over-the-top instances of violence: a character ripped in half; a character's face sliced off with a sword; a character mauled in half, leaving entrails exposed."

"Grand Theft Auto 5," the current chapter in the popular crime saga from Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), came in second place. Take-Two had three games in the top 10 last month, with the others being "NBA 2K15" and "Borderlands: The Handsome Collection."
GTA 5 features "blood and gore, intense violence, mature humor, nudity, strong language, strong sexual content and use of drugs and alcohol," ESRB said.

"Battlefield Hardline" from Electronic Arts (EA) was the third best-selling game in April, after being No. 1 in March. It features "blood and gore, intense violence, strong language and use of drugs," ESRB said.

Overall sales of new video game products at U.S. retail rose 3% year over year to $596 million in April, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. Game sales fell 6% in March, after being up 8% in February and down 5% in January, NPD said.
Physical sales of new game software rose 13% to $257 million, boosted by a growing installed base of next-generation consoles including the PS4, Xbox One and Nintendo's (NTDOY) Wii U.
In April, game hardware sales dropped 4% to $184 million and accessories sales dipped 3% to $155 million, NPD said.
The video game software sector ranks No. 6 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. That's up from No. 8 a week ago, No. 28 four weeks ago and No. 55 eight weeks ago.
Top publicly traded video game publishers have been surging thanks to the console upgrade cycle.
Electronic Arts stock is just below a 10-year high of 63.46 reached Monday, down a fraction in afternoon trading Friday.
Activision Blizzard (ATVI) hit a record high intraday Friday of 25.66 and was up more than 1% in afternoon trading.
RELATED:
Activision Q1 report calm before the 'Storm'

Video game sales returned to growth in June with an assist from the Caped Crusader.June sales of new video game products at U.S. retail rose 18% vs. June 2014 to $869.4 million, the NPD Group reported late Thursday. In May, game sales fell 13% year over year.
Video game hardware sales rose 8% to $313.1 million. Game software sales jumped 21% to $345.5 million. And game accessories sales leaped 34% to $210.7 million, NPD said.

Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, a unit of Time Warner (TWX), was the big winner among game publishers in June. It had the No. 1 game in "Batman: Arkham Knight" and had four of the top 10 best-selling games last month. Its other games in the top 10 included "Lego Jurassic World," "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" and "Mortal Kombat X."

Counting only its 12 days of sales in June, "Batman: Arkham Knight" is the second best-selling game of the year behind "Mortal Kombat X." If you include sales from hardware bundles, "Batman" would be the No. 1 game of the year so far.
"Batman" provided a boost to sales of Sony's (SNE) PlayStation 4 console, Benchmark analyst Mike Hickey said in a note Friday.

"With hits like 'Batman: Arkham Knight,' 'The Witcher 3,' 'Mortal Kombat X,' and 'Dying Light,' Warner Bros. Interactive is the top corporate publisher so far in 2015, with dollar sales growing 217% vs. the first half of 2014," NPD analyst Liam Callahan said in a statement.
Other top-selling games last month included "The Elder Scrolls Online: Tamriel Unlimited" from Bethesda Softworks and "Splatoon" from Nintendo (NTDOY).
Through the first half of the year, physical game software sales are up 3% year over year, Callahan said.
"With a strong lineup of games for the remainder of the year, there is the potential for a positive growth in the second half of the year as well," he said.

The video game software sector has been a top performer on the stock market lately. Leading publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) are both in record high territory. The sector ranks No. 9 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD.

Activision Blizzard, Electronic Arts, Time Warner and others are benefiting from the sweet spot of the console cycle. With a healthy installed base of the latest generation game consoles like Sony's PS4 and Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One, publishers are coming out with their best games.

"The rapid increase in the installed base for PS4 (over 20 million units) and the Xbox One (over 10 million) has created a large footprint for the software industry to sell into, which we believe bodes well for software growth in mid-to-late '15, especially as the pipeline improves later in the year," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a research report Friday.

The fighter previously underwent successful shipboard testing in May and live-bomb drops in June. The…

Stocks were lower near midday Wednesday following disappointing jobs data and a warning by Federal Reserve head Janet Yellen that equity valuations were "quite high."

The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were each down 0.3%. All three indexes are now below their 50-day moving averages. Volume was running 15% higher on the Nasdaq but was fractionally lower on the NYSE compared with Tuesday.

Yellen, speaking at a conference in Washington, said, "Equity market valuations at this point generally are quite high," adding that "there are potential dangers there." However, she said she doesn't see any bubbles forming.
Meanwhile, private U.S. employers added 169,000 jobs in April, the fewest since January 2014, according to payroll processor ADP. The government's key nonfarm payrolls report for April is due Friday.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) weighed on the Nasdaq, sliding 1% in heavy volume. Early in the session, the iPhone maker fell nearly 8% below a 133.70 flat-base buy point. A key IBD sell says to sell a stock if it falls 8% below the purchase price.

Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped 8% after the biotech company said it would buy Synageva BioPharma (GEVA) for $8.4 billion in cash and stock. The acquisition values Synageva at $230 a share, more than double Synageva's closing price Tuesday. Synageva was up 115% at midday.

Earnings season is in full swing, giving investors insight on market leaders such as Electronic Arts, as well as laggards in the current cycle. Five very different companies reported earnings after the market closed Tuesday, leading to spirited after-hours stock action, some soaring and some plummeting. Electronic Arts (EA) climbed in extended stock market trading to a 6-1/2-year high of…
Stock futures pointed to a vastly lower open Tuesday ahead of economic data on the service side of the economy.
Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 12 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures lost 2 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average fell 12 points.
On the economic front, the nation's trade deficit widened to a larger-than-expected $51.5 billion in March, mainly due to the West Coast port dispute.

The ISM service survey for April will be out at 10 a.m. ET. The consensus estimate from Econoday is calling for a flat reading of 56.5. Markit's service PMI will also be out at the same time. It is expected to fall to 57.7 from 59.2 in March.

In the stock market today, Qualys (QLYS) plunged 23% in premarket trading in reaction to late Monday's mixed Q1 results and soft outlook. But Robert W. Baird upgraded the stock to outperform from neutral. Shares of the cybersecurity firm had hit a record high in Monday's session.
CyberArk (CYBR), another security software provider, dropped 3% in premarket trade. It reports after Thursday's close.
Criteo (CRTO) jumped 5% after posting its latest quarterly results and raising guidance. The stock is in a flat base with 46.60 buy point.

Walt Disney (DIS) rose 2% in premarket trade after delivering fiscal Q2 earnings and sales that topped views. Results were helped by strength in theme parks and consumer products such as merchandise from its blockbuster "Frozen."
Earnings from Electronic Arts (EA), LendingClub (LC), Fossil (FOSL), Herbalife (HLF), SolarCity (SCTY) and Zillow (Z) are all due after the bell.

Stock markets overseas were mixed. European bourses were mostly higher despite ongoing drama in Greece. Germany's DAX was fractionally higher while France CAC 40 rose 0.1%. London's FTSE 100 climbed nearly 0.5%.

The Chinese stock market was down hard amid reports of higher margin requirements. European bourses were mostly higher despite ongoing drama in Greece. Germany's DAX was fractionally higher while France CAC 40 rose 0.1%. London's FTSE 100 climbed nearly 0.5%.The Chinese stock market was down hard amid reports of higher margin requirements. The Shanghai composite tumbled 4% and the Hang Seng lost 1.3%.
E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends

The Force was strong with Electronic Arts (EA) at the E3 video game show this week in Los Angeles. Among the major publicly traded game companies, EA stock got the biggest lift from the annual trade show, which ended Thursday. Electronic Arts shares were up 4% from the start of the week through the close of E3, thanks to major positive buzz about its upcoming game "Star Wars: Battlefront."

EA has three new "Star Wars" games coming out that seek to capitalize on excitement surrounding the latest movie in the space adventure series. The Walt Disney (DIS) movie, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," is due to open on Dec. 18.
EA could sell 9.5 million units of "Star Wars: Battlefront" in its fiscal 2016, which ends March 31, said Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson.

"We spent hands on time with 'Star Wars: Battlefront' and came away impressed," Olson said in a note Thursday. "Graphics were highly polished and gameplay mechanics fluid. The strongest component may be the attention to a detailed Star Wars environment, including the landscape of the map, clothes and weapons, as well as scale of AT-AT (walkers) and other vehicles."
Sales estimates going into E3 were conservative for the game, but are now on the rise, Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said in research note Thursday.

Microsoft (MSFT) stock was up 1.6% this week through Thursday, but mostly because of a corporate leadership shuffle, rather than its E3 announcements. Microsoft focused on exclusive game titles for its Xbox One console including its own sci-fi shooter "Halo 5: Guardians." Its holographic HoloLens glasses also caused a stir.

Nintendo (NTDOY) was the biggest loser on Wall Street during E3, with its U.S. shares down 3.3% from the start to the finish of the show. The Japanese video game firm was dinged by the game press for having a relatively weak game lineup and lack of surprises.
Nintendo did not hold a media briefing before or during the show. Instead it opted to webcast a prerecorded digital event for fans.

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) fell 1% during the E3 show. It also did not hold a media briefing before or during the show. It highlighted its new military shooter game "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3" and music game "Guitar Hero Live," among others.
But Activision stock could yet get a lift.

"Activision is the only video game stock that has exhibited a consistent tailwind for shares coming out of E3," Olson said. "Specifically, ATVI has been up between 5-10% in the 30 days after E3 in each of the last 4 years, showing that Activision management leaves investors optimistic following the event. Beyond E3, we view Activision as strategically well-positioned to benefit from a renewed growth period within the console gaming market driven by next-gen software."

E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends LOS ANGELES — Virtual reality games were the talk of the 2015 Electronic Entertainment Expo this week. Gamers buzzed about the immersive gaming experience, with many predicting it will revolutionize the industry. Just a few years ago, however, many gamers gushed about 3-D gaming and motion-controlled gaming using console-connected cameras…

The Electronic Entertainment Expo starts on Tuesday, and everyone who is anyone in the gaming industry will be there, including Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), Disney (DIS), Sony (SNE), Microsoft (MSFT), Facebook's (FB) Oculus VR and more. Virtual reality is expected to be a huge attention-getter this year as several big names are getting in the…

E3 2015 Video Game News: Games, Accessories, Trailers & Trends This year's Electronic Entertainment Expo, better known as E3, comes at an auspicious time for the video game industry. Leading publicly traded game companies have seen their stocks rally as the console upgrade cycle hits its sweet spot. Top publishers like Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) have helped…

During a treacherous first-quarter earnings season, positive reactions stand out. Shares of Activision Blizzard (ATVI) shot to a new all-time high Thursday and held gains as investors cheered its Q1 report.

The Santa Monica, Calif.-based game publisher reported earnings per share of 16 cents, topping views for 7 cents. Activision Blizzard's non-GAAP revenue came in at $703 million, breezing past views for $655.4 million.

Compared to the year-ago quarter, earnings fell 16% and revenue climbed 15%. It was the company's best quarterly revenue gain since the fourth quarter of 2012. The game maker also raised its full-year earnings guidance by a nickel to $1.20 a share.

The stock retook a 23.79 cup-with-handle buy point in big volume. Activision first cleared the buy point on April 23 in light volume. Shares turned lower and fell as much as 5% below the buy point, but never triggered a sell signal. The base is first-stage due to an undercut of the low of a prior pattern.

The stock is still in buy range, but keep in mind that making new purchases during a market correction carries high risk. With an 87 Composite Rating, it's the fourth-highest-rated stock in the gaming software group among stocks priced at least $10 a share.

Rival Electronic Arts (EA) hit a multiyear high Wednesday in response to its quarterly earnings results. The stock is in a buy range past a 58.97 late-stage flat-base entry. Shares have been unable to make much progress since clearing the buy point March 30.

Electronic Arts is still acting well with a 96 Relative Price Strength Rating, but it's in a risky late-stage situation and the market is under heavy distribution. Results for the Redwood City, Calif.-based game maker topped analyst consensus estimates despite a decline in earnings per share. Fiscal 2016 earnings guidance topped Wall Street's targets.

Chinese online game company NetEase (NTES) is extended 7.5% past a 118.57 buy point from a cup-without-handle base. The stock broke out in big volume on April 8. Shares tested investors below the entry, but never triggered a sell signal. The stock's most recent base pattern undercut a prior flat base, which reset the base count.
NetEase is tops in the group with a highest possible 99 Composite Rating. It will report first-quarter earnings on Wednesday after the close.

Recent new issue King Digital Entertainment (KING) will report Q1 results Thursday after the close. After a string of booming earnings and revenue, the company reported quarterly declines in the past two periods. Analysts expect the maker of casual games, including the "Candy Crush" franchise, to report earnings of 53 cents per share, down 10% from the year-ago quarter. The company will also be presenting at a JPMorgan (JPM) investor conference on May 19.

Gaming software stocks were Tuesday's top-performing industry group, up solidly on the back of a stellar earnings report from Take-Two Interactive (TTWO), which gapped up on monster volume. The industry group is up more than 20% year to date and is ranked No. 4 out of 197 groups. Take-Two reported fiscal Q4 EPS of 49 cents a share, well ahead…

Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), maker of the hit pro basketball video game "NBA 2K15," delivered a slam dunk Monday for its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings.Take-Two stock rose 18% to 28.62 on the stock market today. The game publisher, best known for its "Grand Theft Auto" series, hit a record high of 30.80 on Jan. 28.For the quarter ended March 31, Take-Two earned 49 cents a share excluding items, up 133% year over year and beating Wall Street's target of 27 cents. Sales rose 83% to $428 million, short of the $459 million expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Take-Two lost $2.99 a share in Q4, vs. a year-earlier profit of 40 cents a share. GAAP sales rose 54% to $300 million.The largest contributors to Take-Two's revenue growth in Q4 were "Grand Theft Auto 5," "Grand Theft Auto Online," "Evolve," "NBA 2K15" and "Borderlands: The Handsome Collection," the New York-based company said."Fiscal 2016 is off to a great start, highlighted by the April launch of 'Grand Theft Auto 5' for the PC, which has exceeded our expectations," Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said in a statement. "Throughout the coming year, we will continue to execute our proven strategy of launching a select array of the highest-quality titles, led by new annual releases of 'NBA 2K' and 'WWE 2K'; 'Battleborn,' a groundbreaking new intellectual property from Gearbox Software; and a soon-to-be announced new triple-A title from 2K."Price Target LoweredTake-Two had a "mixed quarter," but its outlook was "not as bad as feared," said Baird analyst Colin Sebastian in a research report Tuesday.Sebastian rates Take-Two stock as neutral and lowered his price target to 33 from 34.For its fiscal Q1, Take-Two expects to earn 30 cents a share on sales of $337.5 million. Analysts were expecting the company to lose 2 cents a share on sales of $207.2 million. Take-Two's guidance reflects continued strength in GTA 5, "Grand Theft Auto Online" and "NBA 2K15," Sebastian said.Its full-year guidance looks conservative, Sebastian said. Management expects fiscal 2016 sales and EPS to be $1.35 billion and 88 cents, respectively, well below consensus of $1.49 billion and $1.76.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said the soft full-year guidance reinforces the company's "underwhelming" game release slate.Take-Two's newest game property, "Evolve," was a disappointment in Q1, Pacific Crest analyst Evan Wilson said."At only 2.5 million units sell-in to date, it sold only half of our 5 million estimate and is one of the smallest selling AAA new (intellectual properties) of this generation," Wilson said. He rates Take-Two stock as sector weight.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Take-Two stock but cut his price target to 34 from 35.Meanwhile, two other major game publishers — Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronics Arts (EA) — are trading at or near recent highs. The video game sector in general is benefiting from the growing installed base of next-generation video game consoles and the rise of digital downloads including full games and add-on content.IBD's Computer Software - Gaming group ranks No. 4 out of 197 industry groups.Activision stock rose a fraction Tuesday to 25.48, just below its all-time high of 25.66 reached on Friday.Electronic Arts stock dipped 1% to 62.61, just below its 10-year high of 63.50 reached on Monday.RELATED:Blood and gore drive video game sales higher.

Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) spiked to a 10-year high on Wednesday after posting better-than-expected March quarter results and giving bullish guidance.A flurry of Wall Street analysts raised their price targets on the news.The Redwood City, Calif.-based company earned 39 cents a share excluding items on sales of $896 million in its fiscal Q4 ended March 31. On a year-over-year basis, earnings per share were down 19% and sales down 2%. But analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EA to earn 25 cents a share on sales of $850 million."Two years ago, we discussed a three-year plan to double non-GAAP operating margins to 20%," Chief Financial Officer Blake Jorgensen said in a statement late Tuesday. "Today, I'm happy to announce that we exceeded our goal a full year ahead of schedule. Looking forward, we anticipate continued earnings growth driven by our strong portfolio, investment in new (intellectual property), the market shift to digital, and on-going cost discipline."EA attributed its Q4 outperformance to top-selling games like "Battlefield Hardline" and "Dragon Age: Inquisition"; cost controls; and growth in digital game sales, including full-game downloads and mobile games.EA also gave June quarter and fiscal 2016 earnings guidance that was ahead of Wall Street's targets.EA stock rose 3% to 60.93 on Wednesday. Shares traded as high as 63.25 intraday, a 10-year high.Baird analyst Colin Sebastian reiterated his outperform rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 75 from 56.The company's "turnaround appears largely complete," Sebastian said in a note. EA is now "firing on all cylinders.""Looking ahead, we continue to view EA as a category leader well positioned to take advantage of dual secular trends: a ramping console cycle and the continued ramp in digital games," he said.Sterne Agee analyst Arvind Bhatia maintained his buy rating on EA stock and raised his price target to 70 from 65.Potential catalysts for the stock include news from the E3 video game conference in June, more aggressive stock buybacks and the release of "Star Wars Battlefront" on Nov. 17, Bhatia said in a note.EA management guided to sales of 9 million to 10 million units of the new "Star Wars" game, which comes out about a month before the highly anticipated new movie. That seems conservative, given that Walt Disney (DIS) noted that enthusiasm around the movie, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," is "unprecedented," Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a report. Pitz reiterated his hold rating on EA stock but bumped up his price target to 58 from 47.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson maintained his sector weight rating on EA."We are still looking for a better entry point, although we admit finding one in front of the 'Star Wars Battlefront' launch in November will be difficult," he said. "We think EA is fairly valued in low $60s."EA's pipeline of new game releases will be sparse for the next several months, said Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson. He maintained his overweight rating on EA and boosted his price target to 69 from 68. EA's slate will pick up this fall with the release of new FIFA and Madden NFL games, he said in a note.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter maintained his outperform rating on EA stock and raised his 12-month price target to 70 from 55.RELATED:Video game business a 'Battlefield' in March.

After eight consecutive months of year-over-year growth, U.S. retail sales of video game products dipped slightly in October. Game software sales were down 27% from the same month last year, the marketing research company NPD Group reported late Thursday. A drop in the number of games being released for previous-generation consoles hurt sales of new software at retail, NPD analyst…
Stocks hit fresh session highs late Thursday and were on track for a fourth straight gain.

Helped by Internet and computer hardware stocks, the Nasdaq rallied 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 1%. Volume was tracking modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today

Tata Motors (TTM) stretched its gain to 3%. Earlier, the stock cleared a 48.28 buy point in a double-bottom base in heavy trading. The Indian carmaker has a Composite Rating of 83, the highest in the Auto Manufacturers group. Tata was mentioned in International Leaders earlier this month.

Under Armour (UA) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is in a flat base within a larger pattern. Telsey Advisory Group upgraded shares to outperform from market perform Wednesday.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) reversed and fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close. The chipmaker is expected to earn 65 cents a share, up 41% from a year ago. That would mark a second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Microsemi is working on a potential base.

Investors aren't so sweet on "Candy Crush Saga" video game maker King Digital Entertainment (KING) ahead of its second-quarter earnings report, due out after the market close Tuesday. King shares were down 3.5%, near 18.50, in afternoon trading in the stock market today. London-based King made its IPO debut on March 26 at 22.50, and King stock peaked at 23.48…

Video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI) delivered better-than-expected Q1 results late Tuesday as it prepares for a coming "Storm" next month.The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company earned 16 cents a share excluding items, down 16% from Q1 2014, on sales of $703 million, down 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 7 cents EPS on sales of $655 million.Activision stock was up more than 5% to above 24 in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Activision stock hit an all-time high of 24.50 in intraday trading.Activision's Q1 was fueled by the continued success of its "Call of Duty" and "Hearthstone" franchises.For Q2, Activision expects to earn 7 cents a share ex items on sales of $650 million. Analysts were modeling 9 cents and $690 million.Activision raised its full-year adjusted EPS forecast to $1.20 from $1.15 and its sales target to $4.425 billion from $4.4 billion. Wall Street had been expecting $1.18 EPS on sales of $4.443 billion.Taking On 'League Of Legends'Up next for Activision is the launch of "Heroes of the Storm," a competitor to "League of Legends" from Riot Games, which is majority owned by Chinese Internet firm Tencent Holdings (TCEHY). Tencent also has a stake in Activision."Heroes of the Storm," a free-to-play online team brawler game, is set to launch on June 2. About 11 million people have signed up for a closed beta test of the game."The free-to-play game could be very profitable, but only if it can attract a massive, engaged audience," Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz said in a note. "Activision gives the game away for free; users pay to unlock additional heroes or in-game cosmetic items."The biggest, most profitable games in the world use the free-to-play business model, he said. But the success of such games is difficult to predict, Pitz said. Pitz rates Activision stock a buy with a price target of 26.Cowen analyst Doug Creutz said the "Heroes" game is "looking like a winner," based on enthusiasm during the beta test. He rates Activision stock outperform.At least four analysts raised their price targets on Activision stock after the company announced Q1 earnings. Analysts with Baird, Cowen and Piper Jaffray bumped their targets to 27 from 26. Sterne Agee analyst Arvind Bhatia raised his target to 27 from 24.Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said Activision's 2015 guidance looks "overly conservative." The company likely will benefit from renewed console software sales growth and big titles like "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3," due out Nov. 6."Management has historically under-promised and over-delivered," he said. Olson reiterated his overweight rating on Activision stock.But Activision will face increased competition this holiday season, going up against titles like Microsoft's (MSFT) "Halo 5" and Electronic Arts' (EA) "Star Wars Battlefront," said Baird analyst Colin Sebastian.Sterne Agee's Bhatia said 2015 could be a "trough year" for Activision, with the company's expanded product portfolio driving meaningful growth in 2016.Activision has been known to be overly dependent on "Call of Duty," "World of Warcraft" and "Skylanders," he said. But this is changing with recent launches and upcoming games such as "Hearthstone," "Heroes of the Storm," "Overwatch" and "Guitar Hero," Bhatia said.RELATED:EA stock hits 10-year high on Q4 beat, strong guidance.

Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.
Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.
Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.
Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.

Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.

Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares of the maker of fitness trackers bounced back Monday after hitting a record low Friday.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.
